column2: I am not giving you guys my personal opinion of what I think the climb is rated. I am reciting the consensus rating from over 30 years of people climbing the thing. You don't call Full Service V11
column3: you don't call High Plains Drifter V8
column4: and you don't call So High V6. This isn't 8a.nu
column5: you can't just go around throwing out any number you feel like.

column1: So High wasn't even the point of my rant. I was bashing the article itself
column2: the person who wrote
column3: and the magazine that published it. These people in the media should be obligated to report accurate information. Are we really going to respect Lisa for climbing a V6 more than a V5...please. And did they really have to spew the rating that many times
column4: did they want to make sure that we didn't forget that she was climbing a V6";;"0";"gA==";"velqxumx";"1";"0";;"3";"0";"0"

column1: 2399;"17";"1";"656";"0";"76.175.127.204";"1208613358";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re:";"[quote="socalbolter":g7cyvczr]None of them would qualify as anything much anymore
column2: but prior to the bridge glue-ups and the gyms that came after them
column3: these were the only urban practice spots.

column1: Most of these (and many more) were detailed in Randy Vogel's Hunk Guide back in the 80's.  Most of them were solitary boulders of questionable quality.  At least some of them are now surrounded by homes and others have been mostly forgotten altogether.

El car is def. not a single boulder....and should never be forgotten.......there is so much there under all that dense overgrowth.......not to mention the history....we climbed there for several years in the early 90's...many old routes and a huge amount of new ones....its a great spot if your a true hardcore.....watch out for the big cats though.....old underground guidebooks can still be found....ours had over 200 routes listed";"d1e2fd596849c921eae141c0baf3d947";"0";"gA==";"g7cyvczr";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

column1: Your observation is pretty valid though.  In many mags
column2: forums
column3: videos
column4: etc. you see route and problem ratings ranging up and down on the whim of the source.  Not real sure there's ONE reason for this
column5: but in the magazines' case I would guess that they are trying to magnify the sport's heroes.  Hero worship sells mags and gear
column6: which puts more money into the industry - not necessarily a bad thing.

column1: Nothing at all intended against Lisa
column2: but she is definitely a hero to many climbers.  And while the difference between a V5 and V6 is minimal to most
column3: it is huge to those that can't climb the grade.

column1: This subtle grade shift seems to be gaining steam across the whole sport and makes me realize more why some of the better climbers are no longer (directly) rating their own climbs.";;"0";"gA==";"1qr5n71x";"1";"0";;"16";"0";"0"
102;"15";"6";"16";"0";"68.5.54.187";"1191889090";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"0";;;"[quote="rtm":1o86m40v][quote="a.ron":1o86m40v]I hear you wrote a guide book. Couldn't you have fixed the problem there?
i try to keep my personal influence to a minimum[/quote:1o86m40v]
I think this is the only unbiased way in which to write a guide.  Many of the ratings shown in my Santa Monicas books were higher than I thought they should be
column2: but represented the consensus opinion I received from folks who frequented those areas.  In hindsight
column3: perhaps I should have modified a few of the grades
column4: but overall I think I did the right thing.

column1: As long as something is not terribly sandbagged (read: potentially hazardous outcome to the climber)
column2: it's probably not that big of a deal one way or the other.";;"0";"gA==";"1o86m40v";"1";"0";;"16";"0";"0"

column1: 104;"8";"6";"16";"0";"68.5.54.187";"1191890195";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"0";;;"Ah the glue - ups... they were fun to make and even more fun once there was a regular group climbing at them.
And Paul may remember when the twins' balls hadn't yet dropped
column2: but I remember when he and Chris were in that same position (well
column3: almost...their's might have just dropped).

column1: As much as I am involved in the whole "plastic" side of our sport
column2: I really don't climb much indoors anymore.  I do
column3: however
column4: remember some really good times with the original Rockreation crowd back in the day.  Those were some good times with good people
column5: filled with unconditional support and friendship.  It was wonderful watching everyone getting stronger every week.  Now I see Paul and Robert and everyone (who's still climbing) continuing to get even better.  While my personal climbing levels seem to be lowering with each passing season
column6: I'm psyched to see so many of my old friends still getting stronger and succeeding on their projects.  We all may not have always seen eye-to-eye on everything
column7: but I'm very proud of you guys.

column1: Everything seems so much more splintered and clique-ish these days.  It would be great if everyone could take a big step backwards and enjoy (together) the amazing climbing options we have at our disposal.

I'm also glad to see Robert taking on this website project.  I could definitely see it becoming a very positive force in uniting the So Cal bouldering scene and in spreading the word to those not fortunate enough to live here.";;"0";"gA==";"2gw61hvk";"1";"0";;"16";"0";"0"
105;"21";"1";"16";"0";"68.5.54.187";"1191892639";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"0";;"Steele Valley";"If you guys are interested in some new bouldering options once the snow falls at Black Mountain and the Tram
column2: let me know.

column1: While Steele Valley is not of the caliber of those two areas
column2: it does have a lot of developed problems and potential for many more.

column1: The climbing is somewhat similar to other Riverside and San Diego bouldering areas
column2: but the amount of rock out there puts it in a league of its own.

column1: Currently there are over 300 problems from VB to V11
column2: but there is room for much harder problems.  In fact
column3: there are some that have been tried off and on over the years and will definitely go
column4: but will be well into the double digits.  There are enough classics already established to keep you busy for a few trips
column5: but most people will feel the pull of the undeveloped rock that surrounds the established zones.

column1: For the most part the rock is good quality granite and most of the holds are either slopers or crisp little patina-type crimps.  Problem lengths vary from short little things with just a few hard moves to well into the highball range.  There are a few really steep things there
column2: but the angles are more on par with what can be found in the Buttermilks and the other Bishop area granite options.

column1: The area is approached on legal dirt roads and most of the area is on BLM land.  There are some great circuit areas that we had first climbed at back in the late 90's
column2: but they are on privately owned land and some of that land has since been built on (homes).

it will be the perfect time to check it out.  I'd like to see the area get more traffic and development as I have not been out there regularly since around 2001.  There's plenty left to do there and the area could really become something with some more work.

column1: There have been a number of pics posted over on rockclimbing.com if you want to see what some of it looks like.  Here's a link to the area page over there:
As I said before it's not the best area in So Cal
column2: but is worth a closer look.

column1: 114;"15";"6";"3";"0";"75.80.236.132";"1191953191";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"0";;;"allow me to elaborate on my answer to a-ron about rating stuff for my guides.
in the case of Clawing at the belly of the beast
column2: Ryan Held was the only person to climb the thing at the time that I finished the guide
column3: so I had no choice but to rely solely on his opinion.

column1: y2k - I knew that Matt Beebe gave it a V9 or 10 rating when he Fa'd it
column2: but several people that I know repeated it quickly and gave it a V8 rating. At that point I could have given it a 8/9 rating
column3: but I hear people complain about split ratings so I try to avoid them
column4: and given Jtree's tradition of sandbagging
column5: I concluded that V8 was acceptable.

column1: Pumping Monzonite - this answer is much more complex. The 1st edition of Shermans Hueco guide lists Pumping Monzonite as an equivilent of V8
column2: plus we were climbing it from a little lower than the oldschool start
column3: which made it even harder still. I felt that
column4: given the historical status of the problem
column5: rerating it would be disrespectful to Jtree and to the past generations of Jtree boulderers. And that goes the same for alot of older problems in Jtree. Unless somethings breaks or the problem changes
column6: I think that these older climbing areas should be considered fulcrums to guage ratings
column7: to prevent grade inflation.";;"0";"EA==";"ml23u4ix";"1";"0";;"3";"0";"0"

column1: I can tell you that 4 or 5 years ago when I started to seriously suss out Tram with the intent of writing a guide for the place
column2: I estimated that there were around 300 problems. During the course of assembling the book
column3: the damn area grew and grew.  I ended up re-organizing the book over and over
column4: finally I just had to stop adding problems. I listed about 800 problems
column5: maybe another 100 have gone up since then. Since the book was finished I have had time again the explore at tram
column6: and have immediately stumbled upon several new areas (to me). It seems that there were several areas that hard core locals did not want to be in this edition of the book. Anyways
column7: in the past 2 or 3 months
column8: I have seen some of the best problems that I have seen at Tram period. Enough to fill another book! It was like having a whole new climbing area plopped in our laps. I also suspect that these same locals have even more areas at Tram that they are keeping quite about.

2913;"341";"1";"9";"0";"76.249.189.21";"1213239585";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Wounded Knee";"So two weeks ago I folded my knee sideways at the Tram and yes it hurts. I went to the specialist today and the good news is the knee is bruised/strained. I am being told to take one month off and ride a stationary bike with little resistance and Naproxin 500mg twice a day for a month.

column2: this is my modified plan:

column1: 20 minutes on the bike on level three. This is literally no workout. My heart rate is at 80. This is boring. I am following this up with one-legged system training. I plan to do 100 move sessions every other day. I figure I can keep the core strong and since the wall is small I can control the falls and rest the knee. I am going to stay off the rock until I go to SB in two weeks.
Wish me luck. I hate resting injuries.

column1: i'm a sissy. i hate pain. i will do all i can (including large amounts of drugs) to avoid and mask pain. i will even open myself up to all kinds of internet flaming by asking the following question:
how the hell do i get the pads of my fingertips to stop hurting so bad?
yup. i've climbed for a year now
column2: but have never had my fingertips hurt this bad. it first started last month in Bishop. The crimps didn't cut my fingers -- they just made em hurt like hell. Add two recent weekends in Jtree....oooo man. i can barely type this.

column1: any veterans got any tips? ...cos i gots me some blood beneath these fingertips...

270;"35";"1";"18";"0";"68.5.47.26";"1193507275";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"0";;;"I guess I like the simplicity of the B scale in that to me it just says hard
column2: harder
column3: and really hard. Obviously no one is going to bring back the B scale
column4: but personally I can't really differentiate between many problems given widly differing V grades. I think certain boulder problems cater to a persons strength or can exploit a certain weakness
column5: things like reach finger size etc. To me that makes it rather pointless to try and assign a specific number to one of these things. I suppose however if you're a climber operating at the top end of the spectrum you need to continually create bigger numbers and the V scale allows for that. Since I am not I guess the numbers just don't really matter to me that much. This entire conversation has me feel rather nostalgic and given me sense that the time is right for the comeback of lycra tights. Luckily I kept mine from the eighties
column6: fashion is cyclical you know.";;"0";"gA==";"2ucdj85u";"1";"0";;"18";"0";"0"

column1: 312;"17";"1";"9";"0";"76.243.134.45";"1193748862";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"0";;"Best Area";"As one of the earlier Tram boulderers I would say the Tram is good. There is certainly an abundance of climbing and potential
column2: but does volume of rock equate to quality of climbs? There is an area in Vegas called Mecca. Mecca has ten times the potential of the Tram
column3: but the area is only worth one visit at best. The climbing at the Tram again is good. I would definitely send people there. There are some classics and I am sure since the last time I was there there are more
column4: but the rock quality is what it is and it is not Hueco or Font. I consider those areas to be top quality. I would say in So Cal Black Mountain has the best rock quality. The Underground although limited is the closest thing to Hueco and the Tram is better then Josh. Stoney is fun
column5: but aside from the history just that. That is my 2 cents.

column1: It must really have been a long time since you last visited Tram.  The rock quality at Tram is far superior to that of Black Mtn.  No it's not Hueco or Font
column2: but it's a hell of lot closer
column3: and you don't have to jump through the hoops you do at Hueco.  Anyway last time I checked neither of those areas were in Socal.  The best thing about Tram is that I have a feeling that despite the 800 or so problems RTM will have listed in his guide the best prolems are still out there waiting to be found.";;"0";"gA==";"1ldjudqv";"1";"0";;"10";"0";"0"

column1: 376;"36";"4";"23";"0";"71.254.136.57";"1193945969";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"0";;;"The comp actually turned out really well. We set 53 problems the two days before and a lot of them were REALLY good. The black light setup was fucking awesome and it took a shit load of work to keep the awesome black light feel and still let the climbers be able to see what was going on.

About 40 people competed which I think is a damn good turnout for a Wednesday night especially considering a lot of people already have plans on Halloween. It was also really fun to have everyone competing in costumes... there were some really cool ones out there.
The Top 3 in each category were
3. Deanna Lapine (Might be wrong spelling of last name.)
3. Norman (Don't know last name but he's got long ass black hair.)

The winners of the four categories all received Mad Pads which was pretty cool considering that it wasn't a high profile comp. They also gave away a bunch of Five Ten and Mad Rock stuff for the free raffle.
Overall it was a pretty damn good comp and I think we are going to be doing more of these black light comps in the future so I'll keep ya'll posted.
Hopefully I'll get my hands on some pics and I'll post them up here.";;"0";"CA==";"14nsdvh7";"1";"0";;"23";"0";"0"

377;"15";"6";"30";"0";"207.155.135.230";"1193946417";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"0";;;"I find the ratings just fine. Nothing sandbag about most things I've climbed at any crag. I just assume I have more to learn if I struggle on it. Y2K? I felt it was v8
column2: and still do. My new line to the right
column3: starting at Y2K
column4: called tentatively Right2K and going to the right arete then up
column5: is possibly one grade harder.

column2: learning is always the preferred option in contrast to complaining about what I can't do
column3: or what seems very hard. Josh requires a huge amount of foot trust and foot usage. Balance is equally important. After climbing Jtree for almost 3 decades
column4: I feel that what sets it apart from other crags is a much higher degree of frictional trust than any other rock type. Without it
column5: the moves just feel harder. This makes the conditions all the more important. Josh doesn't necessarily favor strong fingers.

column1: I think the most accurate a rating can be is within 2 grades
column2: or say a v7 or v8. With so many body types and climbing strengths and weaknesses
column3: chances are no one will agree on one number. That said
column4: if it's called v6 or v9
column5: those are just 1 grade differences from anyone's specific grade of v7 or v8.

column1: What I mean is if on a given day
column2: i send something and think it's v7
column3: then return and repeat it several times over months
column4: and find it more a kin to v8
column5: I personally wouldn't feel like I sandbagged someone if I told them initially it was v7. Another person who rates it v9 would be within my 2 grade rule for accuracy (my final v8 and their v9 rating)
column6: making the original v7 rating only two numbers off someone else's rating.

column1: So what constitutes a sandbag? Good question. If a vote was taken on rating Pumping Monzonite
column2: the final computed average might be something like v7.692 (hypothetical example). So is v7 wrong? Is v8 wrong? Is v6 or v9 wrong? Maybe these latter two are not within the "accepted" numbers for such a well known problem
column3: but I wouldn't call them sandbag. On the other hand
column4: if a guide book printed PM as v6
column5: having been repeated so often
column6: it would be sandbag. But with climbs that have minimal repeats
column7: that much deviation is not extreme. In other words
column8: I differentiate between some one's off the cuff comment of a rating with what a guidebook might publish it as.

column1: Sidenote: All Washed Up is an excellent example of what josh rock is all about and calling it v7 seems a bit high to me
column2: but calling it v6 is simply not a sandbag. how could it? It's one rating different given so many different types of people and styles of climbing.";;"0";"CA==";"lmg98az5";"1";"0";;"30";"0";"0"

column1: Sick party Aron!  The ostrich was glamorous.
Debated whether or not to share this here but figured why not?

So I get home Sunday morning and am pretty tipsy so just strip down and climb into bed. Well I get up with a splitting headache to look down at my underwear from the night before. At first they looked soiled. Upon further inspection I realized that they had a huge hole and a bunch of dried blood. Thoughts start flashing through my head... was I gang raped? was I having my first period? Well I make it to the bathroom to "inspect" and find a two inch gash on my right butt cheek. Turns out
column2: the jeans I was wearing had a bent button that created some "friction" upon hurling myself repeatidly headfirst over the slide on the bounce house.  Great party Aron
column3: thanks for the scars! ";;"0";"CA==";"v3loq0xy";"1";"0";;"24";"0";"0"

column2: I guess nobody will guess who that is.

column1: apparently jumping off of a 25' roof onto the bounce house inflicts pain as well. A slight case of whiplash always feels good in the morning. Alcohol was not an influence in this one. I had been looking at this before the party started and brushed it off
column2: but after watching a bunch of drunk retarded emo kids do it. . . .

column1: . .  . Barracho Bouldererist decided that once everyone left
column2: it was time to try it ourselves. Barracho just might have bottomed out and seriously bruised his tail bone but was heavily inebriated so pain was put off until morning. I lucked out by not bottoming out
column3: just slamming my chin into my stomach.

column2: good times were had
column3: costumes were cool
column4: music was. . .well. . interesting
column5: and the turnout was pretty good.

540;"86";"1";"23";"0";"71.254.136.57";"1194655678";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"0";;"JoMo";"Just a heads up because I know theres a lot of Joe's friends that post on here...

Joe fell at the Ventura gym last night and busted up his leg pretty good. His femur broke in half in the dead center of his left leg. It was pretty fucking terrible as I'm sure you all can imagine. The paramedics took him to Ventura county hospital where he had surgery to put a metal rod down the center of his leg.
Not suprisingly Joe treated the whole incident with a pretty comical attitude
column2: joking with the paramedics and hospital staff and having all of us cracking up. I talked to him this morning and he sounds like nothing even happened... though he will be pretty debilitated for a while.

column1: Just wanted to post here so you guys can send some positive vibes or whatever his way. The guys a fucking trooper as I'm sure all of you know but anyone in his situation could use all the good energy they can get.";;"0";"CA==";"1r7tejrl";"1";"0";;"23";"0";"0"

the problem that starts at Angus and heads out right across the seam is Malcolm. Is was done back at the time Angus was first sent. There was also an eliminate that exit in the middle of the boulder off to the right. I am not sure what we called it. There is also a traverse that goes no where in a cave up the hill called the Angus traverse (V7?). There is a little history about Angus.

Erin (the wife) and I left Santa Monica around 7:30a to meet up with [url=http://www.socalbouldering.com/forum/profile.php?mode=viewprofile&u=23:1vzyzntx]B_Held[/url:1vzyzntx] and [url=http://www.socalbouldering.com/forum/profile.php?mode=viewprofile&u=53:1vzyzntx]2Stars[/url:1vzyzntx] at the tram.  After stopping for some decent coffee
column2: we made good time and arrived at the Tram station at 9:40a.

column1: After paying our fees (I've GOT to get an annual pass)
column2: I saw two gents stroll in with pads.  "Is one of you Brady?"  ... "yeah
column3: he is" and matt pointed to his friend.  we introduced each other and hopped on the tram.

column1: Erin and I followed Matt and Brady down the path towards the ranger station.  We were looking for "Vanishing Point" (v9)
column2: but all we knew was it was "above the ranger station."  5-months pregnant Erin decided to opt out and watch all our stuff as the other 3 of us spread out along the mountainside.  After about 15 minutes
column3: Matt called out that he'd found the boulder.

column1: I told Matt and Brady that VP was out of my league
column2: but after watching them on the seam
column3: i took a few shots at it.  I managed to work my way up the seam
column4: but the long reach out left was too much for me.  Brady made it look easy.

column2: Erin and I left Brady and Matt and struck out towards the Cube.  Unfortunately
column3: all the rock arrows I left just off the path pointing towards the Cube had been moved
column4: so I missed the exit on the first pass.  Once I remembered the exit
column5: though
column6: we struck off up the small valley.  Following [url=http://www.socalbouldering.com/forum/profile.php?mode=viewprofile&u=5:1vzyzntx]a.ron[/url:1vzyzntx]'s crude map
column7: I managed to spot Green Tea Arete and worked on that a bit.

column1: I had it written down as a V3 -- maybe if I knew it was a V4
column2: I would have tried a little harder. Either way
column3: I couldn't figure it out and opted for something easier with a better landing.

column1: We cruised to the Cube.  On my last trip up in July
column2: I'd tried The World's Hardest V2 (v1)
column3: and managed to thoroughly piss myself off that I got shut down.  In my frustration over not sending Green Tea Arete
column4: I promptly sent.  Unfortunately
column5: the video of my second send was sloppy as hell:

column2: using a.ron's map
column3: and the GPS that [url=http://www.socalbouldering.com/forum/profile.php?mode=viewprofile&u=3:1vzyzntx]rtm[/url:1vzyzntx] had given me
column4: we moved west trying to find either Standing on the Head of the Dragon (v4) or Buddha Belly Arete (v2).  I missed the Dragon (managed to find it on our way out)
column5: unfortunately.  When I saw there'd be some hiking up hill again
column6: I left Erin and struck out to find the Buddha.  After about 15 min
column7: I finally found the boulder and hiked back down to get Erin and the gear.

column1: I warmed up on this thing (know what it is?).  About 10 yards downhill from Buddha:
Looked like there was a hard sit start
column2: but I did an easy stand start to get the blood flowin'.  Unfortunately
column3: I think I made a big mistake that day -- I worked too long on a hard problem (Vanishing Point)
column4: and it burned me out.  My arms just gave out after about my 2nd try -- after that it was diminishing returns.  It didn't help that the ledge just before the top is also covered in dirt and lichen and I couldn't get in a good position to clean it off.  Either way
column5: this problem was really cool
column6: and I'll definitely make a return trip to finish it off.

column2: I luckily spotted the Dragon off in the trees.  I'll be coming back to that next time as well.

column1: And that's it.  It was already 4:30pm and the sun was going down.  Here's what I learned:  have a strategy.  Want to send a ton of climbs?  Don't work on a climb 4 grades above your current highest.  It'll burn you out and won't leave you anything to send with.  Or
column2: choose to screw around on something hard
column3: take pictures and have fun
column4: but don't expect to send measly V2's later on in the day. I got a little greedy and wanted to do both.

column1: Off to Palm Desert from Wed night through Sun morn...family reunion.  I ate way too much food.  God bless the La Quinta Thanksgiving buffet.
My wife is cool.  She agreed to change up our schedule to accommodate a trip to Jtree before we head back to LA.  Sunday morning
column2: we drove out to the south entrance and drove through the whole park
column3: ending up at Cap Rock.  I'd never gone through the south way
column4: so it was nice to mix it up.

column1: I didn't have my bouldering guide
column2: so I was going off memory.  I quickly found Fry boulder just off the road.  We parked near Cap Rock
column3: hiked along the nature loop
column4: and peeled off towards Fry.  What a cool problem!  It took me a few tries
column5: but I managed to figure out the starting move and got the rest fairly quickly.

column1: We then cruised over to Stonehenge and found Picture Perfect.
Then I took Erin to Real Hidden Valley to have our lunch.  Until that day
column2: Erin had only been to Jtree once.  And it sucked.  I rolled the dice and got us a campsite back in May for Memorial Day.  We baked and she hated it.  We ended up cutting the trip short and going to Palm Springs and the tram (my first trip up).

column1: After a day of hiking all over the Tram
column2: Josh was a nice change for her since the approaches were quite easier.  We grabbed lunch
column3: and I took some pictures of So High
column4: etc. for [url=http://mountainproject.com/v/california/joshua_tree_national_park/real_hidden_valley/106048550?highlightphrase=so+high&:1vzyzntx]Mountain Project.[/url:1vzyzntx]

column2: v3
column3: Shipwreck Boulders.  My first flashed v3 at Josh.

column1: We cruised off to Manx boulders.  If I had something left
column2: I wanted to work on Undertow.  Someone posted on one of my other trip reports that I was missing out by doing the other problems at Manx and skipping Undertow.
I did an old favorite: The Boxer Problem (v2)

column1: Then set to work on Undertow.  I flashed it.  Sweet.

column2: I ran out of memory card during the video.  I tried to shoot more video (after 3 successful sends)
column3: but was burned out. Ah well. Happy with the flash.

column2: we drove over towards the Outback so I could take some more pictures for Mountain Project ... this time of False Hueco.  I did the traverse (v2) which was fun.

column1: I started to work on the Torquemeister (v4)
column2: but my right arm gave out.  All done.

column1: We left the park and cruised out to the 10 freeway
column2: where we managed to sit in stop-and-go traffic for about an hour until we hit Riverside.  I think this was the only time I didn't care I was sitting in traffic ... good climbing days do that to ya.

column1: then keep everyone away from those .. and put them on some well known V2's for their warmups. ";;"0";"GA==";"2kkke4ya";"1";"0";;"21";"0";"0"
Well crap ... it's starting to look like Bishop may be a better
column2: dryer option after all.  Let's see what the forecast says tomorrow or Thurs.

column1: I was SO digging the idea of a Steele Valley Saturday + Tram or Josh Sunday.  :sigh:

column2: you sure do scare easily.

column1: If I canceled climbing trips over the years based on forecasts like that I never would have left home.";;"0";"GA==";"38wvnagw";"1";"0";;"16";"0";"0"
i'm not too worried usually.  but reading the weather reports on this storm
column2: it basically comes out as "we have no idea what the hell this thing is gonna do."  the 5-day forecasts changed from yesterday's "chance" to 30%
column3: and now 40%.

column1: don't worry. not making a decision till probably Thurs night. ";;"0";"GA==";"fnhipuuz";"1";"0";;"21";"0";"0"

column1: Latest forecast shows some rain the night before and a very slight chance in the way early morning on Saturday.  Due to the rock type out there everything drys almost immediately
column2: so I think we're looking good even if the moisture does arrive.

column1: Looking forward to showing you guys what I think has the potential to become a really nice local area.  I sometimes wish I had remained more active out there
column2: but I'm drawn much more to routes than boulders.  Anyway
column3: I'm sure a lot of cool new stuff is going to be climbed once you all get motivated on the place.";;"0";"gA==";"119kvuxg";"1";"0";;"16";"0";"0"

856;"148";"1";"23";"0";"71.254.136.57";"1196447144";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"0";;;"Oooooh... I call being the carebear sandwiched between the other two sliding down the rainbow... uhhh... nevermind.

Anyways... my reason for disliking Steele Valley is last time I was convinced to go by someone that said there was endless potential. I ended up walking around for 3 hours looking for some fresh un-climbed-on rock and ended up finding only one boulder that looked worth trying out of hundreds. Maybe I was just searching in the wrong spot but I covered a couple acres of boulders and found only one climb that looked cool. That was very unmotivating... especially after climbing at the Tram a lot where an equal search would yeild tons of potentially good problems.

column2: there are a lot of really cool looking established problems that I should have gotten on and I'm sure there is potential that I missed... but I tend to be the kind of person where one bad experience makes me stay away for good.";;"0";"gA==";"3s9h7fd5";"1";"0";;"23";"0";"0"

column3: saying a crag is better than another is irrelevant. I like to joke that the Beach is the best since it's so esoteric in nature.

column1: What one decides as important for "better crag" status may not be as important to someone else. Each crag has lessons to learn and moves to perfect. In this light
column2: it's just a process of discovering and learning that makes any crag worthy of what it offers. And for me
column3: being away from the madding crowds
column4: makes all crags better... than not being there. ";;"0";"gA==";"1gjtsmt7";"1";"0";;"30";"0";"0"

column1: Aside from the slopes that we added problems to
column2: I have not looked too extensively on the surrounding hillsides.  I'd sure like to think that there was equal potential on those other slopes
column3: but perhaps I'm wrong in that assumption.

column1: And I would certainly agree that when compared to the Tram
column2: this place blows.  The main appeal for my repeated trips back in the late 90's was it's convenience and short distance from my home and work.
I know of a half dozen lines that are good and will certainly be double-digit.  I'd like to see those climbed at some point since I can't seem to succeed on them.  Aside from that there are some good
column3: harder problems that I'd hope to see repeated.

column1: If you feel inclined to give it another shot
column2: I'd be happy to show you around
column3: but I'm not going to be the Care Bear sitting in front of you.

column1: after the day at Steele Valley
column2: I crashed at a.ron's
column3: then headed out to Josh Sunday morning.

column1: i tried to find some of a.ron's friends from rockreation
column2: but they weren't around.  so i headed out to find some new stuff.
in a turnout just west of Steve Canyon.  headed west.  warmed up on Don't Mess With Texas (v1):

column1: then i did Western Roll (v3).  on the way out
column2: i did Lip Service (v2).

column1: had some cup o' noodles in the back of my car in the turnout and watched some folks do Season Opener ( 5.8 ) on the west wall of Steve Canyon.  after lunch
column2: i went off looking for Lizzy Boulder.

column1: i managed to pass it the first time
column2: but backed up and found it.
my first V4 at Joshua Tree!  (I didn't like the "Fred Nicole" crimper
column3: so i skipped it...might have made it easier...but i'm counting it!)

column1: The music in this video certainly suited the mood of the day...very chill.  i think i saw 5 people the whole day.  and perfect weather.  no winds.  about 50-55deg.

column2: from atop Lizzy Boulder

column1: after taking another 4-5 laps on NSTL
column2: I went off to work Roof Romp (v4) around the corner (north) of White Rastafarian.
but couldn't stick one of the last moves getting out the roof.  managed to tweak my shoulder.  no send today.
ran by aron's to check how his Christmas lights were coming
column3: then found me a DoubleDouble.

column1: Climbs the best quality rock I've found in the entire area.

It's about 30 feet tall and gets progressively steeper the higher you get until you suddenly realize that it's too late to downclimb or to escape off to the left or right.  At that point it really is easier to keep on going.
There are no real handholds on the thing and the climbing is insecure all the way to the top.

column2: but it's probably at least V6 or so and definitely gets your attention.";;"0";"IA==";"2bqv1qge";"1";"0";;"16";"0";"0"

Motivated (for the entire group's efforts) and very humble.
A good role model for not letting yourself get too full of yourself.  Also nice for the rest of us that aren't built like twigs to see what's possible.
All in all a great ambassador for bouldering.";;"0";"IA==";"264wunza";"1";"0";;"16";"0";"0"

column1: 970;"164";"6";"16";"0";"68.109.67.8";"1197055293";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"0";;;"Many times he has called into question some of my local FA ascents in a variety of ways
column2: including arguing with belayers from some of those FA's
column3: posting slanderous comments on internet forums
column4: spreading rumors at the crags
column5: etc.

column1: Recently ran into him at the Quarry
column2: where he and his partner were having difficulty with the crux moves on one of routes there.  I tried to help him with some beta
column3: but he questioned the beta and (once again) my ability to have done the route.  I had been cleaning on another new route that morning
column4: was tired and had not yet done any climbing.  Regardless
column5: I could not walk away from the confrontation.  Instead
column6: I put on my shoes and climbed the route.  Using my beta
column7: both he and his partner were able to do the crux moves
column8: but not once have I received an apology for this or any prior (or later) actions.  To this day he still tells whomever will listen that I'm a fraud.

column1: I try to be as supportive as possible to everyone I come across
column2: and to make my interactions within the climbing community positive.  As such
column3: I have little respect for people like Joe.";;"0";;"3iu01t9v";"1";"0";;"16";"0";"0"

column2: I am looking for a new crash pad. What is the best pad out there these days. Give me your pros and cons on each one and I am sponsored by X
column3: so they are great is not a review.

column1: Mine main concerns are the following:
1. Protection from Falls-Too soft for high ball or too stiff and an ankle breaker
2. Durability of materials - does the material tear or the buckles break?
Rate your pad by this criteria.

column3: it's $400. I found a good deal on eBay
column4: so you may look around a bit. Second
column5: its weight; definitely a heavy pad
column6: but it's actually pretty comfy to hike around. I'd rather hike with it than my old
column7: lighter pad any day. Easily sucks up shoes
column8: chalk
column9: guides
column10: and stuff. My only downside is that it takes up a bit more room in the car. Nice that you can crush it down for flights or longer trips (however
column11: it takes 24 hrs for the cells to "open" again so you can boulder).

column2: the nicest pad I've used.";;"0";"gA==";"ld96dcth";"1";"0";;"17";"0";"0"

column1: Since you asked -- I guess I think there could be better synthesis between the text and pictures.  It seems that the premise of the piece is that the Tram has housed surges of development
column2: followed by inactivity and that generally it is under-utilized and under-appreciated by the so cal masses.  Accordingly
column3: there could be photos of Mulligan
column4: March
column5: Mills along with the numerous other developers I am too new to the Tram to know. I definitely appreciate the excellent photo of Joe.  In fact
column6: all of the photos are excellent - congrats to Damo & Rob! As a Tram devotee and bouldering porn junkie I would have liked to see more.";;"0";"mA==";"1q5nuq93";"1";"0";;"11";"0";"0"

column2: 2007";"Jon McCartie
column3: Sonja Djuricin
column4: Aron Couzens
column5: Scott Sanchez (with son/hardman
column6: 7-year old Luc)

column1: After a quick 4-hour drive from Santa Monica
column2: we awoke in our warm hotel room at the Holiday Inn Express.  We cruised over to Denny's for some Moons Over My Hammy
column3: then headed north to the Happy Boulders.  My poor Toyota sedan was not a huge fan of the washboard road
column4: but we made it to the parking lot at the base of the valley in good time.

column2: looking south

column1: We warmed up near The Gleaner
column2: then Sonja and I took turns on the Monkey Hang (v3) while Scott made a few passes and eventually sent Rave (v7).  I took a few burns on the v5 stand start but couldn't lock off on the sloper.  Aron had disappeared up on the hillside...no report on that adventure.  I managed to get Joseph (v3) before moving on.

column1: Sonja promised to give me a tour of the fun/easy stuff
column2: so we headed further up into the valley.  We started out on some high thin stuff: Path (vB) and Heavenly Path (v1).

column1: Sonja cruises Path in her approach shoes

column2: Heavenly Path

column1: We then cruised over to the north face of More Water
column2: Less Power and took a few laps (many eliminates and variations).  Happy Hooker (v0+) on the right
column3: Grant's Christmas Present (v1) right to left
column4: and Comfort of Home (v2/3) on the left side.

column1: Afterwards we climbed up to the rim of the valley and joined Aron and some friends from Rockreation (OC).  Aron had flashed Little Country Girl (v6)
column2: but couldn't repeat it for the cameras.  I got Craig Gilbert to demonstrate it along with Big City Boy (v6)
column3: just behind it.

column1: Craig's second attempt on Little Country Girl.  The super-strong beta.
Brad Gobright wanted to take a shot at The Hulk (v5/6)
column2: so we all packed up and headed back down to the valley.  Sonja and I joined another group to work on Solaruim (v3).  Brad made quick work of The Hulk -- yelling for a spot at the top because no one had seen him sneak up the problem.  I ticked Rendezvous With An Alien (v3) on the east face of Solarium
column3: while the others groped the holds of Redrum (v7) but no one attempted it.

column2: I hurried ahead of the group to try my hand at Groundwater (v5).  I pulled it out after my 3rd try -- my first outdoor v5.  Not too exciting of a climb
column3: but memorable nonetheless.

column1: the field just south of the parking lot

column2: we were very thankful for the jacuzzi
column3: pool
column4: and sauna.  We met up with Brad and Nick (a friend of Aron's camping out at the buttermilks for a week).  Nothing like a pitcher of margaritas on an empty stomach.  After dinner
column5: we loitered at Wilson's then made our way back to the hotel.  Brad and Nick continued their cold-weather avoidance by attending an 8:30p showing of "I Am Legend."

column2: Scott made the most of his evening by playing online poker from bed while his son slept.

column1: We decided to save some cash and hit the Holiday Inn continental breakfast.  I was delightfully surprised.  Oatmeal
column2: cereal
column3: two hard-boiled eggs
column4: orange juice
column5: and yogurt.  Free.  Booyah.

column1: We stopped by Vons on the way out of town to pick up some veggie goodness for Sonja.
view of the mountains from the parking lot
Looking down the trail from the top of the approach

column2: Bouncing Babies
column3: and Sleeping Gas -- all behind Molly.  We then moved over to the Molly Boulder.  Sonja sent The Great Dominions (v1)
column4: Aron and I sent Head Heritage (v3)
column5: and Scott and Aron sent Molly (v5).  Scott got a delightful surprise from someone's dog that decided to take a dump right next to his pad.  Bad dog.

column1: We moved farther up into the valley and joined a few others at Pow Pow (v7/8).  Sonja and I probably could have flashed it
column2: but we didn't want to show up the others there
column3: so I took some pics and video instead.

column1: Aron spots Brad on Pow Pow
Anthony sends Pow Pow.  Too bad I ran out of memory card just before he topped out.

column2: Brad
column3: and Aron all managed an impressive send.  Afterwards
column4: we  lunched and stopped off to watch some folks on Strength in Numbers (v5):

column2: we cruised over to the Ice Caves.  What an awesome area -- boulders on top of boulders creating a long narrow cave with hard problems galore.  Aron and friends worked on Beefcake (v10)
column3: while I spent the rest of my afternoon on Chizam (v5).  I spent way too long using one piece of beta.  After seeing Aron do it differently
column4: I changed my plan of attack and promptly sent -- my second outdoor v5.  Booyah.

column1: Aron topped off his day with a great ascent of It's All About Love (v8).
heading back out to the cars
Another trip to Wilson's to buy my own guidebook
column2: some burgers at Carls Jr in Lone Pine
column3: and away we went.

column1: Note to self:  figure out a way to get more time off work to spend more time in Bishop.
While trying to compile all my footage of Pow Pow
column2: I managed to lose about 4 hours of work and then most of my pictures.  I'm restoring a backup now and will post some edited video tomorrow.";;"0";"GA==";"2kwz5fnu";"1";"1197994135";;"21";"2";"0"
temps were good
column3: all though the ice caves were a little frosty.

column1: And there was way less people than Thanksgiving which made things more enjoyable.";;"0";"GA==";"3r8pcc6o";"1";"0";;"5";"0";"0"

1061;"175";"1";"21";"0";"71.119.68.194";"1198003992";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"0";;"Injury - pulley (i think)";"Friday was supposed to be a rest day in prep for my Bishop trip.  but i was showing someone around the gym.  I started screwing around in the boulder area and managed to make a move into a two-finger pocket.  my right ring finger has been sore for a few months
column2: but i can usually get it to cooperate if i warm up properly.  this time
column3: however
column4: it hurt like hell.

column1: i taped it up good over the weekend
column2: but the happies and sads are all pockets
column3: so i was a bad boy and didn't rest like i should have.

column1: now the underside of my ring finger hurts whenever i put pressure on it.  (pulling in mostly)  A2 pulley?
any tips?  should i stay off it completely?  or just avoid pockets and tape the crap out of it when i climb (crimps don't hurt

column2: reachy move to a tiny open-hand crimp.  I had some gnarly pain down through the palm of my hand and I couldn't even pick up a large cup or mug with that hand for a while.  Strangely enough
column3: and like you
column4: crimping didn't hurt at all.

column2: I iced it a bit for the first few days.  I waited a couple of weeks to climb on it again and then went back to doing ONLY moves that didn't make it hurt at all.  Slowly
column3: over MONTHS
column4: it got better.

column1: Ligament/tendon injuries take a while to heal.  Go easy on it.  If you can still climb and not make it hurt at all
column2: then I say do it.  If you can't
column3: it's time to find another hobby for a while.";;"0";"CA==";"3mycbyet";"1";"0";;"71";"0";"0"

column1: For me magazines inspire me to go out to new areas. That's it. I look at the pictures and if they look cool I might read the article. Either way I know that if I go to the area to play on rocks its not going to matter what some low payed climbing journalist had to say about it.

And about Matt Birch getting paid for the pictures of him that should have been where Fabio... errr Ivan was... yeah it sucks. And I agree it should have been him. But am I upset about it? Not really. If you're trying to make dough as a professional climber and your name isn't Chris or Dave or if your pecks don't fit in a D-cup bra you're probably screwed.
Mainly the point I was trying to make is: who reads any popular media and takes it to heart? I mean ideally... yeah

column1: 1173;"175";"1";"9";"0";"76.243.135.1";"1199507766";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"0";;"Study";"Here is a little research study I performed (google search) after blowing tendons over six times in the last 15 years.

Objective. The closed traumatic rupture of finger flexor tendon pulleys in rock climbers appeared as a new complex finger trauma in the mid 1980s. The objectives of this study are to characterize this injury and to describe diagnostic and therapeutic guidelines. A grading system for the severity of pulley injuries was developed and used to set therapeutic pathways.

Methods. Six hundred four injured rock climbers were prospectively evaluated from January 1998 to December 2001 with a questionnaire and standard examination protocol. Diagnostic ultrasound was performed in all rock climbers with finger injuries; if necessary
column2: an additional magnetic resonance imaging was done. All pulley injuries were graded according to an introduced pulley-injury score (grade 14).

column1: Results. Three of four of the most frequent injuries were related to the fingers: pulley injuries accounted for 20%
column2: tendovaginitis for 7%
column3: and joint capsular damage for 6.1%. One hundred twenty-two (20.2%) rock climbers presented an injury of the flexor tendon pulley system
column4: 48 had pulley strains
column5: and 74 had ruptures (a single rupture in 90.5% and multiple pulley ruptures in 9.5%). According to the pulley-injury score
column6: 39% were grade 1
column7: 25% were grade 2
column8: 30% were grade 3
column9: and 6% were grade 4 injuries.

column1: Conclusions. Pulley injuries were the most frequent injuries in rock climbers. Whereas grade 13 injuries respond well to conservative treatment
column2: grade 4 injuries require surgical repair. We recommend the loop and a half technique of Widstrom and colleagues and
column3: alternatively
column4: the Weilby repair. We also recommend postoperative initial immobilization and early functional treatment under external pulley protection.

column2: 2 and Tropet et al3 first reported in 1990 the closed traumatic rupture of a finger flexor tendon pulley in rock climbers
column3: further reports have given various diagnostic and therapeutic recommendations. Although the open injury of the pulley system leads to a primary reconstruction
column4: 4 there are no clear guidelines for the procedure with a closed pulley rupture. Whereas the indication for a surgical repair was further spread in the early 1990s
column5: now a nonsurgical approach
column6: at least for a single rupture
column7: is standard.5
column8: 6 This attitude is based on biomechanical analyses of the flexor tendon pulley system710 as well as the very good functional results of many rock climbers
column9: who underwent only self therapy after pulley rupture. The objectives of this study are to determine the frequency of this injury and to give diagnostic and therapeutic guidelines. A severity grading system that can be used to guide treatment of pulley injuries is presented.

column1: We prospectively evaluated 604 injured rock climbers during a 4-year period (January 1
column2: 1998December 31
column3: 2001). Four hundred nineteen (69.4%) athletes were seen during clinical work and were evaluated with a standard questionnaire and examination protocol. One hundred eighty-five (30.6%) athletes were seen during the sport medical care of national (National Championships) and international (World Cup
column4: World Championships) climbing competitions. For evaluation of the climbing difficulty level
column5: the Union Internationale des Associations d'Alpinisme (UIAA) scale was transferred into the metric scale (eg
column6: UIAA 9− = metric 8.7
column7: UIAA 9 = metric 9.0
column8: UIAA 9+ = metric 9.7). The UIAA scale
column9: ranging from grade 1 to 11
column10: is used for classification of the difficulty of a climb
column11: with grade 1 being the easiest and grade 11 currently being the hardest climbing route. The UIAA scale has an open end. Within a grade
column12: a minus applies to an easy climb for the grade
column13: whereas a plus applies for a hard route for the grade. Climbing level was graded according to the hardest on sight (climber tries the route for the first time) and hardest redpoint route (climber knows the route and its special moves well and has trained on it) within the past 2 years. All rock climbers presenting with the suspicion of a pulley injury also received diagnostic ultrasound and optional magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). Ultrasound was performed in a water tube by using a 7.5-MHz linear ultrasound head. In suspected pulley injury
column14: the pathway in Figure 1 was used.

column1: We developed a grading score (Table 1 ) and used it in this study to aid scientific evaluation and to guide therapy. Grade 1 injuries are pulley strains with no dehiscence between bone and tendon in the MRI or ultrasound (<2 mm). The complete rupture of an A4 pulley has a very good prognosis
column2: sometimes leading to a full recovery within 4 to 6 weeks. This has the same severity as a partial rupture of the more essential A2 or A3 pulley. These injuries are rated grade 2. The complete rupture of the A2 or A3 pulley
column3: leading to a prolonged recovery
column4: is rated grade 3. Grade 4 injuries include complex lesions with multiple pulley injuries or single pulley injuries combined with lumbricalis muscle damage or collateral ligament rupture. These lead to a functional deficit if not surgically repaired. Grade 13 injuries received conservative therapy
column5: and grade 4 injuries received surgical repair. Table 2 shows the therapeutic procedure according to the grading.

column1: Six hundred four rock climbers with acute injuries or overuse syndromes were enrolled in a prospective study during January 1
column3: to December 31
column4: 2001. The types and extents of the injuries were determined in all athletes. In the 419 (60.4%) athletes seen in our clinic
column5: demographic (age
column6: sex) and sport specific data (climbing levels
column7: years of climbing experience) were also gathered. In this group of 302 men (70.1%) and 117 women (27.9%)
column8: the average age was 28.3 years (1352). The athletes had been sport climbing for an average of 7.3 years (235). The interval between the acute injury and medical consultation ranged from a few minutes to 1.5 years. Average redpoint climbing level was metric 8.63 (5.311.0) or UIAA 9−
column9: representing US 5.12c. Average on-sight level was metric 8.09 (5.911.3) or UIAA 8
column10: representing US 5.12a.

column4: 55 (9.1%) to feet

column7: 42 (6.9%) to skin

column9: 22 (3.6%) to knees

column2: pulley injuries were the most frequent (n = 122) followed by tendovaginitis (n = 42) and joint capsular damage (n = 37). Table 3 summarizes the finger injuries and overuse syndromes
column3: and Table 4 summarizes the pulley injuries. According to the proposed grading system

column7: and 6% were grade 4 injuries (Figure 2 ). The 50 patients with A2 ruptures included 17 partial and 33 complete ruptures.

column1: Grade 13 injuries were treated conservatively with initial immobilization and early functional therapy under pulley protection. In grade 4 injuries
column2: a surgical repair was performed by the loop and a half technique of Widstrom et al11 or
column3: alternatively
column4: the Weilby repair.12 Postoperatively
column5: an initial immobilization was followed by functional therapy.

column1: Follow-up included 87 (71.3%) of all rock climbers with pulley injuries
column2: including all grade 4 injuries. Of the 80 cases treated conservatively (grade 13 injuries)
column3: 7 (8%) athletes complained of persistent pain after 3 months
column4: caused by posttraumatic tendovaginitis. After local cortisone injection and a prolonged resting period
column5: they regained their initial sport activity level. The other 73 patients returned to full climbing level
column6: with occasional minor pain. Only 6 reported a continuing need of taping the injured finger for longer than 12 months during climbing. All 7 grade 4 patients were re-evaluated: 1 presented a very good functional result
column7: 5 presented a good functional result
column8: and 1 presented a satisfying functional result. One reported a very good sport-specific result with climbing again in the top difficulty levels (UIAA 10
column10: 3 reported good sport-specific results
column11: 2 reported a sufficient sport-specific result
column12: and 1 reported a poor sport-specific result. Finger taping during climbing activity was necessary in all patients.

column2: we found a high number of finger injuries within our total group of rock climbers. This is consistent with data in the literature. Bollen
column4: 2 Rooks
column5: 13 and Largiadr and Oelz14 reported that about 60% of all climbing injuries concentrated on the hand and fingers. Hochholzer et al15 reported a similar finding
column6: with osteoarthritis being the most common and pulley ruptures being the second most common climbing injuries. Considering all finger injuries and overuse syndromes within our group
column7: pulley injuries were the most common. This results from 2 main reasons. First
column8: the Bamberg hospital is located within the Frankenjura
column9: Germany's largest sport-climbing area
column10: which is characterized by short
column11: very steep climbs and requires maximum power moves by using the crimping technique (Figures 3 and 4 ). The crimping finger position seems especially responsible for pulley injuries.1
column15: 10 Second
column16: our center is a major referral center for patients suspected of having this injury.

column1: We propose an algorithm (Figure 1 ) that we use in diagnosing suspected pulley injuries. The clinical picture of pulley injuries and the history from the athletes were in accordance with other studies.1
column7: 16 Most rock climbers reported an acute onset while performing a hard move or slipping off a foothold. Sometimes a loud popping was mentioned. The fingers showed swelling at the level of the proximal or middle phalanx
column8: sometimes accompanied by hematoma. A visible bowstring only occurred in high-grade injuries. When caused by the combined injury of the lumbricalis muscles
column9: an extension deficit of the proximal interphalangeal joint could occur
column10: leading to contraction. According to our algorithm as well as the reports of Gabl et al
column11: 16 we always obtain radiographs to exclude fractures or osseous tears of the fibrocartilago palmaris as well as chronic overuse fractures in the epiphysis of adolescent rock climbers.

column2: ultrasound examination and MRI are important. MRI has been demonstrated to be very sensitive in detecting pulley injuries in many studies4
column4: 1517 and is widely accepted. Although MRI cannot directly detect the damaged pulley
column5: the T1 sequences show dehiscence of tendon from bone
column6: whereas T2 sequences help distinguish a tendovaginitis (Figure 5 ). Intratendonal lesions can be detected in addition to partial ruptures. MRI is limited by its high costs. Lately
column7: ultrasound examination has been demonstrated to achieve nearly the same quality results
column8: sometimes even being superior to MRI
column9: allowing additional dynamic examination.1618 We recommend use of ultrasound as the standard examination
column10: with MRI added if the diagnosis remains unclear.

column2: Bollen1 and Tropet et al3 first reported rock climbers with closed traumatic pulley ruptures. Both Bollen
column3: with conservative treatment
column4: and Tropet
column5: with surgery
column6: achieved good functional results. During the ensuing years
column7: further reports about surgical and conservative treatment have appeared2
column11: 16 but without general guidelines. Whereas surgical repair was commonly used in early years
column12: conservative
column14: at least for single ruptures.5
column15: 6 This attitude is based on biomechanical analyses of the flexor tendon pulley system710 and the very good functional results of many rock climbers
column16: who underwent only self therapy after pulley rupture. An initial strength deficit disappears after 3 to 6 months. Bollen1
column17: 2 reported a survey held at the British National Climbing Championships in 1989
column18: where 18 rock climbers showed an increase of bowstring phenomenon in their fingers. None of these athletes underwent any kind of previous therapy
column19: but at the time of the competition all had good functionality and few complaints. Gabl et al16 used the MRI and the visible bowstring for indication of conservative or surgical therapy. They applied surgery if the bowstring on the MRI extended proximal to the base of the proximal phalanx of the involved finger. MRI is essential in this approach. Although conservative treatment of single pulley injuries became standard
column20: there was no distinction among the different pulleys themselves. An A2-pulley tear has a prolonged recovery in comparison with an A4 tear. For further scientific evaluation
column21: as well as therapeutic decision making

column1: Mainly on the basis of biomechanical analyses of Bollen
column2: 2 a nonsurgical procedure is becoming standard for single ruptures. Bollen described a tearing force of 500 N of a 1.5-cm wide tape above the A2 pulley
column3: which allows good protection of the pulley. Although Warme and Brooks19 could not find any difference in pulley tearing force with or without taping
column4: conservative therapy has shown very good functional results.1
column8: 20 Depending on the interval between trauma and consultation as well as local swelling
column9: we recommend an initial immobilization of 10 to 14 days with a palmar splint combined with anti-inflammatory agents and elevation. Thereafter
column10: treatment consists of early functional therapy with pulley protection by using tape or thermoplastic/soft-cast ring
column11: finger gymnastics
column12: or a Thera-Band Hand Exerciser (Thera-Band
column14: OH). Easy sport-specific activities are allowed for grade 3 injuries after 6 to 8 weeks under pulley protection (tape). Full sport activities can be done after 3 months
column15: with continued taping for at least 6 months. Grade 2 injuries can be treated in a similar but more rapid fashion (Table 2 ). Initial strength deficit will resolve after 3 to 6 months
column16: and bone-to-tendon dehiscence is stable on ultrasound follow-ups.

column1: Grade 4 injuries require surgical repair to prevent functional deficits. Clinically
column2: there is reduced flexion in the distal interphalangeal joint
column3: and sometimes there is an extension deficit of the proximal interphalangeal joint.4
column7: 20 Surgical repair is based on the biomechanical analyses of Lin et al21 as well as the comparison of surgical repairs done by Widstrom et al.11
column8: 22 A single stitching of the remaining incomplete rims of the pulleys is insufficient; a plastic repair is essential. The following various methods have been described: the Kleinert and Bennet12 repair based on Weilby's idea
column9: the belt-loop technique of Karev et al
column10: 23 the single-loop technique according to Bunnel
column11: 24 the Lister25 repair with retinaculum flexorum
column12: the palmaris longus tendon transplantation through the volar plate according to Doyle
column13: 11 the loop and a half technique of Widstrom et al
column14: 11 and the triple loop technique by Okutsu et al.26 Considering the biomechanical analyses of Widstrom et al11
column15: 22 and the reports of Hahn and Lanz
column16: 4 we favor the loop-and-a-half technique of Widstrom et al with a free transplant of the palmaris longus tendon. Although the Weilby repair12 was reported as having the best functional results
column17: sport climbers often need a higher tearing force after reconstruction. This is provided by the loop-and-a-half technique. Nevertheless
column18: the final decision is made during the operation according to the anatomical situation. For reconstruction of the A3 pulley
column19: the loop-and-a-half technique sometimes is not the ideal solution
column20: as the loop can cause irritation on the extensor tendon at the proximal interphalangeal joint. Postoperatively
column21: we apply an initial immobilization for 2 weeks
column22: followed by an early functional treatment with pulley protection with thermoplastic or a soft-cast ring for 4 weeks and further taping during sport activities. The overall results are good
column23: with nearly full recovery of function.

column1: Closed traumatic pulley rupture was described as a new injury mechanism in the 1980s
column2: and early diagnostic and therapeutic approaches varied. Today's approach should include the exclusion of a fracture or joint capsular/collateral ligament lesion
column3: followed by ultrasound differentiation of pulley strains and partial
column4: complete
column5: or multiple pulley ruptures. If the ultrasound fails to give an exact diagnosis
column6: an MRI should be performed. Injuries can be graded according to our proposed grading system to guide therapeutic approach. Grade 13 injuries (strains and partial or single ruptures) are treated conservatively
column7: with initial immobilization and early functional therapy under pulley protection (Table 2 ). Grade 4 injuries (multiple ruptures) require surgical repair. The loop-and-a-half technique of Widstrom et al11 is favored
column8: with the Weilby repair12 being an alternate approach. Postoperatively
column9: initial immobilization is used
column10: followed by physical therapy. Although closed pulley ruptures were initially seen only in rock climbers
column11: who are subject to high impact on the fingers
column12: these injuries may also occur in nonclimbers. We have seen 4 cases of closed pulley ruptures in nonclimbers within the past 3 years. The trauma mechanism in these involved primarily lifting heavy items with crimped fingers.

1178;"175";"1";"9";"0";"76.194.222.225";"1199572652";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"0";;"Finger";"The last injury (right ring) I had I took a different path then I had in the past which was rest until the pain was gone. That meant no climbing for about six months. This time I had decided I wanted to climb and tried a different tact and healed in a very short amount of time.
I let the finger rest for two weeks and kept the ringer finger tapped to the middle finger
column2: so the injured finger always had support. I began going into the gym and doing a ton of pull ups and climbing easy until I would feel some pain in the finger. Once this would happen I would pack up my stuff and head home.

column1: Once home I would ice the hand for 10 minutes and then off ten and then back on ten for about an hour. Of course like me you can play a few online poker tournaments this will help the time go by and maybe you can win some money while healing. I did this for about four weeks and after that time I really have had problem with the finger. I continue to tape the ring finger in the gym just as a safety precaution due the volume of climbing done in the gym and the short rests.
If you can check your ego at the door
column2: just climb pain free and not get sucked into trying that "one problem" you have always wanted to do. You will find the healing process can be quite fast. The steeper you climb the more load on your hands. Spend some time climbing lower angle problems and work on your technique and endurance. This will pay off when the finger heals.

column1: I wonder which sit-starts he added at the Sads...
[b:33n63gka]McColl Beats Storms to V14 in Bishop[/b:33n63gka]
Canadian Sean McColl snuck in an ascent of Goldfish Trombone at the Happy Boulders in California
column2: as major storms pounded the Sierra. McColl spent two days on the problem
column3: completing it January 6. A roof protected the crux holds from heavy rains
column4: but the finishing holds were wet
column5: and by the next day up to 18 inches of snow lay on the ground in the nearby Buttermilk Country near Bishop.

column2: McColl has sent Direction (V13) and Xavier's Roof  (V12) in the Buttermilks; he also flashed a couple of V11 problems and added V11 sit starts to existing routes at the Sads. McColl reportedly is close to completing The Mandala SDS (V13) once the snow melts. The Bishop forecast is mostly good for this week.

column3: a former youth world champion in lead climbing
column4: also had a superb autumn of roped climbing. In October
column5: he made the second ascent of Lucifer (5.14c) and flashed Thanatopsis (5.14a/b) at the Red River Gorge in Kentucky. Before that he completed half a dozen 5.14a and 5.14b routes in Rodellar
column6: Spain
column7: including two on his second go.";;"0";"QA==";"33n63gka";"1";"0";;"21";"0";"0"

1251;"191";"1";"92";"0";"208.240.243.170";"1200057509";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"0";;;"My guess is that they would close the park as a patrolled and managed area.  It does not necessarily mean that they would close access.  There are several SoCal mountains that do not have the same management level as SanJac.  Look at Baldy and the surrounding wilderness.  Even SanG is only patrolled on a couple of the trails and is managed by a ranger station FAR down the mountain.
The tram is privately owned and would maintain operation so nothing would change from a approach standpoint.

My biggest concern is that the tram offers easy P2P access to a 9000 foot elevation and a LOT of newbie and ill prepared hikers and tourists visit there.  The Ranger station and implied patrols have acted as a buffer in a lot of ways from there being many disastrous and costly lost/injured persons rescues (there is at least 1 experienced hiker that gets lost there every year and needs a major rescue)

column1: Women - The only two girls I really remember were Lisa Rands and Alex Puccio. They were both very impressive but Lisa dominated in the finals. Man is she awesome to watch... such a perfect blend of experience
column2: technique and power. So Lisa won
column3: Alex got second
column4: and can't remember the names of the other girls although I did see some climbing pretty darn well.

column1: Men - I'm pretty sure the results for the mens red point section of the comp went (sorry if there's any spelling errors):
The finals (4 problems in which each climber had 5 minutes to work) were somewhat evenly matched amongst all the finalists
column2: with each person excelling on climbs that seemed to suit their styles. The two standouts were Dan Mills and Carlo Traversi.

column1: Dan flashed the first three problems but struggled on the first crux of the last problem. Carlo flashed the first and third problem but took a few tries to complete the second. However
column2: Carlo dominated on the last problem
column3: falling off with his hand wrapped on the finishing jug.

column1: I didn't stick around for the reading of the results but I would think Carlo took first place having gotten further than Dan on the last final. The only reason Dan might have won is if the flash value of the second problem out-weighed Carlo's performance of the final problem.
Once again the comp seemed like a huge success overall. It ran smoothly and the problems were all around very
column2: very good. On a side note there seemed to be no injuries which is very nice.";;"0";"BA==";"2u8aegge";"1";"0";;"23";"0";"0"

column1: I have a user gallery. The idea was that people who look at the site could send in photos for the gallery

column3: I practically have to beg people to send stuff in!

column2: and only managed to get in about 2 hours of bouldering.  seemed to be some great lines
hopefully this summer. It'd be good to build a little more of a community up there. The sport climbing is well known
column3: but no one boulders except a few of us. I've only met other people who want to boulder once or twice at the crags.

column1: It's definitely a unique SoCal destination - my personal favorite for a variety of reasons. I always end up cleaning new problems on every trip. (on our last day up there last fall we added 6 new probs in one little area.) Most of the lines are VO-V3
column2: because of the nature of the rock there. However
column3: there are PLENTY of harder lines to be had. There are hundreds of problems
column4: with lots more potential. There are some pics of some of the latest development in the galleries page
column5: under user galleries. Feel free to add if you have any pics.

column2: just inquiring.[/quote:2ldugqxm]

column1: no offense taken. It's a good question.

column2: and I'm a local climber. I started writing in college
column3: but more so in grad school where I got my MA in Linguistics. I've been hoping someone was gonna redo the old Craig Fry guide for years. Finally
column4: I decided to look into it myself when I saw the new Bishop guidebook. I approached Wolverine about the project a couple months back and they had me do a preliminary coverage sample. I did about half of the total work for the guide and sent it to them. They loved it
column5: said it was perfect
column6: and gave me the contract. It just a matter of fact checking
column7: adding recent FAs
column8: action shots
column9: gathering guest essays from local figures
column10: etc.

column1: I'd say I'm about half way done with the entire guide; I've been working real hard to get it done quickly

column3: I want the guide to be done right

column5: it's essential to include the entire climbing community. And maybe one of the most important qualifications is that I'm definitely not doing it for the money.

column1: I usually stay out of internet forums
column2: but this is an issue that I actually care about. A few thoughts:

column1: The Bishop guide is as good as it is because it was (literally) 10 years in the making
column2: not to mention Wills himself climbed virtually every single problem listed. Wolverine Publishing simply put it into a neat package. It could have been laid out on Eucalyptus bark and it would have been just as good
column3: just harder to lug around. Point being
column4: a proper guide has far more to do with the effort put into it
column5: than the publisher whos paying for it.

column1: Now Im not a Los Angeles local
column2: but Ive climbed at most of the areas youre planning to cover and I happen to know a lot about writing a guidebook. I find it astonishing that you finished a well researched and comprehensive going-over over of Stoney Point in such a short period of time. I also find it suspect that someone who is writing an LA guide needs beta on Malibu Creek. This worries me that perhaps you might not be the right person for the job [yet]. Seriously
column3: embarking on this mission implies that you should know Malibu Creek very well from the get-go.

column1: -Climb every problem you can. This alone requires a substantial amount of time before youve written anything down. Is it mandatory for a guidebook author to climb double digits? No. But it sure helps. It also helps to be able to describe/do scary problems and comment with authority.
-Tell Wolverine not to expect anything for at least a year or two. If you believe youre sufficiently done with Stoney Point
column2: fine
column3: but Horse Flats alone
column4: an area which Ive climbed at a ton
column5: should take 6 months to a year.

column2: the Fry guide hasnt been updated not because it wasnt needed

column5: at least. Please take the time and effort to do it right.

column1: lets talk.  i have the capacity to product a quality guide book.  my materials if you know paper are the highest quality being used.
i have tried to avoid 4 color because it comes from CHINA but it seems everyone gets wet over color images of rocks.
so my new guides will be in COLOR coming this year.
i just got of the phone with craig fry and i have his blessing and support.
mr. waugh and i will talk again tonight.
over the last couple days i have talked to the LOCALS you mention in detail.
your involvemnet so far is asking questions while standing next to them.  they dont even know your last name.
did you get model releases for the photos you took of them bouldering.  i will save you some time and money by letting you know YOU HAD BETTER.

i dont mean to rain on your parade but it has taken me 20 years of climbing and doing business in the climbing industry to be able to call myself a local.  and i am very carefull about that.  i have not climbed in LA that much.  i believe i have these folks support and respect because i do have history and am very clear and careful with my actions and intensions.

column1: Seems to be a particularly touchy subject here.
Guidebooks (at least those done well) are a lot of work.  They should be accurately researched (big time involved here)
column2: historically relevant (learn the history
column3: get to know the locals
column4: experience and include the local color
column5: etc.)
column6: be easy to use (multiple maps
column7: layers
column8: indexes
column9: etc.)
column10: and get climbers psyched to visit the areas (quality action photos of as many different climbers as possible - hopefully those that are involved with the areas being depicted).

column1: Perhaps the best person to do a project like this would be someone involved in the development of the areas being featured
column2: but since this book will cover a broad range of areas that might be too much to ask for.

column1: Next best option would be a compilation of info from many active locals.  This would require someone to be the actual editor
column2: compiler
column3: author or whatever else you want to call it.  Seems like this is more or less what Josh is proposing.

column1: I can think of a handful of obvious candidates (other than Josh) to take on this project
column2: but if I'm honest I would have to admit that they are candidates in my mind because of their historical involvement with the areas or because they are people that have had an impact in my experiences with those areas.  I cant speak to their interest in producing a book or possible skill in doing one.  Would they necessarily do a better job?  Maybe
column3: but I don't really know.

column1: When it comes right down to it
column2: anyone could write this book.  But for that to happen they would have to put the time in to do what's been suggested above by Robert
column3: Kevin
column4: and many others.  Visit all of the areas.  Climb as many of the problems as possible and attempt the others.  Talk to EVERYONE you can about EVERY problem and EVERY area.  Take or purchase quality action and area photos.  Study the history involved and report it accurately and completely.  And above all else
column5: don't cut corners (quality or time spent) and care passionately about the final product.

column1: Regardless of who is involved in this
column2: I hope that person follows these guidelines.

column1: I (as I'm sure are many others) am looking forward to see what becomes of this.  Hopefully there will be a quality guide at the end of the process.";;"0";"gA==";"2bpyb42y";"1";"0";;"16";"0";"0"

column1: nice meeting you yesterday out at Planet X.  good luck with your guidebook.

column2: golfer
column3: jill
column4: and jcpeace (josh)
column5: everyone went their separate ways.  freezing and hungry
column6: i went back to my campsite.  as i sat by my tent
column7: trying to get a fire started with wet wood and sipping my cup o' noodles
column8: i thought
column9: "maybe i should just go home.  i had a day climbing
column10: it's probably gonna rain Sunday.  i'd like to sleep in a real bed."

column1: "no!  this is your last climbing trip before the baby comes!  plus
column2: you already paid for the campsite.  suck it up and climb!"

column1: around 10pm the winds started.  my tent was on a bed of rock
column2: so i neglected to spike it down.  the rocks on the corners didn't help
column3: and around 11pm
column4: my tent collapsed.i struggled to get out of my sleeping bag and put on my jacket.  i piled all my belongings into the back of my tiny car
column5: laid down the seat
column6: and contorted my body enough to lay down and sleep.  the car rocked back and forth in the wind for the rest of the night.

column2: i woke up.  the wind was still howling and the clouds were rolling in from the west.  i sat in the back of my car trying to think of a sheltered place to climb.  i drove out to Hall of Horrors
column3: walked around
column4: and decided to call it a day.  i left the park
column5: experienced the worst ever customer service at the Denny's in Yucca Valley
column6: and started down towards the 10.

column2: and I could barely see 50 yards ahead.  I was doing fine
column3: trying to stay focused on the dashed white lines flying by.  10-east
column4: just before california st. in Redlands
column5: i hydroplaned.  i did about 2 360's
column6: bounced off the center divide
column7: did 2 more 360's and slammed head-first into the center divide.  my car was totaled
column8: i was shaking uncontrollably
column9: and somehow my Joshua Tree park pass had jumped from my center console to the side pocket of the drivers side door (amazing physics).

column1: no car rental places are open in this great city of Redlands.  so now i'm sitting in the lobby of a Howard Johnson below the freeway
column2: waiting for my father in law to drive up from San Diego and pick me up.  he'll drive me to SD where my wife is this weekend
column3: then we'll make the 2 hour drive back to LA tonight.

column1: lesson learned: if you already had a great day of bouldering
column2: and the next day it will probably rain
column3: and you're alone
column4: hungry
column5: and only 2 hours from a warm bed and hot food...go
column6: man.  just go.

column1: just a sore neck and some violent nervous shaking.
