column2: spent my time back by Eat Out More Often/Split Rock.
let me put the rumor about Powerglide to rest - no holds have broken; it's still the same problem it was the first time I saw it back in 2000. In my opinion
column3: it's the area standard for V6.

column2: as for the back of Split Rock
column3: that's a different ball game. I don't consider myself an authority on the place by any means
column4: but here's my take on those problems...

column2: with right hand on the arete
column3: left on crimp about face height. Set feet
column4: bump left up to good sloper on the lip
column5: etc.... I've always thought this was Vaino Problem
column6: but not so sure looking a both guides.

column2: just right of that one
column3: feels maybe V5 for a tall guy like me. It is the best of the lines I have done back there
column4: and I believe it is the Johnson Arete. It starts low
column5: left hand on the arete and right hand in a hole on the face. Move up using arete and crimps/sidepulls on face.

column2: seems like an easy V1. The low left hand ball has broken
column3: but everything else is good.

column1: I'd guess the arete between Johnson Arete and Valdez goes as well
column2: but I haven't tried. Interestingly
column3: the Craig Fry guide has this line listed as "Vain Problem"
column4: B1. (It doesn't show anything as "Vaino"
column5: so maybe this line is the Vaino Problem?

column1: It is a little remarkable that there could be so much confusion over these problems after all these years
column2: but I'd say that because they are off the beaten path and there are discrepancies in the guidebooks it is understandable.

column1: There are a handful of people who could set it straight
column2: so I'll be checking around in the coming weeks if no one posts an explanation. Maybe jspace has that area sussed out for his guide? Dimitrius
column3: you know?

column2: Dimitrius
column3: if you mean a direct line topping out Mosaic Thump
column4: nice! I didn't see any chalk up top
column5: but with the rain lately that's no surprise. Is that the line you're talking about? (Sit start just left of the corner) It's on my top 10 list for Stoney
column6: so I'd love to see the direct top out beta.";;"0";"CA==";"394cpkif";"1";"0";;"17";"0";"0"

myself

column4: like you're doing.

column2: I was kidding
column3: renaming problems/boulders is a crime. And the aside from the fact that lions like to lie around like this rock I have no idea of the name change choice.

column1: I understand that problems can get contrived by creating GYM rules or eliminates
column2: however there are areas such as Morrison CO or the Ice Caves in Bishop
column3: that have been full developed in this fashion. I think the consensus of the bouldering community is that Morrison is not contrived
column4: but a small crag that some locals did everything they could to keep it interesting. I would say the Ice Cave is contrived because someone tried to force lines into a much larger crag when only one real line existed. The only issue I have found with these types of areas is if you are no with a local figuring out these line with any type of description is almost impossible.

column1: I remember the first time I went to the Ice Caves
column2: I just walked out  and left due to the difficulty of finding a distinct line. My point is not that I think this is a good practice
column3: but an established practice.

column2: linking different problems often creates really great moves and fun problems. For SoCal
column3: this is especially the case at Stoney
column4: where there are several boulders that lend themselves to lots of variations and link-ups (Boulder 1
column5: B1
column6: and Turlock
column7: mainly). My only thought was that in this particular case
column8: linking one problem to another isn't really creating any new or different climbing move - it's just a link-up. The thing that makes some variations cool is the fact that you have to figure out a new way to get from point A to point B. But I guess Stoney Point is fairly similar to a big outdoor gym anyway
column9: so what's the harm in adding more to the guide? (By the way

column1: It's a valid and important point that these additions aren't really new routes
column2: but how do we 'talk' about em? Some link-ups are worth adding to a guide

column1: As for the backside of Split Rocks
column2: I've used all the old guides for reference
column3: but I've talked with a few locals about the area. Mike Waugh has been very helpful
column4: and I met another long-time local who gave me some specific info on the arete
column5: but I can't remember his name. I wasn't working on the guidebook at that time so I wasn't taking names. Kinda reminded me of William Dafoe
column6: said he was friends with Reardon and Johnson. Another guy that has been real helpful with some recent FAs is a guy named Yair.

column4: and the other is standing. for the right side split
column5: there is johnson arete proper
column6: a sit start
column7: and a variation that climbs the middle face without using the edge holds. i havent really looked at this middle one
column8: it was mentioned that it has been done before. ill look into it. then there is the right edge and some various face routes to the right of it. i dont have my work in front of me so im just going off memory
column9: besides im not done with the area. i still need to meet with the locals and talk about our plans. Kevin Daniels is in progress of setting up a meeting.

column2: but I don't see something like the Standard Route traversing into the Tree route and topping out as an independent line. Just my opinion. I'd love to hear some others...[/quote:3jifryiu]

column2: I find that star ratings
column3: being subjective

column5: yet

column12: well

column1: Stretch... I see your point and will try and clarify:
I speak of graininess as a term no different then say smoothness
column2: or flakiness without getting into "levels of..." meaning if you ever climbed at josh
column3: you would quickly recognize that small bits of grain end up imbedded in your rubber sole
column4: in your fingers and palms. So that is my point that graininess can be more a reference for a condition without getting into how bad or not bad it is. (first boldened point)

column2: the term has carried such a negative connotation that something that's described as choss is usually undesireable and subsequently avoided. I wanted to differentiate between grain being a state or condition and choss being a judgement of that state or condition. I guess one can argue that grain is also subjective
column3: but then one can also argue that the sky is blue is equally subjective
column4: and it would be since blue is a specific color with a specific hue and the sky might actually not be that--hence it can be all subjective.  (second boldened point)

column7: but I would like to believe that anyone who writes a guide would take the time to do the research and talk to the locals.  Shit Rob basically moved to the Tram.  I think this is what caused all the misplaced grief leveled at JPace.  If the author doesn't do his or her homework you end up with a guide like 5 Star which no one who bothered to glance through before purchasing would ever buy.  So if the author does his research and comes to a consenus on either a V rating or a Star rating WTF is the problem.  Does anyone really believe RTM is trying to shove what he thinks is a classic for the area in anyone's face?  The best thing about a guidebook for me is trying to tick ALL the problems within my ability whether they have stars or not.  I'd like to think that after 20 years of climbing I can make my own decision on how many stars a problem deserves regardless of what the guidebook says.  BTW Sensei I would like to change the 50 BEST problems debate to 50 FAVORITE problems as this seems far less subjective.  One man's classic is another man's chossplie.  Oh and if you disagree with a star or V rating you can always cross it out in your guide

column1: in order to know if any of my favorite websites have been updated
column2: i have to go to each and every one of them. very annoying. i've got about 10 websites that change every day. but if it's not new
column3: it's kind of a waste for me to visit all these sites.

column2: you setup an RSS "reader." there are a ton of options -- Firefox has one built in (so does Safari)
column3: you can use Google Reader
column4: or you can download a separate application that runs on your computer in the background. in this "reader"
column5: you input all your RSS feeds. then
column6: instead of checking each website
column7: you check your reader (1 visit as opposed to many). via RSS
column8: it can tell what websites have changed and lets you know (usually plain text and images -- no ads
column9: extra info
column10: etc.)

column1: you'll find that most websites these days have RSS feeds. in your browser
column2: an RSS icon ( [img:8wsqq5oh]http://crossthebreeze.files.wordpress.com/2005/12/feed-icon32x32.jpg[/img:8wsqq5oh]) will usually show up on the right side of the address bar if the site has an RSS feed.
here are the RSS feeds I have setup on Google Reader:

column1: > 2 Friends' Flickr accounts (so i get updated when they add pictures)
i also have an RSS feed that will update whenever there are no routes/comments or pictures added to my favorite climbing areas on Mountain Project.
so rather than visiting these websites individually to see if anything is new
column2: i just look at Google Reader (or other RSS reader app) to see what's new.
if you fall from here
column3: sometimes your leg gets caught on the hueco below and you can land on your face.";;"0";"GQ==";"3pw9m3y6";"1";"0";;"126";"0";"0"

column2: the new Mail in OSX (10.5) and the new Outlook 2007 has RSS support.
because i have one computer at work and one at home.  this way
column3: i can tell which updates have already been marked as "read"

column2: it has "Live Bookmarks" which lets you bookmark your favorites sites as an RSS feed -- then the [i:45g7rjax]bookmark [/i:45g7rjax]tells you when the site is updated.  (Safari does this
column3: too)

column3: and not so Great of guidebooks";"In designing the upcoming Los Angeles Bouldering guide
column4: I want to use as many resources as I can in order to produce the best guidebook as I am able. One way is surveys. The internet is a great thing.

column1: What are some 'things' guidebook authors do that cause confusion or agitation in using the guide?

column2: if you feel compelled to respond

column4: areas; poor grading
column5: etc.

column1: Buck and I went to a party in Josh of all climbers Saturday night. The invite was "come if you're a girl or come dressed as a girl." Not to incriminate us but we looked like the golden girls. Vintage sequin dresses from the 80's.

I am glad to say that there were plenty of uglier guys dressed as women than us so the entertainment value was high. Any dude that showed up not dressed up was ushered into the bedroom of the hostess and brought back out in a dress / bikini / shorty shorts etc.
Good times were had. A little awkward though.";;"0";"CA==";"1zyf4n01";"1";"0";;"5";"0";"0"

column2: since the site is pushing Bishop as part of the Socal experience I thought I would ask a question about the Mandala SDS. Let me preface this with the fact I think this is one of the best lines I have seen and would make my climbing life if I could send it. I noticed when watching videos of the SDS to the Mandala that no one Toni or Sean actually start sitting down. I have always understood a SDS to begin with your ass on the ground. Is the SDS to Mandala really just a low start to the problem or is this the accepted practice for a SDS now? I know I am splitting hairs here
column3: but if I went to a new crag and the problem said SDS I would try it with ass on dirt. I know from experience that pulling your ass off the ground on a sit down is sometimes the crux of the problem.

column1: By the way bravo to all who have sent this problem from either start standard or low.

column1: 2003;"242";"4";"23";"0";"67.151.201.82";"1206027966";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"0";;;"I think we got about 25ish problems up. This boulder makes for some of the best indoor problems I've ever seen.

Mark Roth set a V7ish overhanging arete problem that is absurdly good. The topout has a very desperate hand foot match on a crimp that scared the crap out of me though. I consider that a good thing in the gym!
That is what is really great about this boulder. There are amazing angles to put up some very unique indoor problems but the topout sections just add a whole new level to gym climbing.

2004;"242";"4";"21";"0";"74.2.188.130";"1206050627";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;;"the Roth v7 looked very cool.  i didn't get a chance to play -- i spent 5+ hours setting routes to the left on the big flat wall before the far roof.
managed to put up two v4's and a vB (to downclimb!).  I also set a v3 that tops out near Matt's v3 (mine starts under the roof then moves up and left).
(you guys need to start taping feet -- i couldn't force matt into any cool moves because he was using every other hold on the wall...lame.)
i agree with Brady -- some VERY cool possibilities with this new setup. and i absolutely love topping out on a lot of those problems...tis a very new indoor experience for me.

column2: but the exploring over at the peanuts surrounding areas has been pretty kind so I think thats the plan. Jack might show up so if that happens maybe i'll detach myself from sensei's hip and head up there. And rtm its more of a Batman and Robin thing.";;"0";"gA==";"3bt055ow";"1";"0";;"29";"0";"0"

column2: why not any hands. You would save a ton on tape. Sounds like a gym full of people with strong fingers and bad footwork. Or let me guess every problem can be climbed with endless drop knees. Not that there is anything wrong with the drop knee moves
column3: but too much of anything is well too much.

column1: 2016;"242";"4";"23";"0";"67.151.201.82";"1206118130";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"0";;;"[quote="FOREmer Golfer":283c8vsh]Sounds like a gym full of people with strong fingers and bad footwork. [/quote:283c8vsh]
You can't use ANY feet at our gym though. Just the small jibs that aren't taped. You can't be stepping on jugs and whatnot... I hope you guys didn't get that impression.

In all honesty its really not THAT different from gyms that tape feet. I try to keep only really shitty feet on the walls so that proper foot work has to be used. And pretty much all sections are low enough on feet so that only one foot sequence is possible per move.
The major difference to gyms that tape feet is at those gyms you can force people into doing foot sequences in certain ways.";;"0";"gA==";"283c8vsh";"1";"0";;"23";"0";"0"

column2: so i can't rag on him too bad.";;"0";"gA==";"1lcnejls";"1";"0";;"21";"0";"0"

2024;"242";"4";"16";"0";"68.5.50.26";"1206136632";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"0";;;"Indoor climbing is contrived from the get go in that it's supposed to be training for the real thing.  I've always felt that using "any feet" (even if it is just jibs) is just plain lazy (for both the setter and the climber).

column2: it should be a complete package with a defined challenge for the climbers to attempt to follow and complete.  Bouldering is supposed to be climbing distilled down to clear and defined movement where the climber can strive for the hardest moves possible at his/her level.  Throwing multiple foot options into the mix changes this considerably IMO.

column2: but to be honest I was near the end of the project and was burnt out.

column1: I went to the area (having not been there for 10 years or so) and much of it was overgrown.  I also saw room for a couple of bolted routes on the creek's edge near the first boulders (maybe 4-6 short 3-5 bolt routes could be done on the bulging wall) and a steep arete climb opposite the shorter wall that would be longer.

column2: it seemed like every potential area I went to research I ended up adding routes to.  I just wasn't up for doing that yet again.  If you or someone you know (maybe Bill) wants to add a few routes there
column3: it would help to round out what is otherwise a somewhat limited (but fun) area.

column1: I'm going to Home Depot today to get some supplies. I spent all day Saturday digging out a little more on that cave at Tick Rock
column2: and I just don't have the right tools.

column1: Purple Stones grown over? ... I can fix that. Bill is pretty psyched about the place. I think some good coverage in the guide will really add to SoCal's bouldering scene. If it's as good as Bill says it is
column2: then it'll be great. It's probably like the tunnel boulders
column3: some really great stuff there but obscure
column4: forgotten and overgrown. Each area that I cover
column5: I also clean up and do some trail maintenence. I'm also working on getting some of those carabiner signs like they have up in Yosemite to mark trailheads to certain areas like Tick Rock or the Tunnel.";;"0";"gA==";"gy7xn1t1";"1";"0";;"98";"0";"0"

column2: keg was consumed
column3: golf was played and photos were taken. Here are some of mine...

column1: I don't know any of the names of the routes so I'm just going to repeat names I heard as buzzwords  (Names have been added)

column2: Mandance whatever (Last Dance V9)

column1: Al oh uh... something (My Heart Grew Wings V3)
Aron on something heinously blank (Mr Witty v6)
Friday (at the happys) was really warm in the sun. Probably 80's but on the canyon walls in the shade with the breeze
column2: it was more low 70's.

column1: Saturday was warm at the golf course. 15 people showed up for golf which = 3 teams of 5. John (Verm) Sherman
column2: myself
column3: Brian Rhodes
column4: Adam Lincoln
column5: and some dude named Jody were the first team (team crimp). We won with 2 over par I think. Brian was doing keg stands at all of the water fountains and we moved the flag to the sandtraps for the group behind us.  Brian also let Verm pose for a tee off from his mouth for a photo. Verm actually hit the ball and scared the crap outa Brian.

column1: A second team consisting of a bunch of people I don't know was asked to stop climbing the trees with their shirts off. Later I found out they were trying to get cell reception.
The third team consisted of E.Z. and fiance
column2: his brother Troy
column3: Buck
column4: and 2 others. They started with a shot of tequila at the first hole. Not sure how many drinks all together but on hole 5 a fight almost started. A ball landed next to some hot headed regulars cart. He proceeded to cuss them out AFTER they apologized. This pissed off Troy who threw down his clubs and gave the guy a push. It escalated a little bit before hot head backed down
column5: left his wife behind and took his golf cart full boar to security (not caring who's games he drove thru and interupted.) Turn's out the guy was a known problem so we were all in the clear. Entertaining to watch though.

column1: Sunday (at the buttermilks) was again really warm. In the shade it was perfect
column2: almost chilly even. No snow anywhere that I saw. A guy named Ian did Mandala right behind us after about 10 minutes working it. He then repeated it 5 min. later with ease.

column1: All in all a good weekend. Townsend Brown
column2: Mellisa Higbie
column3: and John Custer (all ex rockreation people) made appearances. Many were missed.";;"0";"CA==";"33evum8s";"1";"0";;"5";"0";"0"

column1: 2088;"258";"1";"9";"0";"99.139.96.127";"1206672676";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"0";;"New Steele Valley Problem? Jigsaw Boulder?";"I found this cool Jigsaw boulder a few weeks ago at Steele Valley. It looks like it had been previously discovered
column2: however I do not believe it was climbed based on the loose rock that was dislodged for the feet during my ascent. If someone sent this before let me know I am tenatively calling it Jigsaw (V7?) and I am unsure of the rating
column3: but it is harder then Holy Roller whatever the consensus is on that problem. The problem starts on a half pad crimp for the right hand and a minimal gaston for the left.

column1: The feet are under the belly of the boulder. Powerful lock to another half pad crimp.
And pull to the lip where you will find a good edge.
More amazing jigsaw holds help you exit the slab.

Part of the crux is staying off the boulder left and hitting the boulder behind you. A little body tension can help this. This is some off the coolest rock at Steele Valley. The boulder sits behind Ultamatum about 100-200 yards to the north on a hill top near the backside road. Let me know what you think if you climb it. By the way the really nice looking hold chalked out left is really only accessible starting higher on the problem. The boulder cannot be missed look for the jigsaw face.
2089;"258";"1";"16";"0";"68.5.50.26";"1206677369";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"0";;;"I think we saw this while hiking around one afternoon when it had gotten too hot to climb (if it's where I think it is).

column2: no one has ever climbed it.  Congrats on a nice FA.  Perfect name too.

column1: Try to keep track of anything you do out there.  At some point I will be doing a guide.

column2: there is a small developed circuit on the opposite side of the road up the hill (on the right as you are driving up to Ultimatum and that area).

diagonal thin cracks that face the road on a solitary tower.  The thin crack has been bouldered by yours truly.  It's an amazing climb that's hardest getting onto the problem and started up the crack.  It's a little tall
column3: but the higher you get - the easier it is.  I worked it ground up since it has a nice
column4: flat landing.  Most of the rest of that circuit is found on the back of the rock and on the boulders immediately surrounding it
column5: but there is room for much more in the vicinity.

column1: You should wander around that area next time you go out.";;"0";"CA==";"6k5pr2nq";"1";"0";;"16";"0";"0"

column2: David prolly climbs more than you too

column1: The other area I was talking about is on the opposite side of the road and much lower.  Start looking for it as you get to the main intersection before you head up the hill.  It will be straight ahead as you approach the intersection and on your right as you begin up the main hill.

column2: from the Jigsaw Boulder
column3: head more or less straight left along the ridge and there is room for some cool stuff too.  In fact on the far left end of that ridge (300 yards or so) is a long wall that has two good flake problems on it.  The right one is The Flame (picture of Chris Lindner on it in the gallery on this site).  We only did those flakes and a few problems on the taller rock right of it.

column1: This hillside was what we were starting to explore when I stopped going there originally.  I imagine there's a lot yet to be found and done there.

2140;"264";"1";"9";"0";"76.194.219.253";"1207194206";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"0";;;"Kung fu Rick and Don are awesome. I really liked the boulder problem I put up I had no idea I climbed. I am old and the memory is lost. I think that is the problem name.
Also the whole about the author section in the back of the book is pretty entertaining. For everyone who doesn't know RTM very well . . . .
a direct quote from the back of the tram guidebook -
" Robert Miramontes has been a So Cal "local" Boulderer for nearly 20 years
column2: and is responsible for putting up hundreds of problems
column3: including single-handedly finding and developing the Underground of Jtree. Rob started out climbing at Joshua Tree National Park and became instantly obsessed with bouldering and exploring the area. This obsession culminated with the writing of "A Complete Guide to Joshua Tree National Park
column4: " his first book. Eager to branch out
column5: he headed to the mountain retreat of Tram bouldering
column6: and was blown away by the quality of the climbing. Spurred on by the vague and incorrect documented information
column7: the plan was hatched to do a guide for Tram. Not having the same knowledge and experience as Jtree
column8: the author went on a 5 year pilgrimage
column9: to become an expert on the subject of Tram bouldering. During this time
column10: he drew topo's (all 180 of them) and designed Troy Mayr's 3rd Edition Southern California Sport Climbing Guide.  Finally
column11: with the completion of the Tram guide
column12: Robert plans on developing a website on So Cal Bouldering
column13: and someday hopes to learn to sculpt Iron.

column2: Rob enjoyed a fixation on Skydiving
column3: entering many competitions
column4: including two world championships
column5: and was ranked 5th and 6th
column6: in '95 and '96
column7: in the world in Freestyle (acrobatic) Skydiving."

column1: Well the Rockreation crew is now all back in So Cal after a fun trip to Bishop.  It started last Wednesday when me and the girl and my little pup Olive got up bright and early to drive out in the morning.  We set up camp at the Buttermilks and were climbing at the Happys by noon.  I got on Rave and convinced Liz to try some stuff on the Totty boulder.  Miles
column2: Katie
column3: Do
column4: Nathan
column5: Meg
column6: Matt
column7: Angela
column8: Anthony T.
column9: Anthony N
column10: April...hope I'm not forgetting anybody...showed up later that afternoon.  And finally Luke and Brianne showed up with the beer after midnight.  They thought it'd be a good idea to buy three (YES THREE!!) kegs despite only staying two full nights.  You do the math...cause they didn't!  They drank their part though :wink.

column1: Day two was also spent at the Happys with highball sends of Rene
column2: Black Magic
column3: and some tourism on the local favs of the Happy Boulder.  Some girls that Do invited would show up and remain quite the rest of the trip
column4: seriously can't even remember their names.

column1: Day three we went to the milks FINALLY!  We got on Fly Boy
column2: Iron Man
column3: and Seven Spanish Angels where we ran into rtm.  Unfortunately that day would end with Katie spraining her ankle
column4: but she would stick around to cheer us on.  Timetraveler and Thor showed up that afternoon as well.  We also met friendly guy Joe from Colorado and buddy Matso (sp?) from Austria.  They would join our "team" and prove helpful in getting through the kegs!  Terrence and Timmy showed up on their bikes that night.  And my buddy Tan who now lives in LA would show up to join us as well bringing our team total to 23...I think...I dunno I lost count!

column1: Day four we went to the Sads and got on Pow Pow
column2: Strength in Numbers
column3: Beefcake and some other classics.  Doing Pow Pow
column4: in the cave with surrounding boulders filled with cheering friends
column5: honestly made the whole thing feel like I was in a comp!  Many sends
column6: many falls
column7: many laughs!

column2: many people went home.  The remainders tried the Checkerboard
column3: but few sent.

column2: only myself
column3: the girl
column4: the dog
column5: and Joe and Matso remained.  The trip went downhill from here.  It started when I noticed a screw in my tire in the morning.  Small town inflation and limited selection means I now have some overpriced but kickass BFGoodrich All Terrain tires on my ride.  I took the rest of the day off
column6: checked into the hotel and came down with a cold.  5 days of climbing and the day I relax my body shuts down!

column2: the girl and I went back to the Buttermilks to try a few things.  I tried Iron Fly about 157 times before my fingers started getting blood blisters trying to stick the crimp.
we went to the Happys and with no power left decided to get on some easy highballs and warmup-type problems.  I did 20 problems
column3: most of them under V1.  It was fun and I was tired.  Liz got on some easy stuff and even my dog Olive sent a three star VB!  We drove home and made great time
column4: making it home for my mom's home cooked Udon.

column1: Good times.  Here's some pics.  I didn't take many because Nathan has a much better camera and was taking pics the whole time
column2: I'll try to get his web address:

column1: Me showing my excellent footwork on Rave

The girl (Liz) happy at the Happys on the Totty Boulder.  Thought it'd be a good idea to forgo the spot and take pictures despite it being her first time climbing outside.  Yeah!  Way to score points!
Miles on Black Magic with Luke and Matt spotting
Anthony T. sticking the lip of Fly Boy from the sit start.
Me on Saigon with no energy left.";"cebd41b6111d2319fe40ef0ff54ecf99";"0";"CA==";"1u99hxbp";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

column1: Most SDS starts really start at specific holds and not with your ass on the ground because of varying body types. column1: 2192;"275";"1";"5";"0";"66.74.233.126";"1207581831";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: Just bought a tram pass";"wondered around for an hour looking for Christina Pilo and Carry Carmichael
column2: as I got there late and figured they took off. Turns out they were later than I and saw me as I was about to leave.

column1: Had a good day. Warmed up at the dance floor. Put up a really neat ultra highball just up from [i:1lb3hzr6]humping the walrus[/i:1lb3hzr6]. It is next to some v1ish highball crack that's not in the book. I don't think it has gone before but I don't know. Really cool though.  V2 ish maybe with a bad fall. There is room for more lines on it too!!
Went down and played on Dancing Queen with 10 kids from hanger 18. Did Byron's roof/mosquito cove/the depression plus the wills problems on the boulder next to it.
Went to power windows for Pilo and Carry to work on. That is a killer problem. I had forgotten how fun it is.

column2: we went crashpad sledding across the stream from angus. Nice slick steep hill that ends badly into trees. The cordless pad was a little slow and stopped at the bottom
column3: but my flashed pad was like a bobsled and we had to bail off before hitting the trees. This could be a regular run until the snow is completely gone. O

column1: Over all a good day. I think I'll be spending many a weekends up there.";"46495a7fe8c2d014bdf206fa1331675c";"0";"IA==";"1lb3hzr6";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

column4: maybe not for climbing but for the public using the land that is deemed "theirs". Why do you need a permit (adventure pass e.g.) for something you have a right to
column5: getting permits implies asking permission. It just seems that the rangers like the police aren't there to protect you or serve you
column6: they are there to emit the authoritarian aura that keeps everyone inline and who needs to be kept inline in the middle of the desert. One example of the shift in attitudes that I have noticed is that awhile back(pre NPS) some friends and I were partying at Jumbo
column7: things got out of control and a ranger showed up. Everyone was smashed and everyone was sub 21 and all we got was a "come on guys wrap it up". Then about a year ago parked at planet x and ready to depart I whipped out a slingshot and fired it into the desert all of a sudden super ranger in his super expedition rolls up out of nowhere
column8: literally out of thin air
column9: seriously he maneuvered that beast like he was on 21 jump street. 20 minutes and a pretty serious talking to about "weapons" in a national park later and I was $50 poorer and had 1 less slingshot. When I called in to get my slingshot back and pay the $50 the lady on the phone said she had been working there for an eon and never had heard of such a thing happening
column10: i never got my slingshot back. I'm sorry Bee but I have no reserves left for the NPS or its sentries. The NPS telling me what I can and can't do is hard for me to grasp since they have done far more destruction than I could ever pull off. Maybe I'm just frustrated because me and satya just got a $25 fine and a $25 processing fee for taking a nap after an all night bouldering session in the echo cove parking and without being slanderous I can say that he was a cheeky little bastard. Maybe I'm just frustrated because I eat
column11: work and sleep in a places of rules and regulations upheld by sometimes very assertive authorities and I just want to go to the desert or mountain and experience something a little more real without having someone hold my hand and tell me to do this or don't do that. column2: I find that there has been a subtle but marked change in policy in all government organizations I've dealt with including those I've read about towards law enforcement
column3: and the park service is definitely no stranger to that. The former nat'l monument rangers and the older park service rangers had a more laid back approach to policy enforcement
column4: and the newer rangers clearly have been trained to expect something in that they are more nervous
column5: more apt to assume guilt and very much committed to enforcement as a means to an end. I'm even inclined to state this might be a consequence of the post 9/11 fallout.

column1: I say this because I was in the DMV today
column2: and someone had left a suitcase unattended. I watched as the security guard became more and more alarmed as to what he might have to do
column3: that when a man came forward to claim it
column4: the security guard went off on him why he didn't answer the guards announcements previously. The guard was angry
column5: but also relieved that he didn't have to do anything more.

column6: which implies to a judge that I'm not cooperative. He also forget to check the box that requires me to pay or go to court. In other words

column8: we weren't camping

column10: the officer (more apropos) didn't properly fill out the paperwork
column11: so the judge should not give him slack as the officer didn't bother to understand and give us slack.

column9: but I can't see the logic or justification in public land use policy whilst we kill people for corporate interests in other lands.

Aron got the flash and 2nd ascent of "High Castle" my previously unrepeated highball line right of "i'm gay".
Alan  "naked" Moore and myself worked on an unrepeated Dan Mills V10 called "Danimal" that is to the right of Black Mamba; we figured out all the moves but were unable to link
column3: but the problem is really good and deserves traffic; there was no chalk on it when we started working it
column4: as Mills sent it about 2 years ago and its not been tried since.

column1: Alan did all the moves on Devils Dance -V12ish- good job Alan!
yours truly repeated Stretch Armstrong V10 exactly 5 months to the day since i broke my femur
column2: and i was able to achieve this without breaking it again. awesome!
with some BFD sends...for those not in the know
column3: that means Big Fucking Deal and deservedly so!

column2: we had a brittish fellow visiting
column3: Mike Rude(!) and boy is he true to name; between dirty smutty sex jokes
column4: he inspired everyone to raise their cock-err...game! yeah game
column5: and much sending occurred:

column1: Mike came really close to a one day ascent of "Left Hand of Darkness" V10
column2: falling off the V2 moves...wanker!!! "neat try Toooby".

column1: Mike did indeed flash Blue Flame V6 towards the end of the day to make up for all the fisting he did.
Damon Corso made a 2nd try ascent of "9112K4" V7/8 a problem i put on the anniversary of 911.
showing for the girls out there
column2: Cindy Foster crushed "Aquaman" V5(?) in good form.

column1: I established 2 great new problems that are really great
column2: the great "Hershey's Kiss" V3 and the great "Chocolate Frisbee" V1; did i mention
column3: both problems are great? they both utilize large
column4: black zenoliths that are very lovely chocolatey holds.

column1: "kiss" is a little grainy and tall
column2: and requires a sketchy crack down climb
column3: but it should clean up with traffic; some arete moves lead to a perfect Hersheys Kiss shaped xenolith that has a brilliant thumb catch
column4: followed by a long long move to some grain slopes. this problem is near the Dance Floor.

column1: "Choclate Frisbee" looks like someone tossed a great big black frisbee disc into some white granite where it stuck
column2: and then someone snapped the edge off...this 'frisbee' xeno leads to a nice undercling and fun but still chossy climbing above. this problem is near the Boardwalk.

column1: edit: from what i just read
column2: Aron sent "Vanishing Point" V9 in a few tries today; good job Aron!!
thats pretty much all that happened....yep...thats it......................um.........yeah
column3: well that is it i think...........OH WAIT!!!!!!!!!!! News Flash!

column1: Damon Corso climbed the undone Michael Reardon Memorial Crack
column2: AKA "House of Pain" V6 on his 2nd go of the season!!!!

column1: The story for this impeccable line is that Reardon was close to sending before he passed
column2: and Miramontes went ahead and put the line in as Reardons FA in his guide; however it never was climbed
column3: until today.

column1: Armed with a full compliment of  pads (around 10 i think) and aided by a nice four foot snow drift making it not quite so tall
column2: Damo sent in fine style
column3: cranking out the mildly overhanging thin cracks and crimps for 25 feet of Tuolumne like brilliant granite sending!! Damo dedicated the ascent to his lost friend Michael Reardon. Needless to say it was a fine moment and a nice bit of climbing by Damography. i will post pics soon.";"400282a5513c8244b7368e96a2eae923";"0";;"1ig2ms31";"1";"1208504634";;"14";"1";"0"

column1: 2348;"289";"1";"5";"0";"66.74.233.126";"1208358303";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: vanishing point / snowblind";"We did go climbing last evening. It was interesting. Went over to paper dragon first and got spit off of just about all of the warm ups. We were pretty much laughing the whole time and couldn't be serious so we just kept falling off of everything.

As a next option we decided to go look for soul caliber. Found Tree attack on the way. I did it pretty quick. Pilo got almost to  the jug but was a little timid without a second spotter present. Evidently she was attacked by the tree at the base last time she was there. We wondered up the hill just looking until we found soul caliber. That problem looks pretty cool. Next time we'll get on it.
Hit the bar at the top. Ginger
column2: the bartender
column3: is pretty cool. Christina made friends with her and she was giving us all sorts of random little drinks she had learned to make.

column1: We got the 9:00pm tram down and decided to go to the jups so she could send Suck My Venus. Insanely windy there. We pulled out the headlamps and trudged our way in. I thought I sent it
column2: until I got home and looked in the book. So I guess I did the v5 exit. Pilo did do it however at about 10:30pm as the pads blew away. She was super stoked. It was cool.
Mantle

column1: Number 713 in the book is actually "Staghorn". What is called "Staghorn" is actually "White Stag" V6/7ish. "Buckhorn" is 716 into 715.

column1: A 700-acre brush fire burning in the San Jacinto Wilderness is not expected to be fully contained until Wednesday
column2: fire officials said today.
burning at Apache Peak and the San Jacinto Wilderness in southwestern Riverside County
column3: was reported at 4:35 a.m. Tuesday.

column1: The wind-driven blaze forced the closure of the wilderness
column2: Mt. San Jacinto State Park
column3: and a number of hiking trails.

column1: More than 600 firefighters battled the blaze and had it about 5 percent contained this morning
column2: said U.S. Forest Service spokesman Jim Behm.

column1: "It's taking crews three-plus hours to walk to the fire from the nearest trailhead
column2: so it's quite a hike for them just to get to the fire
column3: " Behm said.

column1: Firefighters used two helicopters and four fixed-wing planes to battle the blaze. No structures were threatened.

column1: What are the numbers on the left side of the tick list?  Well I mean I know they're the number of problems at that grade but shouldn't they go up incrementally?  i.e.  5
column5: 25 etc. [/quote:1fcw24wr]

column1: The numbers on the left dynamically change based on your max amount of sends in a given range.  (does that make any sense?)  So
column2: in the example above
column3: the graph shows 18 V6 sends -- therefore the top of the graph is 22
column4: and the midline is 11
column5: and every other tick falls into place.  So yes
column6: the numbers on the left change depending on your particular list.

column2: where does the suggested grade and suggested rating come from?  Who decides that? [/quote:1fcw24wr]

column1: the "suggested grade" and rating is what [u:1fcw24wr]you[/u:1fcw24wr] gave the route when you "ticked" it.  the consensus is an average of all of these from other users.  (if you decide to add a problem to your tick list
column2: it will be required for you to also suggest a grade and star rating for the consensus)";"6404ba5e1f6d116095b5d7a6a31dd2ea";"0";"gQ==";"1fcw24wr";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

column1: 2605;"311";"1";"661";"0";"76.214.30.10";"1209935221";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"What is Beta?";"What is Beta? It's time for some conceptual analysis here. A first try: "advice on the best way to climb a route." Not too shabby
column2: but there is an obvious problem - you can get bad beta
column3: perhaps beta for short people that is horrible advice for a tall (and attractive) dude like me. Alright
column4: how about "advice or instruction on how others climb a problem?" Interesting
column5: but you can get beta without consulting others. Imagine you are alone in the woods climbing a problem you know nothing about. You are getting stumped
column6: but after finding a hidden hold you say to yourself "finally! I've got the beta." No one else comes into the picture here
column7: yet you now have beta whereas before you got on the problem
column8: you didn't.

column1: After much thought (oh how my MA Thesis has suffered!) I think this whole business of giving a straightforward definition in misguided. Beta isn't simply a matter of information. Imagine a boulder problem with a crucial heel hook. You would never have thought to get a heel hook on that particular hold
column2: it is around the corner and somewhat hidden
column3: but there is a large tick mark that wraps around the arete. Based on this tick mark you make the straightforward conclusion that you should heel hook the hold. It seems to me

column1: Lets now move onto the subject of a tick mark. I believe that it is just a mark identifying a feature on the rock
column2: yet it does not provide a clear perspective on how exactly the feature should be utilized. I would like to emphasize the word "clear" from the previous sentence because the perspective has to be clearly portrayed to the individual for beta to exist. Without this clarity all a tick mark does is mark features on the rock. It does not identify which feature is to be used in which order and in what manner.

column1: I probably wasn't very clear in the original post
column2: but I meant to say that beta isn't solely information based - it is also about the role this information plays. I specifically didn't want to say that information that doesn't help (i.e. bad beta) isn't beta because it isn't useful the first time on a climb. What I want to do is spell out conditions for when information is beta (someone telling you a hidden foot
column3: knowing the moves from having been on the climb before) and when it isn't (seeing the same foot because of a large tick
column4: knowing the moves because they are obvious with chalk). I think that the difference here is grounded in the notion of flash and onsight. If the information precludes an onsight
column5: it is beta. If not
column6: it isn't it. So the arbitrator of beta is: if someone knows this information
column7: could he/she (let's be gender friendly here) still onsight the climb?

column1: Its really fucking frustrating because it makes climbing very painful and campusing and system wall training nearly impossible.

column2: a friend of mine
column3: sent me this message
column4: so allow me to add to the mess:

column1: Only this chess game is unique to each player in that each player owns different chess pieces that move according to a different set of rules. No two sets are alike. Now for each different person and their chess set there exists a perfect strategy or plan of action based on the opponents moves. As a good chess player one could reason and come to these perfect moves on his/her own
column2: but they dont have to. They may also be coached in any manner as to the best course of action for a particular situation.

column1: The important idea here is that for each person and his/her chess set there is a best move based on statistics. If one plays a perfect game of chess than one will win over an opponent.
The idea of the statistically most logical move to make based on the situation and your particular chess set is it.

column2: as an analogy to climbing this means that this idea is beta.

column1: It is different for each person.
It is statistically the best move an individual can make based on their physical and mental attributes and for the given situation.
A climber can come to know the beta for a move by his/her reason alone.

column2: a climber can come to know the beta for a move by being coached in any manner.

column1: The coaching method needs some explaining.

column2: how can one be coached by another as to the statistically best method for performing a move when they are of course a different person? (Different Chess Set!) We will assume that know one knows what is statistically best for anyone but themselves. (Most people dont even know what is best for themselves.) The answer is
column3: they cant
column4: but there is a catch.

column1: Just because I say heel hook on the hidden hold around the corner and it is the best way for me
column2: doesnt mean that it isnt the best way for you to.

column1: See what I am getting at.

column2: if you are coached in any way as to the best way to do a move and it just so happens that it is the best way for you to do the move
column3: than you have received beta. (No onsight)

column1: I guess this also means that if you have been coached in any way as to the best way to do a move and it isnt the best way for you
column2: then you have not received beta.

column1: I'm not sure what you mean by "beta is subjective." It isn't subjective in one way: if someone tells me how to do a climb
column2: and I don't do it that way
column3: I still got beta. It isn't like beta for one person is not beta for another. Sure
column4: good beta for one person may be bad for another
column5: but it is still beta. The crux here is describing what time of information constitutes beta. You don't address this issue
column6: merely saying that beta is information "given
column7: received

column9: and because of this I abandoned the idea of spelling out beta in terms of information alone.

2689;"320";"1";"23";"0";"96.229.245.52";"1210651797";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: The Unspoken Battle Between Hangar 18 & Thresh Hold";"[quote="LusiciousD":dpqxy4e3]
1) We find an impartial observer to measure the penis's of all male gym members. The average length of the top 10 members wins and the other gym is forced to close.
2) Dale and Zach have a three round mixed martial arts cage fight with the winner taking all. Zach has connections in this area so I think Dale might need to watch out.
3) We all go to church and hold hands. Maybe even buy undergarments together... then everything will be alright.[/quote:dpqxy4e3]

In all honesty though I don't really find this to be a big deal. I don't like it... but business is business. I know from a lot of experience in the gym climbing scene that climbing gym owners are business people first and climbers second. When a lot of money is involved people tend to care less about the morals and ethics that their hobby community has.

Hopefully both gyms can be successful... but if one has to go down it will just be another small casualty in the world of businesses.";"a5629fae35ed2cf82e6e9e55b6b47382";"0";"gA==";"dpqxy4e3";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

column1: 2738;"323";"1";"23";"0";"96.229.245.52";"1211215879";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: weekend reports?";"Went Trammin' Friday. Pretty nice day up there.... morning conditions were great but it started getting a little hot in the sun midday.

Went to the Vanishing Point boulder first. 2Stars cruised it three times but kept PEing at the top. Now he has to quit his job so he can go mid week to finish it up so he doesn't have to cut himself in the shower anymore. I managed to finish up the Vanishing Point into Snowblind project I had been working on from the stand. Should bag it from the sit come Wednesday.

Afterwards we went over to Attack of the Staph which is fucking amazing. I wish I had some cardio because by the time I got up there I felt like a fucking wreck. Got pretty close on that rig and should be able to bag it as soon as I can convince someone else to hike up there with me again.

Lastly we went to Harry Pothead. Felt too wasted to even try to pull off the crimps at the bottom so we both just sent the mantle which is pretty cool. By the way the start looks harder than V8 but I guess this is the wrong thread to bring that up again in.

One last thing.... I think I left my sunglasses at Vanishing Point. If anyone saw them and happened to grab them or sees them before I get back up there you can keep them or give them back to me or whatever. I was going to write a  whole essay on what its like to leave an accessory at the Tram but I decided my time is better spent watching porn.";"7fc4ac700758812f04263e7a7c4d37ff";"0";;"2fvqqt4t";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

2750;"327";"4";"16";"0";"75.212.130.143";"1211294208";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"New Hangar 18 Location";"Construction is moving along rapidly and I think those of you that care about indoor climbing will really like the gym.

A massive boulder offering more square footage than the other Hangar location will probably be the main attraction for those on this site.  It's got the biggest "cave" terrain of any SoCal gym's bouldering
column2: two large top-out sectors (one at 17 feet tall and one at 20 feet tall)
column3: along with plenty of terrain at other angles as well.

column1: The lead climbing walls were designed to offer valid bouldering terrain up to about the 14-foot level
column2: so this throws another 2000 or so square feet of bouldering options on top of the already HUGE main boulder.

column1: There's plans to add more boulders down the road (and plenty of room to do so)
column2: so at some point the amount of bouldering terrain available will equal or surpass the roped climbing in the gym.

column1: This new gym will host the 2009 ABS Regionals next Spring.
Should be a good addition to the SoCal family of gyms...";"afc8ed51bc54b4c5f8b351348c4bf506";"0";;"2ifacw5j";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

column1: 2783;"330";"1";"13";"0";"71.155.213.86";"1211499330";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Coordination Training to Enhance Your Climbing";"Written By: Dale Partridge - B.S. Exercise Physiology

There is a lofty amount of science behind the sport of rock climbing that I think most of us rarely tap into. I don't know if its the because of the "scientificness" and the energy put into understanding it may be too much for some to handle. Or if most of the tips out there are just not as applicable as they should be. Regardless of the reason the information is out there. I have been doing a little research on my own for the last few months on the topic of Neuromuscular efficiency. I studied this for about a year in school at the National Academy of Sports Medicine while working on my degree and thought it would be a cool post for a forum.
So here we go hang on tight.
Neuromuscular efficiency is the ability of the neuro-musculo-skeletalsystem to allow agonists (big muscles)
column2: antagonists (oposing muscles exe: bicep & tricep)
column3: synergists (smaller muscles that help the big muscles)
column4: and stabilizers (tiny muscles usually surrounding the joints) to work synergistically (together) to produce force
column5: reduce force
column6: and dynamically stabilize the entire kinetic chain.

column1: Wow! Holy crap what the Hell did that mean?
In more layman's terms... its means coordination. Its how well your muscles
column2: nervous system
column3: and you brain can

column1: communicate. When it comes to sports whether climbing
column2: baseball
column3: or lawn bowling there is a certain matter of time  your neuromuscular system uses to adapt to a certain movement
column4: motion
column5: etc. In climbing we see this all of the time. Example: You're projecting a V7 at the Tram and your first few goes are horrible but after working the moves a few more times you slowly but surely are sticking sections of your project. What is happening here is your neuromuscular system went from speaking English and Spanish to speaking Spanglish. It takes time to warm up if its not trained often.

column1: Now the questions is... What about those climbers who flash hard problems all the time? Well they have awesome neuromuscular efficiency
column2: and they're strong. For the rest of us who aren't flashing problems left and right here are some tips to make the time from your first go to your "send" much faster.
foot eye coordination
column3: core tension
column4: balance
column5: body stabilization
column6: static movements
column7: dynamics movements

column1: This type of training takes a little more thought than traditional training regimens as well as the help of some cool out of the ordinary equipment. With my clients I often use a stability ball
column2: airex foam pad
column3: dyna disc
column4: medicine balls
column5: kettle bells
column6: bosu balls
column7: 1/2 foam roll
column8: speed ladders
column9: and floor markers. We have all of this equipment at our gym here in Riverside (Thresh Hold) if you want to ever stop by and try it out just let me know.

column1: There are tons of sites on the topic as well as some articles by some of the smartest people in the world on sports medicine.
Here are some videos that show some cool exercises:
Try throwing it in to your regimen and see if it helps break down your project time. If you ever have any questions feel free to contact me at: dale@climbthreshhold.com

column1: 2814;"332";"1";"24";"0";"71.107.147.170";"1211903616";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: Bishop this weekend";"Well Sunday turned out to be kinda wet.  I took most of the cloudy but dry morning off thinking I would rest up and send hard at the Milks on Monday.  But Sunday afternoon it started to rain and at the Milks it rained all night.  I thought it'd be too wet to climb so we headed to the Happys in the morning on Monday.  Didn't make it to the Milks to send any of my projects and was disappointed to later learn that they dried quickly and were climbable in the afternoon.  Oh well

2815;"332";"1";"462";"0";"64.93.83.3";"1211907671";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: Bishop this weekend";"Just as a follow up. The weather in Bishop this weekend was amazing.  So I guess this means when the weather says 50% chance of rain up there go for it anyway cuz you might just get lucky
column2: we sure did.  Saturday was spent all day at the happys with no rain.  Sunday we went to Owens and it rained in the morning while we chilled in the van waiting to see if it would stop.  It did stop so we went down into the gorge to climb. The first wall we got to was dry and we got in a full days worth of routes
column3: about 10 or so
column4: then it started raining again just as we were leaving
column5: perfect.  Sunday night didn't rain on us until late
column6: like after we were all in bed.  Monday was perfect weather out at the Milks
column7: no rain and none of the problems were wet.  All in all we were handsomely rewarded for not letting the weather report scare us away. When in doubt just say fuck it and drive on.";"c5cdd75ed2dc2e1171fbc676818ca44b";"0";;"1h4tjemx";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

column1: Got home from Josh last night around 10p.  Me and the missus (plus baby) strolled around Hall of Horrors and got my lady on a cool (and decently tall) little 5.7 (with screaming baby below).
Then we went out to Master Cylinder to shoot some video.  Finished the day with a [i:1wu2wlol]quick[/i:1wu2wlol] stop at Chocolate boulders.  (I had only 30 minutes while the wife fed the kid
column2: so I literally ran up the hill and tried to knock out as many problems as I could before the car horn honked.  9 problems in 30 minutes.  booyah).

column1: Weather was awesome.  72-75 all day with some gusty winds towards the end of the day.  Wrapped it up with some less-than-spectacular carne asada at Santana's.

column1: 2824;"332";"1";"11";"0";"66.75.138.220";"1212037136";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: Bishop this weekend";"Ahhh...Bishop is an enigma...we rolled in on Saturday afternoon and climbed until dark. We DID have a problem with finding camping but we probably should have claimed our site prior to climbing -- too anxious to climb! Sunday it rained on us a bit in the morning
column2: then again in the afternoon around 2/3pm. I am shocked that it was dry until the end of the day at the gorge..but then again
column3: I've never been to the gorge...knowing bishop
column4: it could be an entirely unique sub-climate.  We did enjoy the glory of a dry and gorgeous Monday at the Milks
column5: although we had to leave at 4:30 because I am a pansy (and that's all you need to know!). I diverge -- my point is that bishop weather is volatile. You need to be strategic or lucky - It's easy to choose an area that you anticipate will have good weather only to get rained on and then find that the area you were really pyshed on had perfect weather.";"56612e39ec4099b253b413f7d92a09e3";"0";;"19a1j44a";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

column1: 2869;"47";"1";"675";"0";"38.118.148.244";"1212680307";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: Fallen Angel is Paul Andersons low traverse";"I just happened upon this website/forum today and to my surprise I saw my name mentioned.  I would like to clarify a few of Dameats comments.  I did indeed establish a low traverse to the Pile ups boulder in 1989.  I named the problem "Low and Behold" and rated it B1+ which roughly translates to V6.  However
column2: like virtually every problem at Stoney it has evolved due to hold breakage and is certainly different today than it was when I did it.  In addition Stoney Point is notorious for newcomers showing up and claiming first ascents of problems that were down years previous.  The truth is anyone who has climbed/bouldered at Stoney for any length of time is likely guilty of claiming a first of problem that was done many years previously myself included.  In fact I would not be surprised if the low traverse on pile ups had also been done prior to my claimed first ascent.  Climbers/boulders need to keep in mind that the likes of Kamps
column3: Bachar
column4: Yabo
column5: Waugh
column6: Yaniro
column7: Johnson
column8: Lynn Hill and the list goes on have crimped
column9: cranked and dyno all over Stoney back in the day.  Just a little food for thought.  Keep on crankin!

2921;"342";"4";"16";"0";"68.5.49.147";"1213331981";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"USA Climbing Level One Setting Clinic";"Chris Danielson (USAC Setting Committee member) will be out to the new Hangar 18 gym in Riverside on July 19-20th to teach a Level One (local) setting certification clinic.

The two-day clinic (one day for bouldering and one for routes) will supply a Level One certification to those that complete it and it only costs $100 for the two-day clinic.  At present this certification is not required to set for local level comps
column2: but this will not be the case in coming seasons.

column1: If you have any interest in setting this is a great opportunity to pick up the certification and training at a low cost and to get input from one of the most recognized of US setters on your own setting style and skills.
It also gets you a sneak peak at the new gym before it opens to the public.
Space is limited and the slots are going fast so please contact me or Chris (CDanielson@gthi.com) if you want to take part.

column1: I think it would be good to sit down with the head ranger find out if there are any concerns with the climbing and the climbers at the tram. At that point those of us whom climb at the tram should get together as a group and make sure we are respecting the concerns of the forestry department. We do create an impact with large pads
column2: unauthorized trail development
column3: sometimes music
column4: chalk (excessive tick marks)
column5: trash
column6: etc.  Ignoring the concerns of the rangers will only lead to a boiling point leaving little chance of reconciliation.

column1: We need to understand we are not the sole group using the tram and others may find our presence there a nuisance. I have been climbing at the tram for over 10 years and would hate to have this gem lost due to the act of the selfish. Where else can you go out and send quality problems during the summer and then end the day by killing a few pops with your friends at the bar. The tram bouldering is awesome
column2: lets keep it that way.

column1: heres the skinny - we spoke with the rangers an told them that there are a bunch of climbers that are concerned with the increased impact
column2: and want to do something to be proactive. They are going to discuss this topic at their next meeting and decide what we could do to help. At which point we will organise a day that we (us boulderers) can all get together and clean up or do whatever they decide that we can do. This will also serve as a template for organising cleanups at other bouldering areas.

column1: In the meanwhile...trail building or altering the landscape is highly discouraged!! In fact
column2: its illegal and will only make the situation worse! Obeying the rules
column3: and filling out a backcountry pass when there
column4: is by far the best thing we could do at this point. I'll post up the rules
column5: incase anybody doesn't know them. Cleaning up tick marks and picking up trash will help. Respecting vegitation around boulders is another.

column1: Boulderers are not the biggest inpactors at Tram
column2: and they are not singleing us out.  Its just easy for them to monitor our activities because all of the bouldering occurs in concentrated areas that are so close to the ranger station.";"d9bcf2457a5a42db9999a0088a824afc";"0";;"cgyh1uzo";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

column1: 3026;"350";"1";"680";"0";"216.5.28.36";"1215467679";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: Clean up days are a comin'";"Sounds good.  What exactly do you have in mind?  Working on the trails?  Is this something the rangers have talked to you or other climbers about

column2: I have seen many issues with the rangers. We have problems with pad stashing
column3: trashed landscapes where we boulder and many other issues that we could be more aware of as a community. What I am getting at
column4: is that I used to climb at the Tram every weekend during it's seasons with maybe about 6 other climbers on the entire mountain with no issues with the rangers. We actually even bouldered with the rangers when they were off duty and messed around on their training apparatus. I guess you could say that we had a good relationship with them. Here in Colorado
column5: the rangers are now aware that we as a community aren't doing what we should be doing as ambassadors of the outdoors. There is talk about no bouldering in Rocky Mountain National Park at all
column6: that would suck!!!!!! The deal here is that we have already messed it up with the rangers by not policing ourselves among the climbing community. I would think that the these areas are more important than anybodies 8a.nu card. Talk to each other
column7: do what is right for everyone that enjoys the mountain because keeping the rangers on your side is the best for everyone. If we don't abide by the rules
column8: we won't have areas to enjoy kick ass rock climbing. Good luck and I hope the climbing community can come together to keep bouldering alive at the Tram for many years to come.";"f9666bd693b1cb01e554eea41711a5a8";"0";;"6tg2crtl";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

column2: we had a lengthy conversation with one of the regional supervisors for the State park system
column3: who happens to be overseeing the Tram area for the next couple of months. He told us that he has been looking over the bouldering areas
column4: and he sounded impressed by how clean the areas actually are! So
column5: if you have been bouldering at Tram
column6: pat yourself on the back for that!! He also told us that
column7: as a user group
column8: boulderers have just as much right to be there as any other group
column9: just as much as bird watchers have to watch birds
column10: as hikers have to hike
column11: and as boyscouts have to
column12: uhh
column14: they actually want user groups like us up there using the park
column15: thats what its there for. They have no intention of closing the place down to us
column16: their primary function is to enforce the rules
column17: and issue citations to those who break them. At worst
column18: they'll just monitor us more closely
column19: and issue more citations. Its my understanding that they have more trouble with other users.

column1: The fact that we can come together as a user group
column2: organized
column3: will be a bonus to us
column4: not only here at Tram
column5: but everywhere that we boulder. Even if our areas are mostly clean
column6: showing up at this cleanup will have a positive impact with the state park system
column7: and will demonstrate to them that we are concerned with keeping our impacts to a minimum
column8: and that we are concerned with projecting a positive image for ourselves.

column1: I sincerely hope that we have a good turnout for this event. Because I think that thats what is going to impress the rangers the most. obviously
column2: the more people that show up will mean that more of us care
column3: and vice versa. We are going to try to finalize most of the details within the next couple of days
column4: then we'll send out flyers and let everyone know what all we got going on.";"fbb51e3757730512d19f101cc6828dc5";"0";;"24yc18fv";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

column2: we actively DISCOURAGE people from posting copyrighted material on Mountain Project.  And we remove it immediately when it is brought to our attention.
the overwhelming majority of content on MP is original work by the posters.

column1: I fully support additional route databases and wish SoCalBouldering an awesome future.   I only sent the note to Jon to protect the interest of the MP users and the MP community - as they hold the copyright on the content they submit to MP.

we stay in southern california (vista) for the next two weeks and would like to go bouldering a little bit. the problem is
column2: we have no crashpad here. could you recommend some areas where no crashpad is necessary. we have the bouldering guide 'southern california' from craig fry for orientation. the spot 'mt. woodson' sounds very interesting. would you recommend it?
the weather is to hot for bouldering
column3: but maybe some locals would like to invite their lovely bouldering areas to european climbers

column1: what about 'joshua tree'? is it possible for bouldering in the morning before it becomes to hot?

3164;"356";"1";"21";"0";"66.171.52.49";"1216880442";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: bouldering in southern california";"Avoid Woodson if you can.  Most of the problems there are hard to find without a personal guide
column2: and most require ropes.  The Tram is your best bet
column3: but may be too far (although you [i:3di3ap0x]are[/i:3di3ap0x] considering Joshua Tree
column4: which is farther).  Josh is gonna be way too hot unless you catch a good day.  You could pull a nighttime session there -- that's been known to happen.

column2: unfortunately.
I'd head to either a) the Tram (99% recommended)
column3: or b) if you don't want to make that drive
column4: you can head to Santee Boulders (30 min south on I-15).  You'll usually find people there after work in the cooler hours during the summer.  Not nearly the quality or temps of the Tram
column5: but much closer to where you'll be staying.

column1: There's usually a large group of people from this board at the Tram each weekend
column2: so no worries finding someone to show you around (right people?  right?).

column1: 3222;"352";"14";"3";"0";"76.89.122.140";"1217358581";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: Problem DB - Beta Test";"can't you guys just click on the massive header that says SOCAL PROBLEM DATABASE? Grab the Left crimp - which sucks (Like you didn't know)
Left foot out* just under lip on good foothold (sideways edge) - right foot out* paste on total shite smear (above lip)
*Your feet are kind of stemmed at this point which gives you just enough to push to the slot.
2. Fall into under cling/sidepull with right hand (scary looking flake around hip height) Stare at slot and deadpoint/jump.
3. If you are 6'5" with + ape you can keep the heel but your IT Band might snap and hit you in the eye which you will need in order to see the slot you are throwing for - not recommended
Either option 1 or 2 feels about the same.  I tried hard to get this rig nice and wired for the circuit but it's still low percentage.

column2: Costa Mesa. . . .

column1: Miles fell throwing for the top
column2: hit the edge of the pad
column3: rolled his ankle off the edge
column4: punctured a 2 inch bloody slash in the carpet with his exposed ankle bone
column5: leaving his left foot stuck sideways to his shin and I'm sure some pretty agonizing pain throughout his leg.

column1: Not the best injury to see. Especially right before dinner. The wambulance came and picked him up and from what I'm told
column2: he went into surgery that night to 'relocate everything' and inspect for further damage to his tendons and ligaments. He is supposed to be released into society on monday.

column1: Keep the guy in your thoughts and prayers as taking a ride in the meat wagon and going under the knife are not cheap
column2: and taking time off of climbing always sucks not to mention severe pain is no day in the park.
climbing is dangerous. Place your pads accordingly. . . .  It always takes an accident for us to remember pad placement in the gym and unfortunately in a couple weeks / months
column3: we'll be doing the same things again.";"dc910f3da46b684cf1aaeafa1ad8ce32";"0";;"2oao3eo0";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

column2: if you go up before and see climbers out there please spread the word to pick up trash while you're out and don't leave anything behind... regardless of whether it's an organized trash pick-up day or not. I went out mid-week last week and picked up a bunch of cigarettes up near greenpeace and several plastic bottles at the base of climbs in some other areas. I'm guessing that this was climbers' trash since I picked the stuff up in areas that I doubt your normal gumbies are hiking around. I doubt the trash is from the regulars.. or at least I hope not. column1: 3465;"365";"4";"9";"0";"24.247.136.75";"1218990549";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: Ankle breakage of the weeK!!! Compound dislocation?";"Ok kids keep in mind Rick answers to the owner
column2: his direction comes from above. Rockreation has always run as a business first and a climber hang out second. It is what it is and has always been the same. A gym run by trad climbers focused on paying customers.

I am not really sure why you are complaining so much about Rockreation? You are there 4-5 times a week and Hanger and other gyms have been around for years. These gyms have had a better bouldering scene and terrain from Rockreation for years. I am sure the new Hanger is better than the old Hanger and Rockreation
column3: but it is Riverside.

column1: I do think for you young guys trying to work the comp circuit getting out and climbing at other gyms and with other boulderers is important. For me I just try to maximize the limited time I have to train
column2: so I can drag my crippled old arse up a few blocs when I get a hall pass.

column1: I would like Rockreation to be updated
column2: but I can get what I need accomplished there without driving to BFE to train. With gas at $4 plus
column3: I will not travel any farther than needed. If I am heading towards Riverside
column4: then I will keep going to the Tram.

column2: that is a big bummer and I hope he heals fast. It sounds like the pad was not the issue
column3: but where the pad was placed before he started the problem. And for the most part poor spotting is not isolated to Rockreation. This is a gym wide problem. Gyms should require boulderers to learn to spot before they climb
column4: this would help everybody indoors and out.

column2: but try to get there as early as possible to avoid too many pads on the Tram at once. Well prolly hand out raffle tickets around 10:am. Ranger "in charge" Kjer Sahl will be introducing herself. Dimitrius Fritz will be telling us about his climbing shoe recycling program. After that
column3: go climb and clean at your pace. Well meet back at the Amphitheater at 4 or 5pm
column4: turn in trash
column5: do the raffle
column6: then go party up at the Lounge. If everybody that says they are going to be there shows up (ahem!)
column7: it should be a pretty cool gathering!

column1: [quote:3luwykwo]I noticed a spike in the click-throughs last week.  Initially
column2: I simply assumed that the advertisements had finally become relevant to our users -- for weeks
column3: the adsense ads mentioned WoW gold
column4: etc...nothing to do with rock climbing.  About the time the CTR numbers went up is when I noticed rock climbing-related ads.

column2: after talking to a few users
column3: I believe something else may have happened.  This website is very small -- with about 100 uniques a day.  I recently added a new section to the website that took me months to complete.  I believe that a group of users
column4: in a well-intended effort to say "thank you"
column5: began to randomly click advertisements.  I have posted on the website's forum
column6: instructing users to only click on ads that they are interested in
column7: and also telling them "no thanks" to this behavior.  The post is here:

column1: I will also remove the text "Support The ProblemDB; Visit Our Advertisers"  (an idea copied from the website "DrudgeReport") -- just in case this is also encouraging random click-throughs.

There is nothing malicious going on -- just a few uninformed users of the site that think that a boat-load of click-throughs is a *helpful* thing.  I will make a concerted effort to reduce this kind of behavior and encourage the users to only click ads that are relevant and interesting to them.

column1: This morning I awoke to find an email from Google Ad's saying that they have banned my account because of "irregular" activity.
My only guess is this:  in an well-intended effort to say thank you for the ProblemDB
column2: our users have been randomly clicking advertisements.  This spike in click-throughs has triggered Google to shut down my account (which in turn shuts down advertising on ALL sites that I run).
please refrain from clicking on any advertisements unless they interest you.

column1: I go now to the land of Google to request they turn my account back on.

column2: fractured her right cheek bone and was knocked unconscious as a result of being pulled into the wall by Trevors initial fall. She also sustained lots of bruising from large bottle cap sized hail. She is ok
column3: she is up and walking and in good spirits considering. Lots and lots of pain meds. Trevor is doing amazingly well considering what happened. He did fracture his c2 vertebra a blood clot and swelling of the brain. He is awake and able to communicate and move all limbs. As of yesterday he is in a halo to prevent him from moving his neck. he may be released in the next few days
column4: if not today. thats the basics of it for now keep them in your thoughts and hope for a speedy recovery.";"a7d771beb4a698f52bb00f2ce9880c8e";"0";;"157tagmh";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

3637;"388";"1";"24";"0";"71.107.147.170";"1220223245";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"NEWS: Serious Climbing Accident at Suicide";"Trevor Matthews and Claire (not sure of her last name)
column2: who both climb at Rockreation Costa Mesa
column3: were involved in a serious accident out at Suicide yesterday.  Details from Mercury News:

column2: Calif.Riverside County authorities say two rock climbers have been injured in a fall near Idyllwildone critically.

column1: Fire Capt. Timothy Bingham says the climbers were in the Suicide Rocks area on Saturday when the man fell more than 100 feet and suffered head injuries. Rescuers carried him about a mile to safety and he was airlifted to a hospital in critical condition.
Bingham says a woman who was tethered to the climber was injured by the force of his fall.
Two other climbers rescued her but the weather turned bad and they were pelted with hail as they repelled down a rock face with her.
The woman also was hospitalized but there was no immediate word on her condition."

I did speak to Trevor's roommate this morning. Trevor is still in critical condition. He broke his C2 vertebra. He came out of a coma last night and was moving all limbs but they put him back into a drug induced coma. Claire broke her arm with the force of his fall
column2: and has other minor injuries. She went home last night.

column1: Not sure about the details of exactly what went wrong. He was wearing a helmet
column2: which apparently was cracked. Probably saved his life though.

column1: Many of you probably know Trevor from Rockreation where he works as belay staff
column2: usually climbs with Donny and crew.  Claire
column3: who has many years of experience climbing with her family
column4: also started climbing at Rockreation within the past couple of years.  Please keep both of them in your thoughts and prayers.
