column1: 3677;"376";"1";"3";"0";"76.89.123.113";"1220628325";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: Tram Clean Up Aug. 30th";"Thanks to everyone that came out to support the event! It was a lot of fun. We had around 50 people show up
column2: with a few stragglers that we never even saw. It started out rough
column3: we woke up to thunder and lightning. Then got to the Tram
column4: and it broke down
column5: they were turning peeps away at the base of the mtn. Everything worked out though.

column1: Special thanks to Jay and Kristen for driving all the way out there just to drop off prizes from their company Onsight Clothing. Also thanks to Drizzzz
column2: for bringing a posse all the way down from Santa Barbara. Drizzz
column3: where were you for the raffle?? you won a box set of vids from Integrity 7!!! heh
column4: we switched you out for a Tram guide though. Thanks to Garrett too
column5: for driving out solo and bringing climbit stuff.

column1: Thanks to all of the sponsors!! We had way more schwag than people. I think everyone left with several prizes
column2: especially the Pheonix crew. They won so much stuff that they forfeited the grand prize
column3: which was a Revolution crashpad. Even the Ranger Kjer won a pair of Madrock shoes and a chalkbag.

column1: See you all at the next stop. I think JTree
column2: maybe sometime around the new year.";"2c620d4caa73836bcdfe4e1e40240c75";"0";;"4xyitxpc";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

column1: 3690;"391";"1";"24";"0";"71.107.147.170";"1220739615";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: Finding Vanishing Point";"It may have to wait till next summer.  School is slowly taking over my life.
Messed around friday afternoon in the campground.  Gave a couple of tries to Boulder Basin Dyno
column2: but couldn't commit to sticking it.  Tried to find "Emperor's New Clothes" to no avail.

column1: Ran into KK on Saturday at the Visor.  Finally managed to tick that one.  We then cruised up to Cracker Boy and played on that for awhile.

column2: I cruised around and ran into this problem.  Anyone know what it is?  (not in either guide).  From Pink Crack
column3: walk North to the next cluster.  This problem lies just downhill and faces uphill.  Felt v3/v4-ish
column4: but i couldn't tell at the end of the day.

column2: costa mesa
column3: it used to range
column4: but I think everybody is capped off at $10 an hour. Although routes are given a certain time frame - boulder problem = 30 min

column1: So if you're a fast setter
column2: you only have to work as long as it takes you and still get paid the full amount.

other gym employees or the head setter should take care of this. We used to have people do it for trade. There is nothing less motivating as a setter coming in to set and seeing the wall completely full and no space. Stripping and setting in one session can bum out the setter and leave them less inspired. So the route quality going up there after may suffer from lack of motivation.
and clean holds will inspire the setters which should in turn bring better routes. . . . (as long as the setters know what there doing)

column1: A college I set at pays $15 hour.
A couple other gyms I've set at have payed $20 to $35 per route. And usually there is a difference between boulders and routes.

column2: sometimes a flat fee is easier.

column1: Also I think experience plays a huge roll in the pay scale.

Yep that's right - 12 FUCKING MONTHS!!

column2: Brickyard and Lizard's Mouth are officially closed for the next 12 months do to Hydro-Asstro- Mulch being dumped on potential Gap Fire erosion areas. The map above shows the official closed area. A violation of this prohibition is punishable by a fine of not more than $5
column3: 000 for an individual or $10
column4: 000 for an organization
column5: or imprisonment for not more than six months
column6: or both. 16 USC 551 and 18 USC 3559
column8: and 3581. (Translation: Unless your G-Funk and you save $5
column9: 000 a year living in a van down by the river
column10: then you should probably stay out of The Yard)

column1: Hydromulch will be applied by aircraft to about 1500 acres in the Gap Fire area. Hydromulch is an all-organic mix of paper/wood fiber
column2: water and a binding substance. It helps hold the soil in place to minimize erosion
column3: trap moisture and create an environment in which the native seeds and roots already present in the soil can sprout. The green dye in the hydromulch helps the pilots see where they have made their drops
column4: but the color will fade to a light brown within a short period of time. Treatments are scheduled to begin on September 24 and will take 3-4 weeks to complete. The treated areas will be closed to all public entry for the first year to protect the hydromulch cover.

column2: and to provide for public safety
column3: the following act is prohibited within the Los Padres National Forest. This order is effective from September 24
column5: through November 23
column6: 2008. Going into or being upon National Forest System lands within the Gap Fire Hydromulch Closure Area.

column2: the following persons are exempt from this order:

column1: Persons with a permit from the Forest Service specifically authorizing the otherwise

column2: State
column3: or local officer
column4: or member of an organized rescue or fire fighting

column1: force in the performance of an official duty.
= Owners or lessees of land within the Gap Fire Hydromulch Closure Area are exempt from the prohibitions listed above to the extent necessary to gain access to their land.
= Persons who reside within the Gap Fire Hydromulch Closure Area are exempt from the prohibitions listed above to the extent necessary to gain access to their residences.
= These prohibitions are in addition to the general prohibitions in 36 CFR Part 261
column2: Subpart A.

3857;"413";"1";"735";"0";"99.146.38.201";"1222710894";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Picking your brains";"As some one whos fairly new to bouldering i have some questions and i was hoping I could get some insite from a few people.
1. What is the best way to find out the name or rating of a specific problem when the guide you have (dr. topo for blk. mt.) has it listed as "unknown" or "unnamed"?
2. Why would there even be a problem
column2: say at a V4& V6 level that is "unnamed" but theres V1-V3s' that have been named?

column1: 3. Is it the person who sets the problem or the person with the FA that names the problem (I realize sometimes its the same person)?
I know that dr.topo is a 1/2 completed guide made in like 7 days but it pretty much the only thing I could find to make my way around Blk.Mt.
4. is there a better guide for this area? (besides Joe) LOL
3858;"411";"1";"3";"0";"76.89.123.232";"1222711466";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: Caveman - beta";"From the last decent hold that you described - match hands on the decent hold
column2: do the left hand gaston(on the part that hangs down) match hand and foot on the right
column3: match hands on the left (the crumbly flat edge/rail/sloper)
column4: get set up as double underclings.

column1: For the cheater version: reach into the crevice on the left to a "hidden" jug
column2: heel hook right (near the small pocket)
column3: then reach down right hand into the small pocket at the lowpoint of the cave
column4: fighting to keep your shoulder from leaning against the boulder behind (or letting it?). Form there drop both feet onto the low shelf and reach around to the jug on the other side of the lowpoint.

column1: For the more aesthetic version: get a little swing going and shoot your left foot to a toe hook in the jug on the other side of the lowpoint of the cave. Then bring your left hand down into the small pocket
column2: drop both feet down to the shelf (harder if you're shorter!)
column3: then bump right hand to a sloper dish and then around to the jug on the other side.

column1: For the finish move right hand to a fin above the fin with the mono hole in it. Then bring your left hand up and undercling the fin with one finger in the mono. Reach big with the right hand to a jug.

column2: I am not giving you guys my personal opinion of what I think the climb is rated. I am reciting the consensus rating from over 30 years of people climbing the thing. You don't call Full Service V11

column5: you can't just go around throwing out any number you feel like.

3879;"413";"1";"718";"0";"98.173.15.135";"1222795399";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: Picking your brains";"1. What is the best way to find out the name or rating of a specific problem when the guide you have (dr. topo for blk. mt.) has it listed as "unknown" or "unnamed"?

-- Ask folks. Forum topic? Google....I usually rely on rtm's guides when it comes to JTree and the Tram. However note that rtm is compiling info from many sources so the grades may not be accurate. In terms of rating
column2: my best example is Turnbuckle out in Turtle Rock.  Guide - V3
column3: Online consensus at rockclimbing DOT com - V2
column4: Dr. Topo - V1.  My opinion - V1.  So if you really want a grade for a problem you're working
column5: research common sources. As for Black Mtn I have no idea; maybe rtm will complete his trilogy of guidebooks by adding Black Mtn to the list. then they can make a movie out it with skydiving hobbits and orks FA'ing V17.

column1: 2. Why would there even be a problem
column2: say at a V4& V6 level that is "unnamed" but theres V1-V3s' that have been named?

column1: -- Some people are lazy?  It's about having fun really
column2: not about naming problems or grading.  But names and grades should be given as a point of reference.  Now instead of wondering why it's unnamed...give it a name!  If the person who FA'ed didn't bother
column3: then do the rest of us a favor and name it!  Let the rest of the world dispute it if they want.  It's more important to have an easily accessible reference to it so others can enjoy it too
column4: and having a name is a key aspect to that.

column1: 3. Is it the person who sets the problem or the person with the FA that names the problem (I realize sometimes its the same person)?
-- From what I've seen and do myself
column2: you can simply leave unestablished projects unnamed until you send them or name it yourself at project status
column3: either way is acceptable.  For example of the latter
column4: I believe Sharma dubbed The Flame "Flamignon" before he actually completed the problem (please correct me if I am wrong about that).  However the prior appears to be more common practice.  Me
column5: it depends on if I'm really psyched about the route. If not
column6: I'll call it "Project". If so I'll give it a name.  Otherwise you may have a situation like your #2 question (sweet route with no name).  But in the end
column7: I believe the person who gets the FA reserves the right to name it and grade it.

column2: with my right hand still holding the upper crack of the first section
column3: left fingertips on the the lowest section of the upper flake

column2: which in turn would give me wiggle room to turn my shoulders for the crossover?

column1: 3913;"417";"6";"718";"0";"98.173.15.135";"1222891271";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Climbing Alone";"So obviously this is extremely stupid; anything can happen and if shit hits the fan
column2: you're stranded in the middle of JTree or somewhere in the forest up at the Tram with no one to help you
column3: broken bones
column4: bleeding to death
column5: etc. However stupid it may be
column6: I've gone climbing alone on several occassions due to climbing buddies flaking at the last minute
column7: other times just being unable to get a committed group together or even getting a single partner to go.  I hate to miss out on an opportunity to climb outside just because no one wants to go.

column1: On the flipside. I find it to be rather peaceful
column2: a mini sabbatical if you will.  Getting away from everyone
column3: got the iPod
column4: hiking through the desert or mountains; it's pretty sweet.  Of course this also limits what problems I get to work on.  For example I'd never do Emerald City by myself but the Cube or Methane both have relatively flat G-rated landings.

column1: Do any of you guys go climbing alone?";"80cb004acf277910753fbe6cdd6e31fb";"0";;"1k2rz66w";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

column2: mostly for similar reasons.  I've also found it to be much more peaceful at times.  Sometimes it is hard to motivate myself and other times it's easier.

column1: I do try to have my cell phone on me and let people (parents/girlfriend) know where I am going to be that day.
I also talk to myself a lot when climbing alone ";"923fa2246322dcd0c6a2e40310a77a59";"0";;"32j0kc5t";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

3919;"413";"1";"27";"0";"209.176.77.38";"1222908841";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: Picking your brains";"I was motivated to catalog some of the new development at Black Mountain since the SoCal Bouldering Guide came out. There was a rough
column2: inaccurate guide on Dr. Topo and it seemed easiest to adapt it
column3: rather than starting from scratch. I also liked that it would be available online for free. It was never meant to be anything other than something that I through together. I didn't formally get consensus for the grades and I didn't include any of the new areas because: 1) I didn't know them as well 2) new problems were going up every weekend. I assumed someone else or I would update it again. Then I decided to break my thumb and go off to grad school which took me out of the picture.

column1: 1) There are so many unnamed problems because there are many problems that haven't been named. The original SoCal Bouldering Guide has circles for boulders and B grades. Only a few of the old problems were given names in the guide and that is how most of us learned about the area. I've climbed with a number of people who have been climbing there since the dawn of time (at some point in the late 80's) and they don't use names other than the ones given. Besides it's fun to say "have you done the problem around the corner from the big boulder with a seam on the left side?" To really get people rilled up
column2: I'll confess that I got sick of writing "unnamed" so I made up a few.

column1: 2) Sometimes people named V2s and they didn't name V6s.

column2: but sometimes projects get names too. Dark Horse was the Arnauld Special after one person who used to work on it in the mid 90's.

column1: 4) I wish. Someone should kick Chaz in the ass or steal his notes and do it themselves.
Now back to watching ALF reruns
column2: because there is really nothing better to do in Detroit.";"d9bfd3c57ce5413dc096b1a2ac6c5faf";"0";;"3reqir4s";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

column2: left foot dangling.  Now from what I can remember....left hand slipped
column3: I fell about 15 ft on to the small boulder below
column4: chin and chest first.  Drove back
column5: dropped off my buddy and spent 5 hours in the ER for blunt force trauma to the chest and breathing pain.  I would have to say this was a total accident
column6: though my spotter decided it best to stand on the side of the rock that I didn't hit...

column1: I think I'll have to bump my right foot higher next time as the crossover lunge may not work as I am just at full stretch.

column2: not exactly ideal temps but it went anyhow!  After I stuck the left hand gaston
column3: I matched feet and then moved my right foot up to the higher jug
column4: then made the cross over
column5: and then a dynamic move up to the shelf.

column1: Rad problem! Thank god for the juggy mantle. ";"ed79fea35fa336202ad761367e4b5e7c";"0";;"27091tdi";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

column2: no spot
column3: hit my leg on the boulder
column4: blacked out for a second or two. Woke up in a cloud of dust.

column1: try this beta - after the big move left to the gaston
column2: heel hook right
column3: next to your right hand. then match hands at the gaston
column4: rise up on the right heel
column5: then cross left high into the flake. If you get high enough into the flake
column6: its quite juggy.

column1: 4143;"433";"1";"98";"0";"98.112.139.250";"1224806266";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"0";;"Malibu Tunnel Boulders";"...gonna be shooting over at Malibu Tunnel Boulders this Sunday
column2: the 26th. I've cleaned the poison oak and the approach trail is better now. I still need some rebar to fix The Cube trail in case someone has some to donate...

column1: If you haven't been to the tunnel boulders come on down. It's a quality area with a few FAs to be had still. very good rock quality with some classic lines up to v7/8. one water landing FA waiting.
If enough peeps want to go
column2: maybe we can do both the creek and the tunnel boulders. wished I had some cool gifts to give everyone for coming
column3: but all I can offer is maybe a beer or two and great LA bouldering.

column2: take Las Virgenes Rd. to the left and follow road for about 5 miles. Just passed Piuma Rd. is a small parking lot on the right. Park here and walk south on what is now Malibu Canyon Rd. for -10 minutes to the dirt pulloff on your left with a large rock formation. The southend trailhead is here and I'll mark it so you can't miss it.
take Malibu Canyon Road for a little less than 5 miles to the parking lot described above.

column2: It seems I may be putting my climbing shoes up for a while in exchange for a paddle. I am hooked on SUP racing and I only have time for one sport. If you see me at the crag will still be the old guy talking about all the things I used to do. The good news is all of my injuries have healed from the rest and paddling does not seem to hurt my elbow. Good luck to you all and keep sending.

column2: but I was there this weekend and one of the guys in our the group was examining the good left foot edge a couple of feet below the start rail.  The edge itself looked naturally jagged but the area above the actual edge looks like it may have taken a carving. He also noted a difference in discoloration with the area that looked chipped vs the rest of the boulder's common discoloration details.

column1: We could be completely wrong but I thought it best to bring this up in the forum so that someone more knowledgable could chime in and confirm the foot feature's prior existence or if it was a modification.

column1: 4059;"375";"9";"21";"0";"66.171.88.172";"1223782845";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: Database";"[quote="dick":1fpnlhf8]What is the point of the route database? there are no maps or descriptions of how to find the problems
column2: boulders or even the area. is it suppose to provide information to find boulder problems or just list problems for some inexplicable reason?[/quote:1fpnlhf8]

column1: The database is user-driven for many reasons.  The first is to set consensus grades and star-ratings on problems.  The second is that the database will be far more full than if only rTm or myself tried to enter in every single problem.

The down-side to a user-driven database like this is that some people get lazy and enter in crappy descriptions or no directions.  It's up to the community to comment on a particular area and hope someone sees that comment and comes to the rescue.
Maps are provided via the GPS data. It's up to the submitter to provide this.  Drawings of maps can be drawn by the user and submitted just like any other picture.
As the DB grows up a little bit
column2: I think we'll see the descriptions get a little bit more love and the pictures and maps fill out nicely.  This thing has only been around for about 3 months so far
column3: so be patient.

column3: and organics. Our goal is to really expand our line so that everyone can find a use for at least one of our products. We strive to select the most comfortable shirts
column4: shorts
column5: pants
column6: etc so that while people are doing what they love to do (whether that be climbing
column7: lounging
column8: spooning
column9: etc) they are as comfy as can be. We have been working with a couple of superb photographers in the valley
column10: and have been amassing models and throwing them in front of the camera. The plan is to release a catalog that people all over the country (and beyond!) will be able to order through us in 3 ways: online
column11: web
column12: mail & phone - that's 4 actually
column13: so hooray for us! It will be chock full of beautiful models showcasing the gear
column14: even more new products (mostly tees)
column15: some small ads

column1: We are also in talks with a couple different climbing teams in the Southwest about a team sponsorship agreement. We have decided that we would rather not single out climbers
column2: and would rather use our name and products to help build the sport in a very positive way. For us climbing is about the lifestyle of it - the people involved
column3: the inert freedom that comes naturally with it
column4: living and being outside the box mentally and physically. Therefore
column5: we feel that building an entire team up is greater than just singling out an individual.

column1: One of the reasons the ratings of these new areas are so f'd up is that some tool climbs everything and gives it a rating while the problems do not have the traffic or feedback to validate the grades. I came from the surfing world that fears competition so much they threaten people and try to remove them from "their" breaks. The reason I started climbing 20 years ago was because the community was inclusive. It looks like some climbers (you all know who you are) are starting to create the same selfish vibe that has manifested itself in the surfing world.
As someone who is really only motivated anymore by FA's I understand wanting to send all of the things I find
column2: but hoarding an entire area is short sighted and selfish. In the old days if you found a new problem all of us would attack it and someone would send it
column3: usually Rob or Frank. The camaraderie of laying siege to a project is some of the best memories I have of bouldering.

4254;"441";"6";"761";"0";"98.119.206.57";"1226078384";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"0";;"Re: Naming the "Unnamed"";"Bouldering has grown enormously over the years and changed greatly in some ways with more people
column2: higher standards
column3: guidebooks and even the use of crashpads and yet some things remain the same - the purity of movement
column4: the minimalist approach
column5: the comraderie and the amazing places we get to pursue our passion.

column1: The old days had way fewer people out bouldering and seldom if ever was there a guidebook to an area. The reasons were simple - little to no market
column2: no real need and with time spent bouldering with locals at an area one would quickly get to know the problems and their locations. It was common for boulder problems not to get named
column3: and mainly because it didn't matter to them (usually the only problems that did get named were super classic and/or hard). What you ended up with was areas with a few named problems and lots and lots of unnamed problems which was fine if you were given a tour or just showed up and starting pulling
column4: but it made it hard to talk about problems without much to reference to (imagine trying to give directions to your house if none of the streets had names).

column1: Guidebooks changed all that and made it easier to get the information to the masses as well as start to catalog the problems at an area. Slowly over the years names were added to problems and boulders. Look at the older SoCal Bouldering Guide (Fry) for an example of an older style guidebook and then look how things have evolved from a simple overhead topo with nameless ratings to the present JT Guide with it's nice photo topos
column2: named problems and even GPS coordinates.

column1: Robert has stated he doesn't particularly like unnamed problems but still they exist in his guides because often times it can feel like a chore to have to give names to so many problems. Why not get some names on the problems and move on to more important things like picking up trash and maintaining access
column2: and if the "real" name become known we can always change it. Just think - there's some kid out there who going to do his first V-whatever and he'll be psyched to have climbed a problem - a problem with a name.";"b9ae1d429700c3c45a0d58ce29f1a062";"0";;"1x0vh8i3";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

column1: If we drop the two outliers at 5 that means we are only taking the average of 3 sends.  I say at least wait until we have 7 sends.  Somewhere between 7-10.

column2: at what point when taking an average does the outlier not change the + or - of a problem?
V5 V5 V4 would average 4.667 so is that a V5- or V4+ or just a V5?";"3249e3d18d95e8f0a0fed00caf9d069e";"0";;"12u9miup";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

column1: 4287;"375";"9";"718";"0";"76.173.175.249";"1226266221";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: Database";"I think the issue is mathematical rounding.  Question is at what point do you round up?  Maybe when the decimal is at .8 or .9?  At 7.97 it's probably safe to round up to V8-.  Even at 7.8 it's still reasonable.  but at 4.667
column2: probably V4+.  if it's 4.97
column3: then V5-

column1: Have you considered weighted average?  with V5 V5 V4 the weighted average is 4.8 which if rounded goes to V5-.  The weight I used was the number of times a rating was given
column2: which I think makes sense as it indicates grade consistency.

column1: Though ideally outliers (sandbaggers!) should be tossed
column2: statistically they should be normalized.  However what normalization constant to use is beyond me and normalizing is probably too complicated given the context.

column1: I do believe gross outliers should be removed.  Though a while back this was mentioned (maybe just an email between me and fraction) about a given situation "what if a really tall guy came in and rated everything V0?".  Then we're taking consensus on a problem with that V0
column2: which is not ideal given a current average rating of
column3: say
column4: V5.  Maybe it would be best to remove outliers when the grade given is more than 2 off from the rating with the greatest weight?  That would remove gross outliers but not sandbaggers.";"217743b8fc3dc8ef2493eca39e2573e6";"0";;"1rfw8c5k";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

column2: sorry. Welcome to the site.

I did some number crunching using weighted vs standard mathematical average.  Not much change but appears to be more accurate.  So let's say we give ratings a weight of the number of times it's been entered...

column1: mathematical average: (5 + 5 + 4)/3 = 4.67 (rounded) == V4+ or arguably V4

column2: arguably a V5-

column1: So lets see this with Stretch's example
column2: 9 V8 and 1 V6 for "Fraction's Superman Crimpfest"
arguably V8-
but rounded V8-

column1: So it's still a V8- but the calculated average is much more reflective of the number of instances concentrated at V8.

column2: we're still doing consensus so we gotta count it
column3: right?  So when does it go from sandbags to outright outlier?  That's what I was saying about maybe excluding ratings that are more than 2 away from rating with the greatest weight.  If someone adds a V5 rating
column4: it gets tossed as "majority vote" already puts it at V8.

column1: Then again you could argue for excluding on more than 1 away. This would automatically toss the V6 above
column2: which intuitively makes sense when you already have 9 people voting for V8
column3: right?  Now if that was a V7 instead of V6
column4: that might fly...

column1: But you still get the V8- with one versus consensus.  Maybe consider excluding in the calculation any rating that does not have at least one-third the weight of the rating with the most weight.  so in this instance there would have to be at least 3 people voting on V7 for V7's to get included in the calculation.
Anyway this is all just something to consider...disclaimer --- double check the math! ";"94a2fc31e45c117fac3dd42b74d56d87";"0";;"sqjq9y4p";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

4303;"375";"9";"718";"0";"98.173.15.135";"1226352000";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: Database";"I can get behind ditching outliers that are more than 1 off the most common rating since grades typically aren't grossly over/under-rated ie you rarely climb something rated V10 that's actually a V6 and vice versa.

However I wouldn't hard-code the point at which this occurs (after x or y number of sends). You could get 6 guys all saying V9 then one sandbagger saying V5 and that V5 gets stuck in the calculation.  Counting the most commonly given grade
column2: ie using a weight
column3: allows this to happen in real-time.  So even if you get V5 V4 V3 V2 V0 for "Stretch's 5150 Traverse"
column4: they all get a weight of one...then all you need is one more person to provide a matching rating of say
column5: V3.  Then the calculation happens with V4 V3 V3 V2
column6: automatically excluding V5 and V0.  Later you could get a couple of V5's
column7: so then it becomes V5 V5 V5 V4.

column1: Notice that you only use the rating with the highest common occurences and ones that are no more than 1 away.  Oh and I assume the system is storing all tic'ed ratings (never deleting them)
column2: just excluding certain ones from calculation...";"d686a9a01258d2e12a6cfd5e0d685df8";"0";;"1d1ehe42";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"
i get it now)
column3: or b) dropping a high and a low and averaging the rest.  I'd rather not do both.

column2: radical idea coming) How opposed would everyone be to ditching -/+'s altogether?  Actually having a decimal-based V-scale?  There is no "V5-"
column3: but V4.8.

column2: i know.  this is something that Mulligan actually talked to me about when he and Robert discussed the DB in years-past.  Sensei's argument was that he was sick of seeing stuff shuffled around so much between V-grades (it's a 4 there
column3: a 5 there)
column4: that a definitive database with decimals would fix it.

column1: I've added it to the database here:

4450;"459";"6";"718";"0";"98.173.15.135";"1227744712";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Grades/Ratings";"Was wondering about this and was hoping some of you older guys may have some wisdom to share on this subject (not that I'm a young guy myself).

I've heard comments before that got me wondering about the consistency of grades w.r.t. the area you're climbing.  Some examples of those are "it's relative to the place" and "everything is sandbagged"
column2: etc. etc. so what's the deal?  In the end we know what really matters is how hard and fun the problem is
column3: but some clarification would be cool.  Examples:

column1: - "Everything V3 and below in JTree is sandbagged".  Most of us tend to agree JTree is sandbagged
column2: but is that really the case or is it the type of climbing/stone that JTree has to offer vs other places like the Tram?  Is it that JTree actually has more consistent ratings based on what is now considered "classic ratings"?

column1: - Here's an interesting one; "In JTree I can only do V4-V5 but in Bishop I can send V8".  Got this from a JTree local. Again is JTree really sandbagged that bad
column2: OR does Bishop have a number of overrated problems?

column1: [quote="fraction":c3vkhw2g]It's called "The Eppulator." Word has it that the grade it was given coincides with typical Woodson grades -- the FA was done when 5.12 was the hardest ... thus the 5.12/v4 grade. probably v7 or harder
column2: but can't find anyone who has actually sent it recently (although plenty that have tried)[/quote:c3vkhw2g]

column1: ...does that mean The Eppulator is really V4? or is that V4 "oldschool" or "classic" ratings"?
Have ratings over time become diluted such that the bar has been lowered?  Or is it to reflect the difficulty of hard climbs/problems
column2: with the side affect being older problems being falsely upgraded?  Or are problems now more accurately graded than previously thought?

column2: then V4" so on and so on. It has only been in the last month or so that I climbed my first V8 and did not get an overwhelming joy from it!? So I sat back and asked myself why. I came to the conclustion that If I seek out harder and harder problems
column3: It will continue to get harder.

column1: As of late Ive tried to seek out very appealing Problems. Last sunday I got on The coolest Boulder Problem I've been on to date and while sending it I was having fun and feeling the overwhelming joy I was craving from harder problems. The problem I was on was a V5 and Ive been more stoked to go climb it again than that V8. So I figure if I really worry about seeking out the problems that appeal to me
column2: I will come along problems in the mid to upper range and have just as much fun projecting and sending them as I do problems in the mid to lower range.

column2: I just don't see the point.  If he's new and everyone bashes on him for his ignorance
column3: he may get turned off to climbing altogether or it may give him a bad impression of the people in our climbing community.  Every climber I have ever met has always been cool
column4: laid back
column5: encouraging and helpful.  I don't mind passing that along to anyone when the opportunity arises.  I think bashing is ok as long as you know them personally and they understand that it's all just for fun and a form of male bonding.  I'm glad there are those of us who would rather encourage than discourage
column6: and who welcome the opportunity to meet and climb with new people
column7: noob or stone master. And if some climber
column8: ANY climber
column9: has questions about shit that I can answer
column10: then I will.

column1: Unfortunately there's the other side of this....it's unfortunate that some think it's so *cool* to talk shit to people who are new at it
column2: who are trying to make new friends in the climbing community
column3: or who have questions about things they are ignorant about.  Seriously
column4: if you don't know someone personally (or at all) and they didn't say or do anything intentionally bad or wrong to you or anyone else
column5: where THE FUCK do you get off being a dick to them?!?!  I don't know this guy
column6: but I don't think he said anything wrong so fuck yeah i'm willing to come to his defense!  And if he pissed some of you off...[b:2qok4mow]PLEASE GET THE FUCK OVER IT![/b:2qok4mow]  You were [b:2qok4mow]ALL[/b:2qok4mow] noobs at one point so you know how it feels.

1) The art of slandering. if you're not talking shit and smiling about it with everyone in between goes

column1: I would like to apologize for the somewhat abusive tone of my prior message. In an effort make ammends I would like to say that generally the ground in Joshua Tree is sandy and recepetive to tent staking. If the ground is too hard to accept your tent stakes perhaps you should find another location for your tent. Another option is to buy better
column2: more sturdy tent pegs and bring a sledgehammer in case the ground proves to be a bit firm. It is also possible to tie a rope to your tent corners and lash them to a nearby rock. I hope you get answers to all your queries and send many kick ass boulder problems during your one and only trip ever to Joshua Tree. Again bad form on my part and hopefully I have helped to quell some of your tent staking concerns. Have a wonderful trip and enjoy your camping experience.";"0cf37ec0420eff70e408d48bbaf13f35";"0";;"1sbrrmxn";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

column1: i intend to visit hidden valley campground for caveman area and stem gem. after which i intend to head to real hidden valley for JBMF and Turtle rock area. where can i park? do i park at hidden valley campground and then walk to real hidden valley or drive and park near hidden valley?
i also want to visit the cap rock 2 area. do i park there or walk over?[/quote:z9q6fp34]

column2: park in the Intersection Rock day parking -- located just north of Intersection Rock.  From here
column3: you can either a) walk across the main road to JBMFP and Turtle Rock
column4: or b) drive across the road to the Real Hidden Valley parking lot and hit both these problems. (30 second drive)

column2: you'll need to drive.  Head south along the main road.  You'll pass Turtle Rock on your right
column3: then Planet X on your left.  As the road starts to make a big left turn
column4: the parking lot for Cap Rock will be to your right.  If you hit Ryan Campground
column5: you've gone too far.

column1: Buy the guidebook -- all of this is dead easy to figure out with the guide.  You'll also learn about a lot of cool problems that aren't necessarily the "classics" like Stem Gem.

4586;"477";"4";"21";"0";"66.171.88.172";"1229581922";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Bouldering Comp Scoring (Mission Cliffs in SF)";"Long story short: on my last trip to San Francisco for work
column2: I brought my climbing shoes and entered a friendly little climbing competition.  I entered the Men's Intermediate division (v3-v5
column3: middle of three divisions).  [url=http://touchstoneclimbing.com/comps/tbs4_mc.html:27hl1udj]I placed 22 of 69 people[/url:27hl1udj].  Not bad for my first-ever comp
column4: and being a little out of shape.

column1: But here's the weird part.  If I had instead chosen to enter the Men's Advanced
column2: my total score of 19
column3: 280 would have put me in 17th place in that division.  Huh?  Shouldn't they average out the scores and then divide?

column1: That'll teach me to be an underachiever.  Yes
column2: I should be in the Men's Advanced group.  Yes
column3: I can fly a plane.  Yes
column4: I can perform open heart surgery.";"6dc32e25934011b1ed9865fb009cf0e4";"0";"EA==";"27hl1udj";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

column1: 4588;"477";"4";"24";"0";"71.107.164.64";"1229605122";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: Bouldering Comp Scoring (Mission Cliffs in SF)";"That's one thing I've never liked about most comps...in most you can pick your own division.  Then you get climbers who should be in the advanced group but join the intermediate group (for example) and try to get the max points without being considered advanced just to win prizes.  Lame.

The alternative is not having divisions until after people turn in their scorecards which generally works pretty well except that the judges can literally choose the winner of each division except for the highest.
Not sure exactly what you mean by "average out the scores and then divide" but seems like the most logical thing to do would be to not have division sign ups and just rank everybody's scores
column2: then divide the number of total competitors by the number of divisions and that's how many people are in each division.

column1: i.e.  100 competitors 4 divisions = 25 competitors in each division
column2: ranks 1-25 in first division
column3: etc.

column2: you run into people coming in 15th place by having one more point than the 1st place of the preceding division...could get ugly.

column1: Maybe a better format would be to calculate an all encompassing statistical score based on age
column2: weight
column3: ape index
column4: years climbing
column5: and your astrology sign and multiply that number by your score...or should you divide...damnit!

column1: OR...we could just forget the whole thing and climb outside

column1: 4724;"488";"1";"793";"0";"209.33.43.150";"1231723279";"1";"0";"0";"0";"1";"1";;"Re: Jorgeson Sends Insane 45-foot Highball";"i met with kevin the day after he climbed the route.
he call it a solo.  he has been working on it for a few years.  he stated his recent trip to the gtitstone really made it possible.  he stated he is not a soloist and it is more of a route.
the opening moves are V11 with a short V9 ish section in the middle followed by 5.12+ climbing that " flows really well" to the top.
he worked it on toprope extensivelly and had it wired.
honestly the climbing was not hard for him.  the length and new level of commitment was.
dales line ' transporter room ' to the left was also well rehearsed and he had it dialed.  the top of his problem / route is sketchy slab climbing.

both are great climbers pushing standards in my opinion.  i know dale well and have spoken to kevin several times now.  he is a very positive and real person who has given me great energy and support.
on either line a fall from high even with LOTS of pads would result in serious injury.  the possibility of missing the pads all together is very real.
a agree insane is completly WRONG.  it was well within his ability and i believe he stepped off the ground believing it was the right time and place.

good job to kevin and also george who came close to sending the line last year.  i  watched him climb the upper section quite easily.  he is a soloist and grit climber.  it was the opening moves that stopped him.

4754;"493";"1";"29";"0";"72.25.96.254";"1231900667";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Act of Contrition";"If you didn't catch the shot of this problem on the front page you've probably seen it in the guide book.

When the park was covered in snow this problem felt like it had collected all the heat from everything around it and all we could do to bear it was continually shed layers to cope with the intensity of the heat
column2: until we were down to the minimums of decency(at least for me). It was odd to have forties in the shade and then stand next to this scoop of rock that felt like ninety degrees. Even with the

column1: heat it was an awesome day
column2: we did the mentioned problem which "The Brit" called classic grit.

column1: Then sensei lived up to his handle and sent the arete/face directly to the left of Act of Contrition
column2: which was quickly and aptly named "Road to Perdition". When JDub got on it and finished the 18ft.ish crux with bad landing and man eating chasm we both realized that we had just experienced our scariest spot/climb ever.

column1: Its bizarre that in an area as vast as Joshua Tree there are problems good and bad that collect as much chalk as they do
column2: then gems like "Act of Contrition"
column3: which is literally a ten second walk from the car
column4: can go seemingly untouched for seasons. I don't know
column5: the nature of that problem is very conducive to concealing or dissuading use
column6: tall
column7: pale rock
column8: fine grain
column9: no distinct holds to hold or  collect chalk. Maybe I'm wrong
column10: has anyone climbed this? If not grab some shoes you trust
column11: confess your shortcomings and help turn this three star problem into a four star problem.";"a0fd7382e0ac15954dec7e590a6e8678";"0";;"a5gp8t1a";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

column1: 4755;"493";"1";"718";"0";"76.173.175.249";"1231918566";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: Act of Contrition";"I hit it last summer in 90+ degree weather.  Didn't have the ballz to go for the topout.  Maybe it was just my unreliable shoes at the time but the smears felt so insecure and my spotter wasn't as good as she is now.  Plus my hands were sweatier than my ass.  IMO it felt too smooth and the landing w.r.t. the lieback is a big psych-out factor with a number of small boulders in your fall zone.

column2: it's on my project list.  I love it; tall
column3: intimidating
column4: confusing to gym rats because it has almost no obvious holds
column5: bad landing that could potentially send me to the hospital [i:xnexl7x0]again[/i:xnexl7x0] --> perfection

column1: Should get at least 4 stars. I see it as the V0 test piece for the entire park.
Damnz I didn't even know the arete next to it was climbable.  Nice job!";"cd0a94e909b2773e2f612e039cf22dc6";"0";"IA==";"xnexl7x0";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

4757;"491";"6";"53";"0";"192.45.72.27";"1231953473";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: Launching Pads";"I've got one of the organic briefcase pads that I bought for when I was doing a lot of travel to New York and it's great.  Fits in the overhead compartment on the plane and/or under the seat
column2: but big enough when opened that if you place it right it'll do you some good.  I've only used it as a pad by itself
column3: but it would be great for climbing by yourself to bring along with your regular pad to cover any sketchiness at the beginning.  If you're climbing with someone else all the time though
column4: I don't really see the point.  Good for recon too when you don't want to carry a larger pad.";"41e1898fa2e03b42d59da1f8a8cfec58";"0";;"z98urfk2";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

column1: 4791;"494";"4";"29";"0";"68.183.36.92";"1233268156";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: Gyms and the economy";"It would be interesting to see what would happen if some of our gyms closed. Would the remaining gyms get loads of new members? Would our crags become more crowded? Or would less and less people climb because of the constant need to travel to experience the real thing
column2: or more importantly maybe would fewer people would climb because of the fact that they can't simulate the real thing after work?

column1: What if more gyms started closing and the competition circuit was threatened? Would that effect the ability of a company to sponsor their rockstars because of a lack of advertisement? Without the inspiration or general radness of these rockstars in the mags or videos would people have the will to climb while having to create their own methods and motivations?
So now all gyms are closed and we live in a fallen empire
column2: we once thought that California was rock Mecca
column3: and it is with a car
column4: but few people climb and with no one to share the toll of gas
column5: we can't afford it. The shoe companies are gone and the remaining climbers cobble their own shoes.

column1: twenty years go by and China has got so big that we make stuff for them. Nokia comes here and makes us live in dorms and pays us in room and board. People remember what climbing is but no one does it. Until it becomes a mystery for a new civilization to unravel. Our own kind of  glyph.

LIKE IT? YES OR NO AND WHY???";"Stoney point is a good place to get good at climbing
column3: most people I know that have spent all of their time on granite or in a gym can't hang on some of our stoney slopers.  I don't live close to stoney point but I go becuase I like the people I see(even though I tend to keep to myself) and once you get a feel of the place
column4: you can throw the guidebook out and just crank on whatever looks fun
column5: even if it has no chalk on it.  And plus
column6: you can go there all year round
column7: no crowds or long hike in.  If you are gunna break your leg anywhere
column8: stoney is a safe place to do it.  It is a good place
column9: with over hangs
column10: smears
column11: aretes
column12: stems...and friendly people.... just about everything.  What a fun place to climb";"24a20e37c9b1b29b2c3b5a5ffc3e7592";"0";;"2r36uqfw";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

2009 -- Trip Report";"[b:335pcy0w]Friday[/b:335pcy0w]

column1: Took Friday off and drove out to Bishop.  Met some great people and managed to get a lot of good looking video of some hard climbs.
I showed up Friday and met up with Brian Hedrick and Mark Heal.  Mark worked on Stained Glass (v10) for awhile before the rock tore up his fingertips.  Nearby
column2: Giovanni G Traversi made an incredible send of Haroun and the Sea of Stories (v12).  Got that one on video.  Daniel Woods
column3: Ethan Pringle and Doug Munsch showed up just before the send.  Afterwards
column4: the whole group was led by Charlie Barrett across the valley to Xaviers Roof (v12).

column1: The whole group took shots at it
column2: but the sends went to Daniel and Brian.  After that
column3: we cruised down to Zen Flutes  a v10 face with a long dyno finish.  I worked on a v7 around the corner.  (when I find my guidebook
column4: Ill have a name for the thing
column5: but since I didnt complete it
column6: no rush.)

column1: The crew finished the day on Solitaire (v8).  The problem starts on a low sloping rail on a angled wall
column2: followed by a long move to another sloping rail
column3: then a full dyno to a sharp edge over the top.  Once again
column4: the send train rolled in and everyone who tried it
column5: made it up.

column1: Brian and Mark went off to Vons for camp food while G
column2: myself
column3: Daniel
column4: Ethan
column5: and Doug grabbed burgers at Whiskey Creek.  G got his own hotel room (lame) and the other 4 of us split a room at a local motel.

column1: Woke up long before everyone else
column2: and laid in bed rifling through work emails and catching up on Twitter and my RSS feeds.  We got out to the Milks around 10am
column3: met up with Emanuel Moosburger and his pal David from Austria.  The 8-man crew tromped out to Secrets of the Beehive  a ~30ft tall v7 with a crux finish.  Ethan made the first send and made it look easy.  Mark came up second
column4: followed by Brian
column5: then Daniel.  I took a few gos at it
column6: but couldnt make it past a v5/v6 move at the bottom. Doug made it up Queen Sweet Nectar (v9) from the 2nd move on  he swears hell get it from the start next time.

column2: LIKE IT? YES OR NO AND WHY???";"[quote="oneangryrobot":yly0eiyr]word has it that it's near Riverside[/quote:yly0eiyr]

column1: It's before Riverside city but yeah I think Elsinore is in Riverside County (?). About 30+ minutes after you pass Anaheim Hills on the 91 east.  It's a fucking junk yard when you first enter the area via dirt road (make sure your car has some off-roading capability). But once you're in the back hills where the bouldering is
column2: it's pretty recluse.  Some approaches are obvious
column3: others have mildly established trails. The dirt roads can actually lead you up to the very top of the main area as they wind around/through.  The sick thing is that the majority of established rock is in the first two hills; there's an entire gawdamn valley of boulders behind them.  Louie I believe is working on updating the current topo/info.  He said he and Matt Hulet were in the process of putting together a guide (hopefully this year?).  Should be pretty sweet~";"4fe41912634486b2613a038460ff7487";"0";"gA==";"yly0eiyr";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

column2: so if you feel serious about doing it one day just tell then to not worry about the spot
column3: just move the pads. I think once you get on it and you feel the seriousness of it you'll probably stop thinking of it as a boulder problem and more of a solo anyways. I've only climbed on it a couple times but it has more of a solo/adventurous feel to it than a lot of other tall problems I've done. Or you could just tell them you are only going to climb the bottom half and then just go for the top!

column1: 4917;"513";"1";"10";"0";"69.224.45.144";"1235347071";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: Pirates Cove";"Most people (including me) have a love/hate relationship with Pirates Cove.  I have been climbing down there for 20 years so I should know.  The bottom line is when conditions are optimal it might be one of the best "little" crags I've climbed at.  That being said when conditions are anything other than optimal it might be one of the worst.  Look for Santa Ana or other windy conditions and/or low humidity.  If the cave is not dry it's not worth the trip.  The sandy highball topouts add a sense of adventure to the place.  Read John Long's latest article in R&I.  I don't know about it getting old fast as there are always eliminates and variations to be done.  That being said I wouldn't make a long drive to get there (I live 10 min. away).  The place is best suited to the V3 - V6 climber.  Lot's of classics in this range! Heretic I saw your post in the database
column2: and Anabelle is in a state of flux.  Many holds have broken and will continue to break!  As of two weeks ago that cave was dripping with water runoff rendering Anabelle unclimable.  Be sure to check the tide level and remember to bring a towel

column4: or piece of carpet to wipe your feet on.  The rock is becomming really polished from doods climbing with sandy feet.  Sometimes dirty

column2: all consesnsusussuses are determined by taking a straight average of the original submission grade/stars and all the sends of that problem.

column1: the change coming in the new version of the ProblemDB is this:
- take original submission and take basic average between it and sends
This was the formula we all discussed here on the forum awhile back -- power to the people!";"ac5458fa652bf90fd5fba69e4449a43f";"0";;"rvk108ko";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

column2: yeah?

column1: Now does 4.8 round to 5.0 for a V5- or is it V4+? Intuitively with 2 votes for V5
column2: V5- sounds right.

column1: So let's look at Not So Thin Lizzy.  Currently it's at 3- but under the new algorithm it comes to 2.5 (disclaimer: math done in my head off memory
column2: might wanna double check).  So given 2.5
column3: how does the system evaluate it?

column1: - V2 since 2.5 is equidistant from 2.0 and 3.0
column2: making it a moderate V2

column1: - V2+ since it's greater than 2.0 but less than 3.0 (not sure where the cutoff is for the system's interpretation of V2 or V2-)
- V3- (what it currently is now) if we follow mathematical rounding
I assume also if we get something like 10 sends at V10
column2: it will still evalutate to V10

column1: Now you're gonna force my hand and tell you the surprise.  No rounding.  No v4+
column2: v5- (what's the difference).  Consensus grades will be shown in decimal format.  This was Sensei's original idea
column3: and I've come to like it -- a lot.

column1: [quote="Heretic":3lwh6jn3]So let's look at Not So Thin Lizzy.  Currently it's at 3- but under the new algorithm it comes to 2.5 (disclaimer: math done in my head off memory

column3: how does the system evaluate it?

4951;"518";"1";"10";"0";"69.224.45.144";"1236393272";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: bouldering california style...";"Funny you list Vacaville/Puthah Creek.  I have climbed at both area a couple times.  Really cool basalt
column2: and some very fun problems.  The Nut Tree Boulders are a trip.  Climbing on a hillside with herds of cattle
column3: and cow pie landings.  You definetly missed the Tramway.  Sorry Dameat
column4: but it's true.  Stoney and Santa Barbara are both really cool sandstone areas
column5: and so is Pine Mountain.  Great change from the granite that dominates most of California.  Wagon Wheel?  Not!  Steele Valley is cool enough if you live close
column6: but I wouldn't drive too far to get there. Lots of really good undeveolped rock in and around the Kern Valley.  Baldy and Horse Flats are both cool.  Dude you don't want to live in Utah.  The beer is weak
column7: and the bouldering in California is better

column1: 4954;"513";"1";"18";"0";"68.5.68.111";"1236442470";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: Pirates Cove";"For me there is a huge nostalgia factor involved with the beach. In my early years it was a training ground for going out and doing routes since there were no climbing gyms. If I reflect back on the place it's not so much the climbs as it is the many people I met down there . I met many of my early climbing partners there and remember the social scene there as much as anything else. That being said there are some damn good problems there and when the conditions are right I still try and find a way to get there. I've been down there a couple times recently and saw lots of young climbers psyched on the place and lots of problems heavily chalked which was really cool. There are plenty of negatives about the place if that's what you choose to focus on and I'm sure a lot gym bred climbers will write the place off as choss. I just wish someone would clean the City Ordinance Crack so I can do it again
column2: that was always one my favorites. Maybe I'll have to clean it myself.";"5214ccfb8524dd2098f5da2bed8be8c1";"0";;"3cisrx0u";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

4961;"490";"1";"18";"0";"68.5.68.111";"1236605320";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: Santee Boulders [San Diego County]";"I love Santee and I wish I could get there more often. It is obviously not a destination but if you like thin slab climbing Santee and Rubidoux are places where it was taken to the highest level by the old school masters. That 5.10 problem on the back of the Ampitheater is Walkman I believe and to the right is the Powell face which may be the hardest 5.11 ever. I think the 20 point problem is my favorite thing there and it was called 5.11 in Craig Frys guide book which seems a little light by todays standards.";"79e392cb0a22e4968bb773f845709389";"0";;"uimaslf8";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

column3: and discuss some of the offbeat climbing we've been doing around here...  i have as much fun hiking areas to see if there's anything to climb as i do actually climbing.  (pics are not me)

column1: So I've seen a couple people refer to the steve mcqueen boulder thats here in town?  I'm not sure where this would be by name but im pretty familiar with the area (lived here most of my life)....where exactly is it at?

column2: a friend and i found (i think?  there was no sign of development on it) an overhanging arete and an inclined circular traverse on one of the first hills once you enter into steel valley from nichols rd.  You'll know it by the boring highball rock jutting up on the left side of the top and a boulder pile.  Theres pacman graffiti on the front.  Drive past it and turn on the spur trail to the backside
column3: then up the hill
column4: you'll see a giant snowman spraypainted on the back of a big egg. right in front of that is a scaly boulder with a REALLY fun sds overhanging arete with good moves.  ...we figured it to be V2- maybe less...big holds
column5: really fun.  Theres definately holds to build some v4-5 problems off the undercling starting holds down in the cave
column6: and some short face/crack problems with creative sit starts...definately worth checking out.  Dont know if its FA but like i said
column7: there was no sign of any development
column8: and its too good of a climb to not see regular chalk.  We called it the Insecurity boulder and the problem "Dont Judge Me".  If someone has already done it
column9: let me know.

column1: Next to it is an inclined flat lipped boulder with a ton of fun variations and traverse/rail problems. You can do a circular traverse around the whole thing
column2: although the landing is rocky at the upper part of the route  Its got a bunch of crappy graffiti on it and theres been some walls made under it to enclose the cave off...  I'll put some pics up soon.

column1: We used to climb some of the rocks in the valley between the summits and the weird satellite dishes
column2: has anyone done a topo for that area?  Louie?
curious if anyone on here has climbed the solitary metamorphic boulder on the spur trail that heads towards fishermans camp off of the tenaja falls trail?  We've been climbing it for a while
column3: know we werent the first
column4: but cleaned a few new routes on it.  Just curious what people were rating some of the runs... most of the stuff we found on it was v0-v2 with maybe a harder route or two on the overhang...

column1: Anyone ever hit up the bluebird boulders by the campground off of ortega?
and as far as tenaja is concerned
column2: we've been going up to la cresta heights a bit lately and running some fun boulders on the graded lots (should stay empty for a while now considering the economy)... some fun problems....sooooo many boulders taken away by mini-mansions already though.  However
column3: half the hill is national park property
column4: and there are alot of undeveloped rocks surrounded by dense chapperal. Working on responsible singletrack trailbuilding up there
column5: if anyone is interested
column6: let me know. theres some highball slab routes protected by a single hanger on a rock above the water tower
column7: and from there are some other problems... nothing crazy...but cool to check out if youre bored and in the area.  Anyone else work any problems up here?

column1: The overhanging hemet boulder off gibbel with the sit starts
column2: anyone have appropriate ratings on that?  (side note
column3: simpson park is FUN! not alot of hard climbs
column4: but some surprising variety- really good energy up there with jack mcbroom and the hemet underground climbers...super positive guys) The rock off of Gibbel-

column1: Anyone climb the rocks off of leon rd in menifee (not the rocks off of newport with the painted eagle and the two highballs)?  easiest way is to turn onto leon from domenigoni and head south on the oiled dirt road
column2: park near the 90 degree bend in the road
column3: FUN traverses on the flat side of the road
column4: and a few fun problems on the hillside
column5: with room for more. not sure if this side of the hill is private
column6: but we've never gotten hassled.   [img:yr07d5ou]http://c3.ac-images.myspacecdn.com/images01/98/l_2a01efbbcb08dcfe94b3512a6d87557a.jpg[/img:yr07d5ou]

column2: referred to in craig fry's guide as the glue-on boulder area... the south side of the highway...not the best
column3: but some fun climbs none the less...anyone ever hike around there?

column1: By Thomas mountain where the 74 hits the 371
column2: anyone drive up pimlico canyon rd along that ridge? Or the boulders off of Morris Ranch Rd?  I've heard good things
column3: but dont have a truck to get up there.";"d38bc0fcbe748f9dc6e9aa45c6dbbe87";"0";"CA==";"yr07d5ou";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

5001;"528";"14";"718";"0";"76.173.101.159";"1237970128";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Delete the bullshit?";"Is there any opposition to deleting DB entries that fall into some combination of these categories?:
1. an absolutely poor description.  I'm talking epic FAIL. Literally know one knows what the fuck you're talking about
column2: what the holds are like. etc.

column1: 2. little to no approach directions.  This only applies when the parent level(s) do not adequately describe the approach

column2: no pics or video

column1: 4. the shit is just wrong.  ex: someone makes an entry with pics of a problem that is obviously
column2: say
column3: Dark Matter
column4: but calls it "Purple People Eater" and rates it V19.

column1: If there's no opposition to this
column2: could we start some process for which we all can review a particular entry for it's level of quality?  Some have already done this at some level
column3: ex: http://www.westcoastbouldering.com/prob ... hp?id=1153. This entry
column4: according to those who chimed in
column5: qualifies for #1
column6: doesn't for #2 as the parent level (Pile Ups) has pretty good directions
column7: and qualifies for #3.

column2: it would be cool if the entry could be marked as "up for review" by the community and if there are no issues after some time period X
column3: the entry stays and we live happily ever after.  However if the community opposes it for whatever reason
column4: the account that entered it is sent a PM indicating that the entry requires some editing or clarification (as specified by the community via comments).  If said edits/clarifications are not made within some time period Y
column5: the entry is deleted and the account is again notified of the deletion. If edits are made
column6: time period X is restarted and allowed to expire if all is good.

column1: 5012;"526";"1";"1395";"0";"71.177.144.51";"1238348019";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: discussions about a few local spots (temecula area)";"Well my motivation comes from two different places... one
column2: im a single father (mom's out of the country in semi retirement... ) and i run a store
column3: so most of the time i get to climb is limited to half day excursions
column4: so i make as much use out of the local buffets as possible.  I can shoot up to hemet in the morning and do a 10 problem circuit before noon and be back to pick up my daughter.  Second
column5: I enjoy hiking to new areas that i have no beta on and figuring stuff out.   Dont get me wrong
column6: if i get the chance
column7: i'll run up to tram
column8: or Black Mountain
column9: Santee or Bishop... but the convenience of the valley boulderfields keep me on the rock on a frequent basis and thats all i care about...

column2: I was under the impression that the steve mcqueen boulder was that one on rainbow valley rd by the border check...that highball on the side of the road.  Its not near rock mountain is it?

column1: I agree with you on the blank egg issue...its very frustrating to see such a huge amount of rocks only to have most of them be unclimbable...  Going up the ridge on the south side of the freeway at the border check (the opposite side of where the rainbow boulders are)
column2: most of the rocks are just BLANK.

column1: I actually enjoy face climbing alot more than i do overhanging
column2: so being around here isnt such a burden as well.

5013;"529";"1";"661";"0";"66.215.217.136";"1238439388";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Black Mountain Guide";"Black Mountain will have a guidebook soon! Ian McIntosh and I are working with Wolverine on a guide to that beautiful mountain. This guide will be rad. Wolverine publishes the best guides in the country
column2: including Bishop and Hueco bouldering. This is what we are shooting for - a guide for Black Mountain that can compare with the cream of the crop.

column1: We see this as a community project
column2: since the climbing at Black Mountain is endless and predates just about everyone currently going up there. We've been busy exploring new areas and scrubbing new boulders
column3: and to keep on schedule we're shooting for twenty new problems a week. This is hard! We know where the projects are
column4: we just need help climbing them. We've got this thing
column5: I think it's a blog
column6: where we are going to put up info on new problems and new areas. Take a look: blackmountainbouldering.blogspot.com. It's new
column7: but there should be updates bi-weekly.

column1: We've completed topos and descriptions for all of the well-known problems (around 450 of them)
column2: so let us know if you know of any areas up there
column3: or do any cool projects
column4: or have any great photos
column5: or know the history. We'll repay by letting you all know what we discover.

column1: The process continues. We'll both be at Black Mountain on the weekends and most Wednesdays. We're working on a new area near the bottom of the mountain right now
column2: called The Republic. We'll be out there Wednesday
column3: so email blackmountainblog@gmail.com if you'd like directions.

column1: This is great news!  I can't wait for it to come out.  Great idea on the blog!  Don't forget to use the ProblemDB for consensus grades/stars.
Also - to everyone else - if you feel strongly about a grade at Black
column2: make sure your voice is heard by ticking the problem in the ProblemDB.  No whining about the grades in the guide if you don't speak up!

column1: 5016;"529";"1";"661";"0";"71.137.255.46";"1238461018";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: Black Mountain Guide";"Directions to The Republic are up on the blog: blackmountainbouldering.blogspot.com. Hopefully we'll see you Wednesday.
I also have to wholeheartedly agree with master Fraction. Let your feelings be known on the grades. Our inspiration for grading comes from the old hardmen
column2: so take the benchmarks to be Big Greenie (V1)
column3: Hueco Wall (V3)
column4: Boneheads (V5)
column5: Cracker Boy (V7)
column6: OK Arete (V8)
column7: Morphic Resonance (V9)
column8: Dark Horse and Buzzsaw (V10). Granite bouldering is hard

5031;"533";"6";"718";"0";"76.173.101.159";"1239367420";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Skipping Holds --> New Problem or Variation?";"Taking this to the forum as suggested by big brother.
Does skipping holds on an existing problem equate to a new problem or is it just a variation of the existing problem?
Let's look at it from different perspectives. What's a good example of a problem with variations?...Caveman in JTree. It ends on two different places outside the cave
column2: you can skip the hidden hueco to bump the grade up by one
column3: you can take a high juggy variation or stay low on a sweet gaston
column4: and you can even do it in reverse.  But they are all still considered Caveman.

column1: So when is a new problem generally established off an existing problem?:

column2: ridiculously difficult SDS (ex: the Chuckawalla Sit)
ridiculously difficult topout/end (ex: EZ Direct Mantle)

column1: c) combination of a. and b. (ex: Mandala Direct SDS)
d) joining two or more problems (ex: Terremer
column2: The Wheel of Life)
same finish
column3: different path (ex. I-FLOP vs Pancake House
column4: Double Orifice vs Double Orifice Direct)

column1: So when is it not a new problem?
- Given an existing problem following an order A-B-C
column2: when starting at A
column3: ending at C
column4: following an intended path B
column5: you skip holds or use intermediates. With respect to skipping holds or using intermediates
column6: neither warrant a proclamation of a new or distinct problem as all available holds pre-exist on path B
column7: and how they are utilized may be easier
column8: harder or equal in difficulty depending on your stats and/or climbing style. Consequently
column9: this should only warrant a tick with a reasonable grade
column10: given the climbers stats and style
column11: and what/how existing holds on path B were used during the send.

column1: - A simpler argument; we all tend to skip holds on VB's and V0's
column2: especially in the gym. But do we ever claim it's a new problem?  Usually never. We just call it a "variation" of an existing problem
column3: if anything.

column1: Some problems where skipping holds are regarded as distinct problems:
- The Crack Eliminate at Stoney. Skipping all the holds on the right side but nonetheless just a harder variation of an already great problem?
- Vaino's Dyno at Stoney.  Skips everthing between the start holds and the sloper topout of the Yabo Mantle.  Some of you really tall guys don't even need to dyno
column2: it's just a really huge dynamic move.  Some really high feet and even a shorter guy like me can reach the sloper from the same start holds.

column1: - Unitizing the "G" at the Tram - Offroutes a large foothold
column2: otherwise the same as Nipple Shredder. Who removed the pink-on-blue tape from the foothold?

column1: There is a slight gray area; a certain run-and-jump...A Streetcar Named Desire. Given the nature of this run-and-jump
column2: the "start hold" is the topout dish.  But different start hold == distinct problem! However
column3: some consider this to be just a different variation of Streetcar...";"abe1b1bad6905bd8cb85488a1bf0d186";"0";;"1in2gvnl";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

column1: 5036;"534";"1";"16";"0";"68.4.52.217";"1239434809";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: steele valley area clarification";"Those are the Snowman Boulders
column2: due to the obvious graffiti found on the largest one.  In fact
column3: the hardest problem there is Angry Snowman.

column1: There are many more problems already established there than shown on your topos.

column2: I would like to do a more complete topo/guide to the area

column1: The Amoeba Boulder is uphill from the Shotgun Boulder and that grouping
column2: above and right of the problem Elevation.  There is a somewhat highball problem on the front side that climbs up to and past an orange amoeba shaped feature.  Most of the problems are in a narrow corridor on the backside of the boulder and are shorter than Amoeba.

column1: Someday I promise to put together more complete info on the area
column2: but as I said time is always lacking...

column1: 5208;"681";"9";"21";"0";"216.93.161.36";"1240000617";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: New Site Design Is Up!";"ps  I remember folks talking about this awhile back
column2: so I figured you'd want to know.

column1: Grades and stars are now weighted.  Here's how it works:
1st grade (when the problem is added).  (example: v1)
1st tick --> normal average of 1st grade plus 1st tick (ex: v1 + v2 / 2 = v1.5)
...we continue the normal average until we get 3 ticks.

column2: we do a weighted average.  See this thread for more details:
props fraction
column3: looks really good.  I'm not a web design or computer guy so I can't really appreciate what you've been up to

column1: I've only tried this problem once.  I would match on the incut left-facing flake thing and move with my left hand into the two finger pocket
column2: then I would go up right handed to the grey intrusion crimp...From here I could see how a heel-hook would work but I couldn't do it at the time.

column1: I also tried matching on the incut left-facing flake and crossing right handed to the desperate sloper down and right from the grey intrusion crimp
column2: then I had to throw a left foot karate kick onto the wall in a stem like position.  This might've worked too but maybe this is the V7/V9 difference in beta.

column1: Anyway I couldn't tell which way was easier at the time.
P.S.  I'll check out Jingus Arete too thanks for the heads-up a.ron.
P.P.S. Different people climb things different ways

column1: 5299;"696";"1";"664";"0";"149.136.33.253";"1241533923";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: Shameless Beta Request for Chili Sauce aka Moffett Problem";"The original problem did not entail a heel hook.  If one desires to use one

column1: The attitude expressed here is so typical of the young boulderer todaym and frankly it sucks.  Here's an illustration of my point: I went to Hueco with some peeps a short while back
column2: one wanted to get on that cave probelm on the boulder adjacent to Baby Face Boulder...I forget the name
column3: but if I recall the grade
column4: it's V7 I think...starts as a sit at the back of the cave on crappy holds and then goes straight back
column5: you can use a wicked knee bar or lunge staright backwards...sorry I forget the name but it's a benchmark problem.  So I watch this person try and learn the problem
column6: and each time they start the problem over
column7: they begin to start on holds that are further into the problem
column8: in essence removing three to four moves of the climb.  I don't know the person well enough to call dab at this point.  Anyway
column9: they finally give it a push...but like four moves into the prob and send.  They get all exicted and stoked
column10: high fives etc...and I all can say to my buddy with whom I am standing with away from the hoopla is that was not a send
column11: no way
column12: no how.  This exact event happended later on the trip on a Standard V8 for Hueco
column13: this time I called dab as they decided that the original 15-feet of the problem were not important enough to include and the probelm was the same regardless. The remark was something like
column14: "on the videos I have seen of the problem
column15: professionals today don't start there."  Great
column16: forget the history of the rig
column17: dumb it down because a new generation deems it not worthy...nice for our sport.

column1: Same thing with Chili Sauce...if one is going to claim a send
column2: one ought to be ethical about the matter and send the problem
column3: not some other contrived version of it just to boost one's ego.";"b784ec9316774464364733bb342b0404";"0";;"3vtk6ko8";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

column1: 5300;"696";"1";"10";"0";"69.226.189.135";"1241535247";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: Shameless Beta Request for Chili Sauce aka Moffett Problem";"Doing a heel hook on Chili Sauce is not exactly the same thing as skipping 15 ft. of a problem.  I am not a young boulderer as I have been climbing for 20+ years.  Whetether you use a heel hook or not the handholds are the same.  Just because Jerry didn't use a heel hook doesn't mean we all have to climb it the same way.  Do you really think Jerry didn't use it on pupose?  I think it is more than likely he just didn't see it that way. I had done the problem the original way when I learned of the sneaky new heel hook beta.  I think Rob Mulligan was the first to use it?  Anyway my point is that as long as you use all the original holds you have done the problem. If Jerry had used a heel hook on the FA would doing the problem without one also be offensive to you?  I totally agree that history is lost on many of today's younger climbers.  Most of them couldn't even tell you who John Gil is
column2: but everyone who climbs should be able to apply their own ethics to their climbing as long as they are not damaging the rock.  If they cheat themselves they are the one's who have to live with it.";"ee462d43e92d06ca8bdcf6251643ba73";"0";;"3objaios";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

column1: 5301;"696";"1";"664";"0";"149.136.33.253";"1241536774";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: Shameless Beta Request for Chili Sauce aka Moffett Problem";"Thanks for the great reply...
I have never used the heel hook so I take your word that the hand holds are the same
column2: given this
column3: a heel hook obviously takes a lot of weight off your crimps...and changes the way one progresses upward from that point.  No wonder it's not V9.  To your point about the original holds
column4: the rock where the heel would go is not original...that's not an original foot hold...which is my point.

column1: When I hopped on this classic
column2: a heel hook never entered my mind as a solution
column3: the natural line and feel (for me and I guess Jerry) was to go right up the middle using the face.  To answer your question
column4: if the original probelm did entaill a heel hook and someone later decied to do it not using one
column5: no
column6: I would not at all be offended.  Eliminates have a place in bouldering
column7: making stuff harder is fun...part and parcel of bouldering.

column1: Ethics in bouldering to me are important because alot of the time it's just you and the rock with no witnesses around...why do you think calling DAB became such an important part of bouldering recently...I think it's a really cool thing that some of today's boulderers invented...keeps em honest.  But you are right
column2: in the end
column3: cheating yourself is tough to live with.";"e44ca79ca40e40890e4b62cd3310a85d";"0";;"3lqhmpd3";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"
