column1: the brits are known for their pulling skills. such fu is their style but just that. using a heel hook is a different way to do it. the problem is that the line is contrived because it
column2: the original way
column3: climbs too close to an obvious heelhook. I really don't understand your attitude and your emphasis on ethics. Besides
column4: what is ethical about bouldering style? I've yet to see the ethos behind anything in bouldering except the spotter doing what he/she says. (Ethics is morality-based and relates to the responsibility one has to others: like for pilots
column5: etc).

column2: wanting beta on a contrived problem is cool
column3: but your attitude is BULLSHIT> doing the problem WITHOUT heel hooking IS contrived cause it's a forced style just to get a higher score.

column1: a rating can be defined as being the most efficient way to climb it under the best conditions. V6 is what I think it is--based on problems in hueco
column2: but maybe 7 too. if this is applied to chili sauce then the heel hook is the logical way to send it
column3: choosing harder ways is up to you but not required of others.

column2: chili sauce is nice
column3: but there are better lines in that rating worth doing... Y2K or Right2K are both in the 8 or 9 category and way more clean and pure. There's also Bittersweet (9)
column4: electro gecko 2000 (7ish- pure pulling power and NO WAY to heel hook
column5: but it's a choss pile )
column6: dark amber (7)
column7: broken flowers (7 or 9/ stand or sit)
column8: the north wind (7ish--ultra pure)
column9: kingpin (6?)
column10: line right of kingpin
column11: and several new lines around the peanut ranging from 4 to 7ish (they are on a boulder called the Bushmill
column12: due east of the Peanut with the backside
column14: having two lines
column15: one on the left and one in the center
column16: then around front is an arete that starts off a block with a way hard first move after you hang the start pinch)
column17: also just above the peanut is a slasher face of slopers that goes up the right side clearly visible from the peanut--up and left about 100 feet
column21: etc. I think all these are in the shade at one time or another. some are not in the guidebook cause they are super new.

column1: There is a problem in colorado known as Meathook. V11. It didn't get a second ascent for years until this guy
column2: a local
column3: and not young either
column4: sent it using a drop knee. some said it was not a legit ascent. The fact is the guy couldn't do it the original way because he's not tall enough. the move goes into an undercling
column5: if memory serves me
column6: and if you are too short it's damn near impossible to do. the truth is
column7: the line being pure
column8: his use of a dropknee IS because he's damn good at that technique (a veritable expert at it since watching him hike anything in the black hole at morrison--powerpulling just doesn't work in the blackhole). His ascent was different
column9: but it wasn't "unethical
column10: " it was just a different style of movement applied.

column1: I realize some peeps skip start holds
column2: of which I think is totally lame. I've asked rTm to designate start holds and start beta for a new version of the jt guide of which I think he's fine doing. I also dislike peeps doing stussy-starts (bumping from the ground to get the next hold without actually pulling on first). The irony is today in high level comps is a stussy start will/can get you DQ'd. climbing style is of utmost importance and should be suppported and addressed whenever possible
column3: and it should be done in a nice and educational way. some peeps simply don't know better and really just need to be edumacated. I also have an issue with the spotter touching the boulderer
column4: or the boulderer hitting or scrapping the pad or a tree
column5: etc. Their response is that they would have held it anyways. Of course if they were that omniscient
column6: then why climb it at all since they already know what they WILL do. This type of practice is most often established in the gym
column7: and peeps could politely tell others that that isn't actually climbing
column8: it's climbing with an aid point. But most think it arrogant or elitist or presumptious. It is. And it's also important for the sport or practice that the community be the glue that holds and binds and promotes real quality style... we all know the mags are too pretentious and self-righteous to do that for us. column2: I don't like to heel hook
column3: I just do it cause it suits the available holds to use something that's a foot reach away and is
column4: if I remember correctly
column5: two inches deep? Anyways
column6: my position is to be knowledgeable of the original ascent
column7: even repeat it as it was done
column8: if possible and always try to climbing it in the best style and most balanced and efficient way. I think the problem is we see it from to very different point of views based on what you see as the sanctity of the original ascent. I'm not mocking you by saying that. I'm merely pointing out that you hold in great reverence the style demonstrated in the original ascent. Moffat (I apologize for not knowing the spelling) chose for unknown reasons not to heel hook
column9: and that is important to you. What is important to me is that there is another way that is more efficient.

column1: I think such reverence is good and important
column2: but I don't think the "old school" guys are infallible. If it's important to some peeps to remember the way it was done then so be it. Not my cup o' tea
column3: at least not to any exacting or fundamental sense. There's a fine line concerning the differences in our views in that I would be so inclined to agree with you if I had to actually do a move or two to get to some holds
column4: but i don't. The fact that I have to lift my leg to get the heal hook is the key movement in question
column5: and I can see how someone with a strong and absolute view of the original ascent would simply not see it any other way
column6: but I can also see how it makes no sense to say one body movement or another is disallowed just because Moffat chose to do something specific to reach up to potentially the same holds. But
column7: if you heel hook you can reach farther left to lower and better initial holds followed by reaching all the way around to good holds. Or... you can continue up and reach the exact same holds used in doing the problem without heel hooking. So
column8: is it wrong to move one body part over another? That thinking
column9: though it defends the absolute style of the first ascensionist
column10: is also self defeating in that it creates too strict a rule set on the climber's ability to move freely.

column1: If you want to stick to a strict interpretation of the traditional ascent then that's your thing. I think
column2: in this case
column3: such a strict interpretation also inhibits free body movement making it less meaningful. I'm more interested in pursing the experience within a simple set of rules governing whether there was any outside interference
column4: or I used the ground to assist me. In general
column5: I agree with how things are done in classic style
column6: but on this one I don't.

column1: My apologies if I bummed you because chili sauce is important to you. But I can't disregard
column2: even if Moffat disregarded it
column3: an obvious hold to the left
column4: and yet
column5: you said you don't think that foot hold is obvious or easily accessible. To me it is
column6: and that makes all the difference.";"064340e3a181b0e84c403adbf0ce8ae8";"0";;"cmkikvgo";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

He didn't do the full top-out slab for (I think) Sex Magician Sit
column8: so I asked him about it
column9: saying something like "are you satisfied with your send?".  He said yes that he was. To me
column10: that's what truly matters; that [i:1p29m1h4]he[/i:1p29m1h4] is satisfied with [i:1p29m1h4]his[/i:1p29m1h4] send.  Anyone can say he didn't really send since he didn't top out
column11: but no one has the right to tell him that he shouldn't feel satisfied with his send if he does.

column1: If someone unlocks more efficient beta on line A-B-C
column2: using same start holds A
column3: same holds/foot features on path B

column5: that makes the problem easier than previously thought (based on their style

column7: height

column10: then this simply equates to a downgrade
column11: yes?  So if someone unlocked new beta for Crouching Tiger at the Tram that now makes it a V4
column12: then so be it. The original FAist who rated it V7 or whatever simply didn't consider certain movements on the same path other than the ones that he felt were best for himself and his style/abilities.  HOW you use the same available holds (using intermediates
column14: whatever) on an established path should never matter as there is no "tape" indicating what holds to use and such.  And there are certainly no written or unwritten rules that say we need to honor the FAist by maintaining their original grade on the problem or that we need to do the line the exact same way they did it. And I might have missed it in reading
column15: but how does anyone know for sure the exact sequence Moffat used to send Chili Sauce in the first place?

column1: I've always felt that a name given to a problem is a name given to the line. If the line is impure
column2: and someone can use jugs off to the side to make the problem easier then I should have considered that and included it in the rating to accurately reflect that option. Eliminits are such BECAUSE an option exists. Why does slashface get so many stars? Well
column3: there aren't any other options. the rock is quite stellar
column4: and it's tall. It looks good
column5: and it feels good to send
column6: and it's a wonderful gateway for those wanting to do a tall problem.  Those that say chili sauce is not the best problem say so mostly
column7: I would guess being that I'm from that crowd
column8: because the line is marred by the jugs to the left side. I used them. Some don't. Had the line not be done 25+ years ago
column9: it would have been a standard for 6 or 7 with the heel hook--given that most today would interpret that from the point of view of gym climbing
column10: and heel hooks are standard fair today. Moffat did it
column11: and so it goes that his style is the classic style of ascent. It does help to have such a stellar career and name; otherwise
column12: I would say such a "classic" style would simply not exist on the problem.

column2: the problem has a classic style of ascent and a "new wave" style too. Lets call the heel hook line chili powder... I guess that could be controversial too
column3: in that it takes away from moffat's ascent
column4: and gives me perks I should never really have gotten. You be the judge (just don't rain on my parade.)

column2: but for those of us who are either injured or just flat out old ... two questions:

column1: 1) Does anyone follow a regimented training schedule?  Simpler schedules I've seen go X weeks on
column2: 1 week off.  Some other do different types of workouts through the schedule (endurance
column3: aerobic
column4: etc.)
column5: then finish
column6: then repeat.

column1: 2) Does anyone try to take off a big chunk of time (a month or so) each year to recouperate?  I've heard it's good to take one month off from climbing each year to give your body a chance to catchup.
The max time I've ever taken off was two weeks -- once after I injured my shoulder at the tram
column2: and once after I got a cortisone shot for the same shoulder 6 months afterwards.  It seems to be catching up to me since my injuries persist and I'm starting to look at long-term damage (especially for my shoulder).

column2: suffice it to say that I spend:
strength-endurance
column3: and power training
column4: with every other Monday adding finger board or hangboard training

column1: Tuesdays or Wednesdays - Gym bouldering on one day
column2: the other day at 24-Hour Fitness for Opposition Training
column3: Abs and Cardio

column1: Thursdays - If I don't feel too sore
column2: I'll do some leading and/or traversing the gym for endurance.

column1: Saturday or Sunday - Bouldering one day on the weekend
column2: rest the other.

column1: I'll do this for the entire quarter
column2: then take the first week of each quarter off.  Last time I took too much time off I had to retrain my fingers to crimp. No bueno.

I've had inflamatory issues in both shoulders since I was 18 (that's 14 years now) stemming from an older job at UPS. This unfortunately has completely altered my gym workouts i.e. no more bench pressing
column3: military or overhead pressing
column4: not to mention having to be very very careful doing any wide-grip pullups
column5: and absolutely nothing with a barbell
column6: ever
column7: as it impinges the shoulder joint.  Luckily for myself and for my climbing
column8: I can still do pushups
column9: dips and pressdowns with little to no strain on the shoulder.  However I've NEVER had an issue with my shoulder while climbing.  I attribute that to the constant stretch your shoulders get when your arms are straightened out
column10: not to mention the strengthening from all the pull-ups (the traps
column11: rear delts
column12: etc.). However it's important to note a few things for maintaining shoulder strength and health:

column1: 1. Stretch constantly.  While you're at work
column2: sitting at the keyboard or just waiting for your turn on the boulder
column3: stretch your shoulders out.  Never keep them still for too long.  Make it a habit to stretch and rotate often.

column1: 2. Do ALL those dorky exercises they tell you to do in physical rehab.  If you don't wanna look stupid laying down on your side rotating a dumbell
column2: then find one of those newer stand-alone cable machines
column3: fix your elbow against the handle bar and do the rotation exercises using the cable for resistance.

column1: 3. If you have to do military presses (to strengthen the anterior delts)
column2: keep the weight light and the reps high.  Avoid any kind of front raise exercise as they are generally bad for the shoulder.
go to your local gym or buy some dumbells
column3: and train your delts.  This should be part of your opposition training.

column1: 5. Make it a [i:20w0uu3e]habit[/i:20w0uu3e] to do all the above.

6. Save the Cortisone shots for when you're 90; you don't want to erode the shoulder before its time. Unfortunately for me Cortisone is no longer an option as I've had 2 in my left and 3 in my right. Your max EVER is gonna be 4...I think...
I've managed to stave off shoulder pain for the last 10 or so years doing all the above
column2: though it does come back from time to time when I get lazy and decide to sleep on my arm
column3: sit too long at the computer
column4: or get stupid at the gym and try to dumbell military press some obscene amount of weight.  But recurrence is once a year at most.  Wish I had a better answer than that but overall I would say adjusting your habits and consistent training is the key to preventing that shoulder from going to all hell.";"4f80fe6e8cf962f942c9bea26dd5953c";"0";"IA==";"20w0uu3e";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

column1: 5361;"702";"6";"21";"0";"24.23.130.142";"1241903275";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: Training Schedule / Time Off";"[quote="B_Held":32z5t34a]Steroids and painkillers when you're sore.[/quote:32z5t34a]

5362;"702";"6";"718";"0";"76.174.112.190";"1241927078";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: Training Schedule / Time Off";"[quote="Stretch":2qch0em5]Why is the max 4 on the cortisone. Doesn't it wear off?[/quote:2qch0em5]
It does but the side effect is that it erodes thus weakening the soft tissue
column2: ligaments and tendons around the shoulder.  If I remember correctly
column3: my doctor told me three shots in the same place is usually the limit

column2: but I just came across it so...
that's an important point
column3: and here is my explanation of why things either seem to appear that way or just might be that way. First off
column4: each crag has it's own style
column5: or technical elements
column6: required to move efficiently over that stone. Some stone has a higher capacity or need for friction
column7: and the frictional characteristics can be different based on crystal size. This frictional component is very important in terms of footwork as it relates to angle of the wall. The higher the demand of shoe friction
column8: the more relevant it is to wall angle (being that very friction-dependent footwork has a limited angle that's usable
column9: josh being a good example). The different rock compositions also produce different types of holds
column10: angles
column11: and wall or "panel" like features (ie. some crags require a fairly high degree of turnout moves while another might not).

column2: looking at any one person's developed style and movement skills
column3: would you think there would be compatibilities such that one might feel more confident
column4: more capable or more suited to one crag over another? Imagine each crag being a separate school of training/style. Ask yourself
column5: have you really masters this or that crag's special character or nature?

column2: it's very subjective
column3: but this subjectivity can be put into perspective by making sure you climb a diverse set of problems at any given crag for any given grade or grade range.

column1: Lets looks at a few crags and their specific nature. Joshua tree is often seen as a sandbag crag
column2: but is it? The rock has mostly large crystals
column3: offers very high friction capabilities for the shoes and hands
column4: and is often times is in the sub vert to just overhung angle. As one can imagine
column5: this demands a very high dependency on foot work and maximizing shoe friction. But the foot holds aren't always obvious and may be just flat smearing surfaces that seem quite steep to use effectively. Furthermore
column6: hand hold types tend to be sloping
column7: sometimes incut at odd places. Pinching is very important as is finger tip crystal pulling (where you actually place your finger tips up behind individual crystals and open crimp or open hand pull). But josh friction has more to do with the large crystals' very sharp edges rather than the surfaces of the crystals. That's why rubber is very effective on josh rock
column8: but hands can be a fixed bag
column9: especially if you try to just open smear the finger pads on the rock. Lets contrast this with yosemite granite (tram and black mtn are similar with the tram being the most different). The ditch has mostly flat crimps
column10: very technical angles (not unlike josh)
column11: small holds that require fingertip pulling without the high surface area/friction one might get in josh. the ditch is also very temperature and humidity dependent where even just a mild breeze can make a big difference. The rock simply isn't very frictiony
column12: or feels greasy
column13: unless conditions are just right. In the sun
column14: it can be down right terrible.  The nature of the edges demands very precise body positioning unlike other crags. Foot holds tend to be very small requiring a fair amount of toe strength whereas josh usually requires broad foot smearing (basically trying to maximize surface area)

column1: My point is that there is a unique relationship between rock type
column2: angles available and hold shapes that are all dependent on the weather patterns of that area during the in season. Whatever your inherent ability is
column3: finding out your "real" limits demands a fairly healthy amount of climbing on that particular stone.

column1: Now lets look at a persons' own experiences: lets profile a typical gym climber who learned but hasn't refined their skills yet and another who has refined their skills in the same gym. The first climber is beginning to learn how climbers move: turn out
column2: weighting one foot
column3: flagging for balance and support
column4: locking off
column5: dynoing
column6: momentum dynoing
column7: turn in moves like drops and backsteps
column8: etc. Though this climber has reached a point of understanding for the language of movement
column9: they haven't yet become efficient at their gyms' style of movement: setting
column10: wall angle and hold choice. In essence
column11: this person is not so "molded" or "pre-set" to move or pull according to a fixed set of variables... his/her gym. But this person as learned one thing
column12: that learning in the gym usually is learning to stand on fairly large or incut footholds. The later person has already made movement on his/her gym terrain second nature. This means
column14: he/she has to relearn and rediscover new parameters that might be outside his/her experience. Ironically
column15: the latter person is more "biased" towards a certain type of climbing. The former is more malleable. Also
column16: as problems get harder in the gym
column17: they usually get so by way of worse hand holds: smaller and/or slopier. Usually
column18: difficulty is not based on foot hold size or shape
column19: or even movement. This means the first mistake a gym climber learns is to trust their feet too much
column21: and just think of pulling WITHOUT regard to their balance; balance being something you deal with if you hit the target hold (ie
column22: desire to hang on). But learning to stand on your feet on micro footholds
column23: or very smeary faces demands a high degree of balance--something rarely learned in gyms.

column1: The irony is the first person might "accept" the new demands of an outside crag sooner and learn to work with it while the latter person finds themselves trying to "live up" to their old standard in the gym. This means they will start to seek out problems that favor their skill set and level of performance. For josh
column2: there are some gym-style problems: nicole overhang
column3: bittersweet (minus the mantel)
column4: thin lizzy
column5: caveman
column6: scatterbrain
column7: chili sauce
column8: flight attendant
column9: etc. These typically have good landings and mild topouts
column10: but they don't represent the typical josh problem. Ironically
column11: though gym climbing has a huge potential for variation
column12: it
column14: ends up being very narrow in it's movement variation. And the biggest drawback with gym climbing is the lack of new and refreshing wall angles and profiles. These angles and profiles can become second nature to an experienced gym climber such that new angles can totally shut that person down.

column1: Ask yourself if you mentally have a harder time with scary topouts
column2: or bad landings while bouldering. In other words
column3: are you more emotionally effected by risk elements?

column1: The problem database is an attempt to give a mathematical rating to a consensus opinion. It's a way to separate yourself form the number as this number includes many opinions. Is midnight lightning v8 or 9? well
column2: I bet it's somewhere in the low eight point rating since many seem to agree with the v8 rating it was first given after the B rating system was dropped. Also
column3: shorter peeps might rate it higher. The climb favors being tall or at least lanky.

column1: Movement is based on developing core strengths
column2: primary pulling/pushing strengths and finger strength. yet all of this means little without a sense of balance and finding as much equilibrium as possible. Without balance
column3: one is using far more energy just to maintain position let alone advancing upwards. Gym climbing or hueco problems tend to be about grabbing good holds and pulling your way up. Often
column4: hueco is seen as overrated
column5: but the irony is it's not. It's a crag that just happened to be most like the gym before gyms were created. The gym forces a climber
column6: because of setting limitations
column7: to learn to develop primary muscles over technical concerns. Hueco suits that style perfectly. hueco isn't overrated
column8: it's the real thing
column9: but it seems so because we climb that style all the time. What if you spent that much time in the  gym climbing vert sloping walls? I bet you'd bet pretty good at font climbing without ever going there.

column1: The point is that sandbag and overrated problems that aren't done intentionally are more often related to the climber than the climb. Ask yourself: is this the type of movement I practice? Have I truly maxed out my capacity to use feet? Is my core weak (ie
column2: feet cut loose all the time in the gym)? Am I intimidated by the line and fall line?

column1: I personally find josh not to be sandbag
column2: but then again I spend a lot of time there and often challenge myself on the classic lines that are VERY technical. I might flash a v8 but spend an hour trying to send a v4. Why? Because I have to learn it first. The 8 was gym ready
column3: but the 4 was all new to me. I then confirm this by seeing if I can send the 4 over and over even when I'm tired. If I can
column4: I bet it really is 4
column5: and I've finally mastered it.

column1: 5390;"459";"6";"718";"0";"65.203.134.170";"1242170530";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: Grades/Ratings";"Thanks for the insight.  Maybe I just have a bias toward JTree and the type of climbing it has to offer.  I would say I do experience 'mental cruxes' when climbing certain problems but have never let that keep me off the problem.  I had a bad splatter off of White Rastafarian last year but managed to get over it by the following weekend.  Eventually sending that problem
column2: though not my most difficult send
column3: was my most satisfying thus far.  However 'being scared' I think was natural for me
column4: which is one of the main reasons I chose to work that line.  The idea of mastering your fear to attain something you desire has thus far been an unequaled motivator.

column1: I appreciate the ability to contribute and review consensus grades on the problemdb
column2: and to get opinions from so many climbers with a broad range of experience.  I only question the obvious (and unfortunate) possibility of 'ego stroke'; problems being overrated simply for the sake of someone saying they sent a "V-whatever".  Now that the problemdb has the ability to keep a scorecard like 8gay.fu
column3: there appears to be more incentive for those who contribute to the problemdb to overrate.

column2: I will think more on it and reply back.  In parting
column3: I'll say that Nohl's response is also something I've been putting to work as it puts things into perspective i.e. finding those climbs that look fun and are fun
column4: rather than looking for grades.";"a8b350324a7f0b59ceda67e30a60ce25";"0";;"2err1ac9";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

column1: 5397;"705";"1";"661";"0";"71.84.213.92";"1242331350";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: Black Mountain Questions for the Forest Service";"The meeting went amazingly well. We met with John Ladley
column2: Recreation Office
column3: and Andy Smith
column4: Assistant Recreation Office (see the Super Topo link in a previous post for more on Andy's work at Taquitz). Both were not only friendly
column5: and seemed to truly care about the mountains
column6: but were also open to reasonable suggestions for change. Here's the cliff notes version of the meeting
column7: in ascending order of importance:

column1: 1. John and Andy didn't know about the dirt road to the Republic
column2: so there is little chance of it being cleaned up any time soon. Ah well
column3: real men have trucks anyway.

column1: 2. Of course you need an adventure pass to park on the road
column2: but the Golden Eagle Pass - or what do they call it now
column3: the "America the Beautiful Interagency Access Pass" (how lovingly bureaucratic) - also works. Just put it on the windshield.

column1: 3. Parking in the campground with an adventure pass is allowed (although I've heard reports to the contrary in the past)
column2: just don't do it on a busy weekend when you may be taking sites away from campers. Use common sense.

column1: 4. There are some pictographs around OK Corral. We've all seen them
column2: but I just assumed it was paint from the 70s or something. We were first told to enjoy them and then to respect them. Remember Hueco
column3: and be kind to the writing on the rocks.

column1: 5. The lower gate is closed to prevent people from trashing the road and getting stuck when there is mud and snow. But as we pointed out
column2: the road below the Corral - and to a large extent the campground as well - dries out early in the season. We suggested that another gate be added directly above the Corral or the campground
column3: and John and Andy were both open to it. [b:1dhut2w0]HEAR THAT! WE COULD HAVE NEARLY YEAR ROUND BLACK MOUNTAIN ACCESS![/b:1dhut2w0]

column1: A second gate isn't a done deal by any means
column2: but the possibility is a live one. It needs to get cleared by the fire people
column3: and someone has to pay for it (perhaps $3
column5: but there may soon come a day when the summer is Black Mountain's off season.

column1: Overall the meeting went as well as could be imagined. Any thoughts on all this?";"e41913de61d002332fb63120da0d0273";"0";"QA==";"1dhut2w0";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

column1: 5410;"709";"1";"718";"0";"99.21.5.100";"1242429991";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Crouching Tiger - Beta";"So apparently there is V4 beta for Crouching Tiger (Tram - Conquest Ridge).  If someone knows what this beta is
column2: could you please enlighten me?
but I think I remember an awkward heel hook around right of the low block.  This moves the crux higher in the seam.";"e6df947cc1c7a1cdb84651d00d81dddd";"0";;"14h6xpza";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"
I hear...";"da ditch is a weee bit greasy
column3: eh. but I doubt that the ditch rivals LC for most fickle conditions around. Anyways
column4: feel free to chime in on the most fickle bouldering crag around. Blacks might be up there too
column5: but haven't been in so long
column6: and usually always limited to shit weather (late spring and summer) anyways
column7: I could be wrong about that.

column1: And to add to that... it might be that granite is the most fickle of crags to climb at. Squam is a bit more tolerant
column2: but I think that's more to do with continuous prevailing winds that keeps the boulders aired out moreso than blacks or da ditch.

column1: On another note: what's the most consistent granite crag around
column2: and most consistent crag regardless of stone?

column1: ps. IMHO all the major crags accessible for the bay area cuties are at least 3 hours away... anyone want to correct me on that... cause all I know is da ditch and tahoe. I'd say that makes their weekend approaches a grade 3
column2: going to the east side being a grade 2 and anything under 2 hours a grade 4
column3: anything under an hour a grade 5. So what is a grade 1? You don't want to know! (new rating system officially launched tonight!)";"7fba823e6563abe7be55e6515a855b12";"0";;"2vldmko0";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

column1: 5413;"709";"1";"753";"0";"75.142.52.27";"1242448587";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: Crouching Tiger - Beta";"V4 beta? thatd be intresting. the easiest way i know of doing it is start on the block. heel left foot and reach to the sloper. heel hook around the right block about midway. gastone the obvious crimp with right hand. left hand in the seam. bump right hand to a higher crimp (posotive) in the seam. then move left hand to the gastone making it a very good sidepull. then jug it up with the throw for the top.
well hope this sheds some light on the problem.";"1e3e73506236c05f748d3962baab4ef3";"0";;"3pvyxo15";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

5414;"709";"1";"24";"0";"71.107.178.59";"1242490849";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: Crouching Tiger - Beta";"There's no way the heel hook makes this V4.  We're talking a 3 grade difference.  It doesn't make it [i:2441ytw8]that[/i:2441ytw8] much easier
column2: maybe V6.  And I can't speak for the FAionist but this beta isn't exactly a secret...pretty much the only way I've seen it done.";"cb5bb3ff7774b97d0b255bf69d2a1574";"0";"IA==";"2441ytw8";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

column1: 5415;"709";"1";"21";"0";"63.146.75.2";"1242573828";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: Crouching Tiger - Beta";"I saw Craig Gilbert do it the hard way -- straight up without any heel hooking.  Everyone watched and groaned.
I'll get John Markham on this thread (Aron should know too - he was there).";"00ac398a1a7761214d5e41b43e748be8";"0";;"1mogijs7";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

Yeah I know easy beta for that climb.  So what you do is you kinda bear hug for the start and you get a right heel/toe cam and go up with the right hand.  The trick for this first move is to paste your left foot a little higher than you think and rock up into the cam to reach the first hold (this hold is not as good as the one right above it
column2: but it helps if you can't reach the good one).  After this you bump to the better hold
column3: match
column4: than either bump right hand one more time and go big to the jug or just go big from the match ; ]

column1: After that its pretty much done.  This method is a little tweaky
column2: but give it a good amount of attempts its much easier than the Craig way for sure.
if not let me know...

column1: 5417;"709";"1";"718";"0";"99.21.5.100";"1242625462";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: Crouching Tiger - Beta";"Thanks all for the replies.  I tried deeloin's method today; that sloper is no bueno in the summertime
column2: though in colder temps it will go for sure.  I'll probably try again next weekend so we'll go with Timetraveler's beta (awesome handle.  I used to love B2TF but I''ve always been more of a Terminator fan wrt time travel).

column1: Some other beta; I was climbing with a really tall guy today.  He did some interesting shit.  Start both hands on each corner of the big block
column2: then heel hook/calf scum on the left corner of the block (left start hold).  Nice and controlled left-hand static reach to the middle crimp. Then bring both feet onto the block and bomb for the jugs.";"680afb59de58cb0b3972bb801a53dd1f";"0";;"3exehg1f";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

column1: 5418;"435";"1";"718";"0";"99.21.5.100";"1242626119";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: Sunshine Daydream/Yo Picasso";"Revisiting this topic. I know it's been awhile...

I tried this today with the kneebar without much success as it doesn't seem as my leg is long enough for it?  Probably just bad foot placement. However I did try something else; using the jugs inside the offwidth.  There were ample holds to get you up to second rail
column2: however if you reach up a bit higher
column3: you can get a sweet-ass hand jam at the very top of the offwidth
column4: good enough to rest on and get to the very last rail at the top
column5: then traverse right to the topout.

column2: I'm wondering if this becomes now a question of efficiency or is this just one of many variations on this same problem.  Damon (Corso?)'s version looks to be V4 or harder
column3: the rails + the kneebars also appears to be about V4.  However the offwidth jugs and handjam doesn't feel anymore than easy-moderate V3.  Has anyone else gone up the offwidth the same way?  If so what's your take?

column1: 5419;"709";"1";"10";"0";"69.109.40.146";"1242673837";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: Crouching Tiger - Beta";"On the FA I used the left heel hook and bumped my left hand twice up to the good hold in the seam.  Then slaped around right to the sloper
column2: and established my feet to go right again the the gaston.  Match and go for the jug.  For some unknown reason I topped out to the left onto the sketchy
column3: mossy slab above the dead tree.  Not hard
column4: but scary.  Later RTM figured out that you could mantle straight up from the jug.  As for the grade I don't really know. RTM rated it V7 in the guide
column5: but it could be easier with different beta. From reading the posts it seems everyone other than the ridicuously strong Craig Gilbert pretty much did it ithe same way.  Let's call it B1 and move on.  Always thought it was a pretty cool problem though.  Don't over look the slabs on the other side of the boulder.  Good fun.  Hope this helps
column6: but I just remembered that heel hooking is cheating
column7: so maybe CG got the first and only REAL ascent.  LOL.";"d7a9f199b541ebab2771cac55b592a4a";"0";;"voihboc0";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

5433;"712";"6";"5";"0";"99.48.89.220";"1242850287";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"mission impossible";"A man was riding his Harley along a California beach when suddenly the sky clouded above his head and
column2: in a booming voice
column3: the Lord said
column4: "Because you have TRIED to be faithful to me in all ways
column5: I will grant you one wish."

column1: The biker pulled over and said
column2: "Thank you
column3: Lord. Please build a bridge to Hawaii so I can ride over anytime I want."

column2: "Your request is materialistic. Think of the enormous undertaking; the supports required to reach the bottom of the Pacific
column3: and the concrete and steel it would take! It will nearly exhaust several natural resources. I can do it
column4: but it is hard for me to justify your desire for worldly things. Take a little more time and think of something that could possibly help mankind."

column1: The biker thought about it for a long time. Finally
column2: he said
column3: "Lord
column4: I wish that I
column5: and all men
column6: could understand our wives; I want to know how she feels inside
column7: what she's thinking when she gives me the silent treatment
column8: why she cries
column9: what she really means when she says nothing's wrong
column10: and how I can make a woman truly happy."

column2: "You want two lanes
column3: or four on that bridge?"";"c66f9e96acde9c3cecf7f694c7aa3648";"0";;"3e2a9qae";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

actually

column1: I started to do some work on allowing all users to modify any section of the site.  In order to not create a total anarchist state
column2: I'd need to implement a "revisions" system
column3: so we could easily roll back unwanted changes and see what users edited.

column2: this is actually a pretty significant change to the site -- all descriptions would need to reference a different database table
column3: as well as editing pages
column4: RSS feeds
column5: etc.  In addition
column6: I'd need to create a mechanism for admins to review/compare/rollback previous versions.

column1: So -- I am *still* going to do it
column2: because I agree with the idea completely.  I just need to find a spare weekend or two to implement the feature.  Gimme a month or two and you guys can edit till your hearts content.

column1: Cheers.  And thanks for using the problemDB:

column2: and you're welcome.

column1: 5557;"729";"6";"680";"0";"216.5.28.36";"1244571947";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"SavageClimbing.com!";"I wanted to share my website with those of you that haven't had the pleasure of viewing it yet!

It is a blog with an emphasis on quality climbing videos.  I've got several HD videos up on the site including one from Black Mountain and a bunch from our trip to Hueco in February.  The newest video is a V11 from Hueco by the name of Power of Landjager.  I should have a lot more from Tram and Black Mtn from this summer season.  Let me know what you think (unless your name is Aron)!

I had done some problems a while ago (ten years ?) that I never realized were FA's until Hensell and Powell told me as much when we were all out there last year.  They are down at the Wild West area on a solitary boulder.  One climbs the steep left arete and the other climbs the OH face to its right.  Both are pretty good and quite different from the normal dime-fests that hill is known for.  If you're looking for more to do at the Rube
column2: you should look down there as there are a few obvious (scary) highball things still to do.

column1: Also interested in checking out Flat Top (thread drift - sorry) when you guys revisit the area.  Let me know...";"2eb0e777d2efb5cd546d748a664d157c";"0";;"1r2h9wd5";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

Here's your science fact for the day:  temperature drops 3 degrees for every thousand feet of elevation.   So Valley station is about 2600' and ranger station is 8400' ... so say 6000' feet?  aka 18 degree difference from top to bottom.
That's not always exact because a lot of factors can change the temp
column2: but it's a good guide if you ever need to make a quick estimation.";"a3fcd99cadb26daf93af0a3f6825f14b";"0";;"3ijuqg87";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

column1: And on the that note I'll get back to the point of this thread. Since the industry I work in has been put on hold until people are ready to spend boat loads of money on luxuries. I have taken up Hobo (different from bum or tramp. Hobo is short for "Hoe Boy" which came from migrant farmers during the Great Depression and refers to one that travels for work
column2: just so you know) status and found work on the east side. Leaving this weekend and hopefully riding out our "Great Recession". I got super lucky and got a gig that will pay me more than I've ever been paid and I get to live somewhere that I love to live with people that I love to live with.I'll be in Swall Meadows so I doubt I'll have any run ins with any of you
column3: but hopefully I'll see some of you guys out at the crags this fall and maybe some Way lake sessions this summer. Aron is cruising up and you should too. I'll be on a job site with a couple of guys that are workhorses so I will greatly appreciate the company.

5660;"716";"15";"1834";"0";"75.23.154.38";"1246469908";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: Waimea Arete (beta request)";"hey thats me! the above pic makes it look harder than it is at that point - once you grab the right sloper off the left hand mini hueco (below pic) then left heel hook hand foot exchange and pull/stand up onto the left heel and grab the big sloper in your face as a left hand intermediate then bump up to the top lip with your left hand. then i think (its been awhile) i flipped the left heel to a toe stand and matched the top lip (like the above pic shows) and then just stand up and mantel/flop onto the top. the bulge is in your chest but the top is better than it looks and the mini hueco is a good foot hold and keeps you locked in. once i did it with a spotter i did another lap with my spotter taking that pic - so its not that bad.   cheers!!";"1fc684234a352d718ecaf738d7153dd6";"1";;"285rczpx";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

5686;"742";"6";"21";"0";"67.180.150.191";"1246855517";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"RIP John Bachar:  1957-2009";"It's being reported that legendary climber John Bachar died today
column2: falling during a free solo of Dike Wall.

column1: A few users on Supertopo.com's forums confirm it.  Friend of West Coast Bouldering
column2: jleicht
column3: just got a text from a guide friend of his in Bishop who confirmed the fatality.

column1: 5688;"742";"6";"598";"0";"76.191.218.112";"1246905832";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: RIP John Bachar:  1957-2009";"It would be difficult to overstate how important John Bachar was for bouldering in SoCal.      The Front Range in Colorado was probably the only other place in North America where bouldering was as well integrated into the regular practice of elite rock climbing.  Even in the 1980s
column2: bouldering was a pretty marginal sport
column3: something done maybe at the end of the day while drinking beers or as a substitute for "real" climbing.

column2: like Largo
column3: made it one of his specialties.   The high balls
column4: including those that blur the line between bouldering and soloing
column5: are best known.   But many of his best technical problems were really memorable.  The original line of Caveman
column6: right to left
column7: done in EBs with the toe hook
column8: was a pioneering line
column9: as were many of his other creations.

column1: Aside from simply taking bouldering seriously; climbing bold lines; and creating visionary technical routes
column2: Bachar was also important for the style of his movement.   Bouldering was an art form
column3: and flailing-- grunting
column4: scraping
column5: shaking --was a form of failure.  His preferred motion was always smooth
column6: measured
column7: and controlled.

5698;"744";"4";"16";"0";"166.143.5.211";"1247714461";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Slo-Op 3 - New bouldering gym";"For those that aren't familiar with the history
column2: a group of dedicated climbers pooled their funds and rented a small storage unit some years ago. They then proceeded to fill the space with climbing walls and had their own mini-gym. That original facility (Slo-Op 1) was enjoyed by many and they even hosted some competitions. One day the inevitable happened though and they had to tear down their walls.

column1: The main users took the tear down in stride and did not give up. Instead they rented a larger commercial space and built a far larger version of what they used to enjoy. After a couple of years
column2: the number of people using this new Slo-Op 2 facility was far larger than what was ever envisioned and so once again it was time to move.

column1: Construction is now drawing to a close on Slo-Op 3
column2: and they went big this time. Well over 3000 square feet of top-notch bouldering terrain will be suplemented by a dedicated slackline area
column3: a campus board
column4: and an adjustable crack machine. The bouldering terrain is where the new Slo-Op really shines though. There is a good mix of angles (including plenty of steep terrain)on which to climb and almost everything offers top-out options to better simulate the outdoor bouldering experience. The walls are tall too. Many of them topout between 14 and 16 feet above the floor.

column1: Regardless of your climbing ability or angle preference you should check the place out. If you're within a couple of hours drive from San Luis Obispo
column2: it would be well worth the drive to climb on these boulders. If you live closer
column3: you should be very happy because you have a wonderful new facility in which to climb. I only wish it was a few hours closer to home for me. I guess I may need to take a road trip...";"931ca00ad56131355bb6c65c317984f1";"0";;"pb1u57tc";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

column1: 5706;"748";"6";"753";"0";"71.138.119.2";"1248071154";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Break Days?";"hello all so ive been sick for the past week and its like my first time taking three whole break days since i started climbing alittle over a year ago. damn three break days seems/feels like alot.
how many do you usually take and whats recommended? this is a question i shoulda asked along time ago.";"8bb8c0bc01f5015d330c271450446e36";"0";;"1cw4t4q9";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"
5707;"748";"6";"24";"0";"71.165.100.176";"1248103470";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: Break Days?";"Don't stress it.  Your body needs a rest every now and then - listen to it!
Don't worry about losing strength or technique.  I've felt maybe a little sluggish coming back from a break
column2: especially the first day back after a week or so off
column3: but you'll be back at full strength in no time.  I generally feel like it takes me about as much time (climbing regularly) as I took off to gain all my strength back which is really a small price to pay for taking some much needed rest.  For example
column4: if I take a week off
column5: it usually takes me a full week (climbing maybe 4 times) to feel like I've regained all my strength.  I have also lost most aches and pains or illnesses in that time though so definitely worth it.";"4488b4ed2a341dfc5d8b93d559c636fe";"0";;"13ouxcpc";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

column1: 5753;"758";"6";"24";"0";"71.165.100.176";"1250030509";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: Moon Climbing - School Room";"$200 is an awful lot to have someone tell where to put holds.  What does this include?  The holds only?  Most of those holds look like small crimps.  I think motivationally this would get old.  I was able to download some of the problem setup and the directions of the holds are navigational only (ie. north
column2: south
column3: southwest
column4: etc.).  That doesn't leave much room for tweaking if you're really wanting to keep problems exactly the same.  For instance
column5: you'll find that turning a hold only a few degrees can often be the difference in awkward or not or the difference in sending or not.

column1: It will probably get you stronger
column2: but I think the most common problem with home walls is staying motivated.  This is in my opinion hindered by never changing the problems
column3: holds that are too similar or lack variety
column4: not being creative
column5: and uniform t-nut placement.  This last one is key in my opinion
column6: but often overlooked.  If you want a system board then uniform t-nuts (placed in rows with equal distance from each other) like the Moon system calls for is probably a good thing.  But for a fun home woody
column7: randomly placing lots of t-nuts leaves more to the imagination
column8: yields less consistent (read: boring) problems
column9: and thus creates a more motivating and fun wall.";"4b6578553b7cd0f09aed37b5a1b1198d";"0";;"2l10uwt2";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

5759;"758";"6";"10";"0";"69.225.220.128";"1250049994";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: Moon Climbing - School Room";"Yeah Fraction I pretty much agree with Stretch.  The most critcal factor in a home wall is keeping it interesting.  It's always fun and new at first
column2: but after a while it can get stale due to the limited space.  I try to compltetly strip
column3: and clean all the holds on my walls at least 3 or 4 times a year.  Here's the kicker.  In the alomost 8 years I've had my wall I've found the most fun way to set problems is to just put up all your holds up in random positions on the wall.  At this point it's like a blank canvas
column4: and you can put up problems as you see them.  No forced movement
column5: and to me it always feels like your doing a new problem.  Similar to FA's outside.  You see the moves
column6: and envision the problems.  Much more fun than forcing the movement
column7: and trying to be creative all the time.  Just my 2 cents.";"2a43f48b818885a789b0375283433e07";"0";;"36fjwy29";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

column1: 5760;"759";"6";"1844";"0";"68.2.255.67";"1250069670";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"0";;"Re: La Sportiva Solutions";"I have had 4 pairs of these and here are the negatives I have observed:

column2: especially when faily new

column1: - the rubber on the top of the toe box tends to peel off of the leather if you toe hook alot (or even a little if done aggresively enough) and thereafter just rolls on you if you try to toe hook
column2: neccesitating that you just cut it off.

column1: - there is a stitch in the interior of the shoe that runs straight down the heel of your foot. In 2 of 4 pairs that I have owned
column2: this stitch has worn through and seperated
column3: making the shoe very uncomfortable. This has only happened after the shoe rubber was very worn but
column4: nonetheless
column5: I now don't feel the shoes are worth resoling.

column1: That is about all I could come up with. Aside from smearing
column2: the shoes perform superbly. On very steep rock they are very nearly amazing. I like. I have
column3: after all
column4: purchased 4 pairs despite those complaints. The velcro closure works great and the shoes fit very comfortably on my feet almost immeadiatly. As far as sizing
column5: I wear Solutions in the same size as Katanas and 1/2 size larger than Miuras.";"3ef5d9a4d48e255d8b66fff844821d5b";"0";;"3bw3awzp";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

5896;"790";"6";"1854";"0";"64.79.127.126";"1253044260";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Organic crashpads...";"I'm looking to buy my first crashpad and am a bit overwhelmed by the choice out there.  I'm leaning towards an Organic crashpad since I've heard pretty good things about them.  I just wanted to ask a bouldering specific community -  Are they really worth the $$ and wait or should I just go with a slightly cheaper crashpad from my local rock gym or REI?
I don't boulder a whole bunch
column2: but I figure I may as well get quality if we're talking about shelling out between $150 and $200.";"e7d761b49d977b1af5e17634475ab6e0";"0";;"uvnazjax";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

column1: 5899;"790";"6";"718";"0";"99.21.5.100";"1253047428";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: Organic crashpads...";"Not exactly an Organic fan so I wanted to provide a bit of criticism.  The key thing for me is that I've landed on a couple of Organics and they are pretty stiff.  I actually landed square in the middle of one and sprained my ankle (not an ackward landing in any way
column2: but it was so stiff I might as well have landed on the ground...).  Maybe it needed to be broken in more or whatnot
column3: but my experience is that they are a bit too stiff for me.

column1: Just make sure that you get what you are looking for...do you want just a crasher or do you want one with functional aspects to it?  For example
column2: do you want extra handles? Pockets?  Do you intend on stuffing gear inside it? A flap at the bottom so if you stuff gear in between it won't fall out?  A flap on the side for the same reason?  Do you care about metal buckles or how the thing locks down? Oh...do you intend to highball it?

column1: If you don't care about most of that
column2: go with the cheapest thing out there...I believe it's the Mad Rock Double Fold?  It serves its intended purpose rather well for the price.  If you want functionality
column3: save some cash and go higher end.  My fav so far is the Black Diamond Drop Zone and Mondo.  If you can wait til Xmas
column4: you may find some SWEET internet deals...or if you can get it wholesale through your gym then go for it. REI will charge full retail; Eff That~ ";"27e325d20f72016813c4dbfd7d2b30f2";"0";;"vac9ic5k";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

column1: I'll be gettin up to black on friday morning and try to get the free group site #4/5. We are unsure if we should bring a pony keg or full keg this year. We have yet to actually finish a full size one during this event ( some will find this sad). But either way

column1: It's only bouldering around the camping areas
column2: however a short drive to Idyllwild will give you much taller pieces of granite (but you all should know this).
maps
column3: and pics of the place)

column1: -Right on San Gorgonio Ave (highway 243) head up the mountain for about 15 miles
-Left at Black Moutain Sign. (there are 2 - don't go to the trail head   parking lot
column2: go to the second sign.) Take this dirt road for about 5 miles staying left at the fork in the road. Pass a sign that points to boulder basin campground on the left down a short road. Our campsite should be about a mile further down the road. If you get to a gated group campground you're almost there. Pass this campground and go uphill around a couple turns and a large pullout should be on your left. These are campsites 4 and 5 and you should find us here.

column1: High clearance not needed but drive slow if you don't have it.

column1: 5881;"783";"1";"21";"0";"72.130.139.32";"1252691776";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: Mt Woodson";"The main approach is from the East. Mt. Woodson lies along highway 67 between Poway and Ramona. Park about three miles north of the Hwy. 67 Poway Rd junction in the vicinity of the state forestry fire station. A short dirt trail passes through the trees until it hits a paved road which winds all the way to the top of Mt. Woodson. (http://members.cox.net/sandiegorock/cli ... odson.html)
Directions to certain boulders are almost impossible.  Even with a map I had from the SD guidebook
column2: it's incredibly difficult to find stuff.  I'd suggest staying towards the bottom of the hill near the Warm Up Boulders or the Sunday Afternoon Boulder.  If you've got time on your hands (to get a little lost)
column3: I always take new-comers to Big Horn.  It's got a ton of great problems on it. (see link below)

column2: directions are tough.  So here's some GPS for ya.  Go grab Google Earth and you'll figure it all out.

column1: ...if you're at the base of Robbins Crack
column2: there's a few fun and tall 5.10's directly behind you:
but mega-classic):
roadside):

column1: (just down the road from Hamburger Crack)
Big Grunt (tall 5.9 chimney in a huge boulder)
The Cave (one of my fav's.  v2/3 roof into a tall 5.11):
Big Horn (i could spend all day on this boulder)
Also - wear light pants.  You might end up doing some bushwacking
column2: and you're best to avoid the cuts and sometimes poison oak.

column1: 6461;"886";"1";"1942";"0";"75.80.234.71";"1283708137";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Best glue?";"I hooked a hold off practicing some aid bouldering and need to replace it ASAP.  What do you guys use?";"52fef19e0284f7e43f8077834952839a";"0";;"3pyoa2ct";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

6462;"886";"1";"718";"0";"174.67.221.100";"1283719617";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: Best glue?";"We actually don't use glue anymore as modifying or otherwise "manufacturing" any sort of problem/route (chipping
column2: gluing
column3: etc.) is a major ethics violation
column4: and though I'm not completely sure
column5: I assume it's prohibited by law in any/all state and national parks and any other form of protected land. So we all must act accordingly.

column2: we use clear and simple Scotch Tape.

column1: The use of Scotch Tape is incredibly advantageous for problem repair as it allows us to work the problem with the repaired hold
column2: and then (here's the big kicker) allows for easy removal of the broken hold with minimal/no trace on either the boulder/face or the broken piece.  Just please remember to be considerate; pack out your used Scotch Tape and leave the broken hold near the problem for others to tape up.

column2: I don't prefer to wear my shoes increadibly tight. Don't get me wrong
column3: I do wear my shoes pretty snug
column4: but I feel that what most climbers do to their feet is akin to Victorian era girdling practices. I think most people prefer to go down about 2 sizes from their street shoes give or take a half a size. I wouldn't recommend buying any shoes that couldn't first be sized in person

column1: 5783;"759";"6";"53";"0";"208.12.121.254";"1250187494";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: La Sportiva Solutions";"I've had a couple of pairs of solutions and they kick ass.

My street shoe size is ~9.5 and I wear my solutions at 38.  I could/should probably go a few sizes larger as they're pretty tight at first (I have to use some plastic bag pieces to get my feet into them the first couple of times)
column2: but after they stretch out they're perfect.  I think they run a little smaller than the other shoes as my cobras in a size 37.5 slide on with ease..  Best to just go in somewhere and try them out though if you can.

column1: Only complaints really are the toe box rubber as mentioned already and the webbing that they use for the closure system tends to break.  You can rig that back up
column2: but it's a bummer considering the price.";"a29160c6eb6b130a858bdd2521de07d0";"0";;"3qtbzp4q";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

column1: I used to own the Metolious Cheap Bastard (http://www.spadout.com/p/metolius-cheap-bastard/)
* angled hinge (you'll find the Mad Rock just has a straight hinge
column2: which is fairly dangerous)

column1: * hinged in the middle -- angled or not
column2: it freaked me out
it was awkward to lay against something like a boulder at your back.  if it didn't fit perfectly
column3: it'd just close shut

column2: if i wanted to stuff crap inside
column3: it'd end up with a fat
column4: awkward bulge

column2: I bought the Black Diamond Impact (http://www.bouldering.com/products/Blac ... h-Pad.html)

column1: * no hinge -- which solves all my previous cons

column2: but not a huge deal

column1: I remember a crash pad review in Climbing Mag in 2007 -- they picked Organic as #1.  I can't find the article online
column2: but here's the final review for the Organic Pad: http://www.organicclimbing.com/images/editorschoice.pdf";"0cab4092186fa59c7797b308b1e71e4c";"0";;"jsdyfrgo";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"
a voodoo
column3: cordless (doesn't exist)
column4: dropzone
column5: and organic.

column1: They all work well at first
column2: but the organic is the only pad that lasts.  The madrock pads are cheap but if you climb alot they could be worn out in as little as 3-6 months.  I probably climb outside about 100-125 days per year and my organic has lasted for over 2 years and that's before Josh's new foam (which he thinks will last longer than the old stuff).  Also the center hinge combined with the continuous top sheet makes the pad almost as sturdy as a taco style pad
column3: but doesn't give you problems when you go to lay it out.  Also you are able to adjust (at least on my pad) where the straps are on the pad
column4: so you can carry it higher on your back if you're short
column5: or lower if you're tall.

column1: Mondo's are absurd... i don't know what's up with the round edges; it basically means if you have multiple pads as a landing
column2: you are guaranteed to have ankle breaking gaps between pads.

column1: I know this sounds like an organic plug

column2: I Just wanted to introduce myself. My names Marky Im 23 years old and newly into climbing
column3: mainly bouldering due to money restraints. I live about 2 miles from Mt. Rubidioux and tend to climb there with a couple friends. Ive been looking into climbing somewhere else and was looking for some tips. I dont have a legit crash pad and climb at 0-2 level of difficulty depending on the situation. My friends and I use a piece of foam and are currently in the process of hopefully getting a good pad soon. So my question is where is a good place to go for us? We tried Steele Valley on Sunday and couldnt really find aything very well and ended up giving up due to the excessive heat there. I wouldnt mind going with anyone willing to share beta and any advice and help are always greatly appreciated. I climb Thresh Hold alot and if you would like to meet there and get to know each other before going outdoors im fine with that. Anyways thanks for taking the time to read this. I look forward to meeting some if not all of you eventually and climbing all these good places you all talk about.

column2: 2009";"I just completed the comp scorecard and got these stats for the # of problems at each level. A total 135 climbs!

column1: There is plenty of room for new problems
column2: especially at V4 and up
column3: as I don't climb much harder than V4/V5. As always I am stoked to point folks towards developing new problems. Bear Valley is loaded with untapped stone which a few of you have tasted this summer since the new Supertopo "NorCal Bouldering Guide".

column1: Also folks have been contacting us about the weather for this weekend. Yes there is a small cold front coming in Saturday evening and Sunday. We are not expecting this to effect the Saturday competition. In fact the cool and breezy condition will be optimal for bouldering with daytime temps in the mid-50's & low-60's. I'm not sure I could have asked for better weather to make the shoes stick without the fingers getting cold!
Note: If this weather system materializes some of the Sunday climbing clinics may get cancelled but not the "Climber Self-Rescue Workshop".

column1: 5937;"799";"1";"3";"0";"66.74.36.198";"1255101699";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: New Joshua Tree bouldering";"Lots of new stuff in Josh. Last year was huge

column1: Echo Cove is right off the road so not sure if there would be a long hike to any of that stuff. Park in front of the cove and walk north
column2: in the small canyon left of the Cove proper. Scramble up into the rocks above/behind the cove (5min walk). The problems are scattered about. Mostly easy stuff there
column3: but cool hueco'd out rock.

5992;"805";"1";"696";"0";"96.41.76.173";"1257372178";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: Can anybody name this Josh problem?";"Lets try this again. As you drive into the parking lot
column2: on the far end to the left there is a little extension to the lot. At the very end of that lot
column3: there is a climb right off of the lot and right by a table. The climb is maybe 8 or so feet high and is facing the main road. It starts matched on a good crimp/pinch at about stomach height and moves up and left to a good crimp. You then need to make a big reach over a bulge to a long horizontal sloping crimp with a good gaston on the right side of it. Then move up to sloping lip that is angling up and right. The top was kind of grainy
column4: but not too bad. I think the grade is around v3
column5: but who knows
column6: there are still v0s there that I haven't done
column7: and I remember my friends telling me that it wasn't in the guide.";"2ac0cca76b0fb22f3624c8fad185da1b";"0";;"2osbzgxb";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

column2: my friend came through on a translation ... kinda.  She admits to being a little rusty
column3: but hopefully it'll help us understand the French and their insightful comments on the desert.

column2: I couldn't give you an exact translation--that would take a while and I'm not that good anymore....but if you want the gist...He basically says "how amazingly beautiful this area of CA is and ...that the rocks make you feel so small in the grand scheme of the earth...that there are animals that are so different than his own country...that there are blocks
column3: there are challenges in every step
column4: but we stop
column5: get some rest
column6: watch the sunset and crash...we had no where to be
column7: no schedule--the sole objective for this trip was to discover new heights to climb...we continue
column8: despite the obstacles
column9: it takes wisdom
column10: patience
column11: we persevere because of desire...our days are numbers
column12: we have to return to civilization and make our way home to France...our last challenge in order not to forget this experience
column13: to absorb our surroundings and all its wisdom..one last sunrise for one last try"...(and then the video wouldn't play anymore)[/quote:gpgw8lgt]";"686accda414155e3d7aa00084609e152";"0";"gA==";"gpgw8lgt";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

column1: 6045;"809";"1";"1842";"0";"134.71.74.232";"1258483206";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: Indian Cove Bouldering";"Well I spent most of the weekend guiding for a group of scouts so I didn't get to do quite the development I wanted.  I did find a couple of solid pieces of rock.  Pixie rock of course has its crazy caveman-like cave traverse.  The lip traverse I'd say goes at about V4 or 5 and the low traverse will go at about V8 or 9.  In campsite 17 there is an awesome crystally V8 stem problem.  I also found one super no-fall slabby high ball on the backside of the main area.

I'm going back to JTree this weekend to spend a day in Hidden Valley and then guide in Indian Cove for a few days so I'll be getting some pictures and video up on these rocks and plenty more.  Personally I'm stoked on the area.  I think there is going to be a lot to get excited about in the area.";"a63ad3b53451e1bfcb1fd4c3f033c424";"0";;"rxe9u3yn";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

6062;"812";"1";"753";"0";"71.139.226.88";"1259292689";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"i need some Jtree directions.";"whats up guys. i need some direction to the problems alexandria and pumping mazonite. any helps appreciated

Pumping is at Cap Rock.  Follow Park Blvd past Intersection Rock.  Turn Right at the paved road heading toward Keys Point.  Cap Rock will be the conglomerations immediately on the left hand side.  Parking lot is on the left.

column2: one on your left and one on your right.  Follow the obvious trail from the parking lot (starting next to the outhouse) toward the conglomeration on the right
column3: staying on the left fork as it leads you left and around. Keep looking straight ahead along the trail and you'll see the problem boulder (more distinctly the trail passes between two very large
column4: close together boulders; the one on the left is the problem boulder). Another tell-tale sign for the problem boulder is that upon walking up to it via these directions
column5: if you look up near the obvious lip of the boulder from the trail
column6: you should see a couple of shallow huecos with chalk on them
column7: low enough to jump to.  I forget which problem that is
column8: some V5-V6 thing.  Pumping Monzonite is on the opposite arete
column9: starting on the huge thread near the bottom.  Go get it Aztec!

column1: I've updated the database for Relic:
Eliminates  - deliberately not using certain holds
column2: usually the big jugs
column3: etc. - almost always harder.

column1: Sit Down Starts (SDS) speak for themselves - almost always harder.
Variations - different start or different finish - can be easier or harder.

column2: but can also be called the same name as the original route with Eliminate
column3: SDS or Var. tagged on the end.

column1: New problems or not? This is tricky. Not a new problem if they were spawned from the original problem
column2: but rather a new eliminate
column3: new SDS
column4: or new variation to the original problem.

column2: if a problem has a completely different start and/or finish
column3: but only uses one or two holds of the original boulder problem
column4: I'd say it could legitimately be called a separate (new) problem. Perhaps also if it's significantly different in concept.";"1e700f2662f73472b7359dc4382f8b18";"0";;"33bdnubd";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

column1: Alright so my recent 'discussion' with stretch about the Yabo Roof Traverse.  He believes sharp jugs and a 10 foot traverse 5 feet off the ground equate to one star.  Completely his opinion based on what he perceives rock quality to be as well as quality of movement. For me
column2: completely different opinion.  Quality of movement was almost equal to that of White Rastafarian
column3: except much more technical.  The jugs were sharp but felt perfectly fine to me.  Technical sequence into a rather perfect mantle (not hard but no gimme either).  For me this was [i:2epi000i]at least[/i:2epi000i] a 3 out of 5-star problem.

column2: it's consensus opinion on quality.  But even that can be so subjective based on the climber's physical aspects or possibly in the above case
column3: different envisioned/executed sequence of movement.

column1: I would LOVE to see a bio for some of the older
column2: classic lines in JTree though (I didn't see it addressed in the thread but rTm
column3: consider this my request for it PLEASE!).  Not that the brief history's given in the JTree and Tram guides were bad.  I just would have liked to know more about some of the individual contributors. and more of the history in-depth.   I love the bios and history included in the Bishop guide.  Being able to read about Bishop's history
column4: who's treaded though there
column5: who's put up what lines
column6: etc.
column7: it allows the reader/climber to attain a deeper appreciation for what the place has to offer. Brief bio's on some of JTree's desert rats (especially Long
column8: Hill and the late and great Bachar) would be sweet.  For me
column9: that kind of knowledge is powerful

column1: 6138;"790";"6";"30";"0";"76.170.154.182";"1263582102";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: Organic crashpads...";"I missed this thread but would still like to chime in. I'm sure nsmonkeygirl that you've already bought a crashpad. Anyways
column2: there are basically only a few types of pad out there. The dominant style is an open cell foam pad
column3: top layer approx. 1 inch closed cell foam
column4: with primarily shoulder straps. This type of pad can not carry too much since the load is on the shoulders. Regarding the foam
column5: the heavier it is
column6: the better it is. That's a bit generalized
column7: but is mostly true. I use a flashed pad (I'm also biased in that I'm one of their product testers)
column8: a shogun
column9: and the foam has been seriously used for maybe 5 or more years
column10: and I've had them replace the cover once
column11: last month
column12: and the top closed cell layer some time early last year
column13: I think. The open cell foam used by flashed is one of the heavier if not the heaviest out there
column14: but it's also basically bombproof. It's in perfect condition to this day. All closed cell breaks down
column15: and it's supposed to do that. It takes the brunt of the shock on impact and needs to be replaced on occasion. The outer cover was still usable
column16: but flashed replaced mine to test the addition of top supports that pull the upper part close to my back and shoulders.

column1: Of the two types of conventional pads
column2: the heavier ones with better open cell foam need more support for carrying them. The flashed conventional pads are the only ones that I know of with a real or serious hip harness. The lighter you are and the less capable your shoulders are for taking the weight of pad and gear
column3: a hip system makes a huge difference. All their pads with full hip support ride very well. I can easily hike for 2 hours one way
column4: seriously
column5: without any issues and carrying a full day's load of water
column6: camera stuff
column7: food and gear.

column1: the other type of pad is an air pad system
column2: and I only know of flashed air pad that's in production
column3: but I'm sure someone might fill me in on others. It's quite different in characteristics and is heavier than other pads. The primary strength of the air pad is that it absorbs almost all the kinetic energy on impact. What this means is that you don't get that rebound shock from the open cell foam trying to return to it's original form. For most peeps (younger mainly) it's no big deal to deal with
column4: but in the long run
column5: there is the possibility that the conventional pads could cause knee and lower back issues. Of course this is premised on the fact that one is actually falling from a decent height repeatedly. Also
column6: the edges on the air pad don't hold up to a fixed corner or edge
column7: so it's very forgiving if you land on the edge. the downside is it because it doesn't hold up
column8: pushed up against a conventional pad will expose the conventional pad's edge. The higher you fall
column9: the better the air pad is
column10: IMHO. The air pad also doesn't hold a rigid base or form against irregular surfaces. This can be both good and bad. The good is that it'll conform and deform on impact when the surface is angled--meaning it acts as if the surface is flat. A conventional pad will literally "kick" you off and down the slope of the pad. The bad is that the air will not establish a rigid and flat surface over irregularities. Sharp objects will cause the pad to not be as effective and will potentially create a risk of impact if not fixed by other means (mainly to use a conventional pad to flatten the area first). The air pad is expensive. The latest design of the airpad now rides very good. It has the upper straps to pull the top close
column11: and it uses the full suspension.

column2: I feel it's the best there is. It has limitations
column3: that should improve with better technology and design. What makes it so good has everything to do with the impact feel. I typically take one air pad and one conventional pad. Because it's expensive
column4: I think it's best suited for those wanting to do highballs. because the edges are forgiving
column5: it's perfect as the top layer and strike zone sitting over conventional pads.

column1: A buddy of mine recently had his lower spine fuzed
column2: after twice rupturing a disc. He loves highballs and he's not afraid to go for it. It cost him. He uses the air pad now and swears by it. No one can say what the causes are for his back problem
column3: but I really do think
column4: anecdotally
column5: that had he had an air pad the whole time
column6: he wouldn't have a fuzed spine today. just my opinion. of course
column7: how one falls has tons to do with impact as well as one's genes
column8: I'm sure.

column1: I assume by your name that you're a chick
column2: if so
column3: the temple works very well and isn't a small pad. I've had several women say it's their best crash pad and they love the way it carries. Their small and their shoulders took a beating with the conventional designs sans serious waist strap.

column1: 6141;"223";"1";"718";"0";"99.21.5.100";"1263632091";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: star ratings and their purpose?";"I wouldn't say so.  Again Yabo Roof Traverse was awesome for me.  Highballs get'em I think because they potentially bring into play a mental crux.  If the crux of White Rastafarian were only 5 feet off the ground
column2: it wouldn't be that fun or exciting.  But with that stupid-ass boulder in the fall zone and a crux roughly 15 feet up
column3: there's a little bit more to think through
column4: especially if you're scared of heights.  So yeah if you enjoy dealing with a mental crux due to height or bad landing areas (or both in this case)
column5: then there's definitely going to be a higher degree of satisfaction upon sending
column6: and within that
column7: enjoyment.

column2: I like jacked up landing zones too.  They can put just as much of a fear factor into play as being super high off the ground.  With that
column3: I would also put that into consideration for quality.  For example
column4: the landing zone for Illuminatrix at the Tram...two words came to mind when we first saw it..."Fuck That". haha  only a V4 but still would be a proud send for those who like the thrill of serious injury or potential death.  Oh and don't forget Up 40 in JTree; 30+ feet high
column5: X-Rated landing~  I see it as a noteworthy achievement for anyone who can master their fears enough to send wicked problems like that.
