column1: When it comes down to it
column2: a guide needs to tell you three things about a problem: If you can do it
column3: if you want to do it
column4: where it is. A rating answers the first question
column5: stars are for the second
column6: and directions/descriptions are for the third. We can only climb so hard and we only only have so much time to climb
column7: so ratings and stars are really where it's at. Imagine going to Bishop and not even visiting the Buttermilks because the guide didn't tell you they were awesome. Or going to Font and skipping Bas Cuvier. Or spending a Yosemite trip exclusively on the glacier point apron
column8: simply out of negligence. Just as certain areas are better than others
column9: certain climbs are better than others. Sometimes it is pretty subjective
column10: but most people agree most of the time. Stem Gem is a great problem
column11: the choss behind it sucks. The right side of the Gallery at Red Rocks is super fun
column12: but the left side is short
column14: and miserable.

column1: There is room for reasonable disagreement with stars
column2: just as there is room for reasonable disagreement with the grade. People can have different reasonable thoughts as to whether a problem is v4 or v5
column3: whether a problem is ** or ***. But it is rare that one person says a problem is v4 and another v10. Same for stars. Truly horrible problems are universally acknowledged as such
column4: as are the very best. When it comes down to it
column5: this is what really matters
column6: and stars convey this information efficiently and clearly.

column2: but stars that consider too much information including height
column3: style or type of climbing
column4: character or nature of holds
column5: lay of the line (so to speak)
column6: history
column7: rock quality
column8: fall quality
column9: etc. is a star system that is too all inclusive
column10: becoming too arbitrary. Over time
column11: I find that it's useless. I just look at the little pictures and then try and judge for myself.

column1: There needs to be a balance and there needs
column2: I think

column4: but it was only do-able in hiking boots.  Also due to the snow level none of the climbs are discernible.  I've been up there a lot and while I could vaguely tell where I was by the valleys

column1: I'm with the others.  I highly suggest JTree-Hidden Valley Campground to be specific.  Since you're going up on a Sunday or Monday morning you shouldn't have much if any trouble finding a campsite.  Most of the campsites have fire pits which is a definite win.  You don't need a reservation for the site which will make life easier with the short notice.  And of course the desert night sky is always a winner for a trip with the girl.  As far as the climbing
column2: pick up a copy of A Complete Bouldering Guidebook to Joshua Tree National Park by Robert Miramontes.  There is ample beginner to mid-range bouldering right in camp and an abundant amount of un-established rock for just walking around and jumping on stuff.

column1: 6229;"849";"1";"24";"0";"96.251.166.196";"1269317137";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Pine Mountain trip beta please";"I'm planning on taking a trip to Pine Mountain in Ojai
column2: but am not having much luck finding info.

column1: Is the campground free?  Easy to find/access?
What about the bouldering?  Is there any guidebook?  Are problems pretty easy to find?  I'm seeing there's a lot near the campground which is cool.  Any that are just a must do?

6230;"849";"1";"10";"0";"69.224.44.154";"1269318945";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: Pine Mountain trip beta please";"When are you planning on going?  If it's soon better check for road closures.  Like most high altitude areas access is limited during the winter/early spring months.  Call the Forset Service for info:  (805) 646-4348.  Pretty sure there is a nominal fee for camping
column2: but the site's are nice and it won't break the bank.  Ton's of bouldering in and around the campground as well as all over the mountain.  Many great easy problems and moderates.  Really cool sandstone
column3: and probably one of the best and most overlooked bouldering areas in So Cal.  As for guides pickup Bob Bank's "Oceans Eleven".  It covers Pine Mountain as well as the Santa Barbara areas
column4: and the now defunct Swimming Hole.  On a side note it may be one of the best guidebooks I've ever owned
column5: not so much for the info
column6: but the humor and the history.  Hope this helps.

its quite popular over at arcadia rock climbing as we try to push ourselves to do the hardest stuff on it.

currently its been about how much weight you can dead hang with on the smallest crimps the moonboard has to offer. one of my buddies holds the current record (for our gym i dunno there may be someone doing more at another gym.) at 100 pounds for alittle over 5 seconds.  theres a video online of it. i max out at about 47 pounds. but anyways lemme know if any of you are fellow hangers!";"0cbed068a8c7ddab6d6634f0c1982d00";"0";;"r0lkcukw";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

column2: for one I bouldered on that very same boulder in the late 80's and funny thing - at that time there happened to be chalk on it. I asked around and found that that boulder as well as numerous others in the vicinity were climbed back in the early to mid 1980's. You have to remember that bouldering has been going on out there for 30+ years if not more.

column1: It's foolish to assume that just because a boulder or boulder problem isn't in the guidebook means it hasn't been done
column2: especially something right off the road and super obvious
column3: and a problem having no chalk on it means absolutely nothing.

column1: Cool that you're getting out there and exploring beyond what's in the guidebook because it's literally the tip of the iceberg. If you want some ideas on other areas to check out let me know.";"6ddd0893d4972b68b42c89ab0cac619c";"0";"gA==";"2aj5o9pe";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

column1: 6255;"846";"1";"1898";"0";"76.95.23.162";"1272152031";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: New Boulder @ Split Rock parking lot";"Thank you for the info Daytripper.  It IS J-tree and I should have assumed EVERYTHING here has been climbed
column2: the only thing that threw me off is that the hold around the left side of the arete broke several times on me and is now about 1/4 of the size it was when I first attempted it.  I would hate to leave this problem unnamed (I personally think unnamed climbs should be limited to the trash that is scattered around the actually fun problems) so if an original name cannot be remembered I would suggest "reacharound" due to the super balancy fun move where you need to reach with your right hand around the left side of the arete to grab the crimp.  So respond with what you other J-tree climbers think!

column1: P.S. Dont start E-bashing me cause you think I'm trying to push my own agenda I'm just trying to give a name to a very cool problem so we don't need to refer to it as "that problem on the left side of the boulder in the split rock parking lot"";"9edd2d4da6374bf7da7e315295340e1e";"0";;"29fd1a57";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

6256;"846";"1";"718";"0";"174.67.221.100";"1272190060";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: New Boulder @ Split Rock parking lot";" I remember this argument. I believe there are a number of folks who would agree you. I personally would rather there be a name for a problem that's enjoyable because unnamed problems tend to have this stigma of sucking (you yourself even elude to this in your posting) when they actually may not suck at all (i.e. what you enjoy may be completely different from what someone else enjoys).
But when a name is unknown and the problem has been done before
column2: it's better to leave history as-is. Besides
column3: JTree is almost infinite when it comes to undiscovered boulders and problems and if you're willing to wander the desert a bit
column4: you'll be sure to find something that needs an FA. Though I've been pretty far out there at times only to find chalk even in the most remote areas.

column1: Some other indicators that a problem has been climbed before are completely clean/flat landing areas or flattened/mangled plants at or around the base of a boulder.  Breakage (or choss/grain/kitty litter) is natural due erosion. Consider that this boulder probably hasn't seen much traffic and is for the most part exposed (weather having a bigger impact on it; rain washing away chalk for example); It isn't surprising that a hold or two may have eroded over a long period of time
column2: just waiting to be broken off.

column1: The oldschoolers are an almost endless well of info on JTree
column2: so if in doubt or want confirmation
column3: get feedback from them.

column1: I am a little bit hesitating between Bishop (too hot?)
column2: the Tram and Black Mountain... What's your feeling between Tram and BM? Do I have a chance to meet some climbers at that time? Do you know if I can rent a pad somewhere (I'd prefer not to bring mine overseas for 2 days bouldering...)? Where can I find a the Black Mountain guidebook (even DrTopo's one)? Is the Tram guidebook up to date?

column1: Thanks in advance for answering the questions you can ;o)

column2: webmaster of [url:3dwtcs1s]http://www.zebloc.com[/url:3dwtcs1s] (where you may find few articles in english in the english content menu)...";"b11ca1dfb691538a7acd30831f1057ee";"0";"EA==";"3dwtcs1s";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

column1: I can tell you that the tram guide came out a couple years ago
column2: but is pretty current. I hear there's a lot of snow still up there but you can get to the boulders.

column1: Black Mt has some interesting restraints right now. The loggers up there have all the gates closed down to the paved road but they may not be there around your time frame. The newer area called the "the Republic" is accessible and has no gates but you will want a high clearance vehicle to get up the dirt road and you can camp up there. There is no real guidebook for the area yet but one is currently underway. The author and myself will most likely be up there on the 23rd. A huge climbing gym we work at is opening on the 22nd and we'll have to be there for that unfortunately.

I've also heard Bishop is heating up. I'd say your best bet is a day at tram and a day at Black. Stay current on the forum and you should find some peeps to climb/tour you around with that weekend.";"3acd66ea73bfd7e7ccc453057d132c61";"0";;"28rkbisw";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

6275;"855";"1";"5";"0";"66.75.17.2";"1272599567";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: Bouldering near (or not far from) LA by May 22nd?";"There are multiple gates. The halfway point up the dirt road has one that's closed for "snow" and a lower gate where the dirt meets pavement. The loggers up there have the lowest one closed (at the pavement) so people don't get in the way of the trucks coming and going. Lame on their part! We talked to a guy a couple weeks ago and he said they would be gone for a month or so and the gate would open - then they would be back. Not sure where this open month falls. That had no actual dates for us.
How hard you lookin to get on? The Republic has some awesome lines and is not affected by the loggers.";"f1033c3fbe5cb7780421db3e4dd09796";"0";;"w0trmcbk";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

column2: # 663 boulder in the guidebook pages 234 & 237.

column1: It's basically a climb up the right arete & face but finishing in the middle/left at the top of the boulder among all the spider webs I used the big jug on the .8 problem and the crack in the center of the face for the start. I did my best to clean it off so it's there to try.
If it's an FA I would be honored
column2: but if not
column3: it is a nice problem in my book!

column2: there's a small boulder with a low roof  (approx 5 feet high) that's NW of Franks Roof up the hill right over the fallen down tree that's not in the guide. Anyone seen this? I tried it last season and saw some chalk on it so I'm in no way stating an FA.  Squat start on the low brick on the right then top out in the center with a heinous mantle. If you haven't seen it
column3: it's a fun challenge!

column1: 6405;"879";"1";"718";"0";"12.31.165.98";"1281641262";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: Is "comfortising" the same as "chipping"?";"I think he's just saying the Happy's feel a little better vs the other sharpness you'll encounter in other areas of Bishop.

Ok...even mentioning the possibility that this might be OK in Joshua Tree is just plain sacrilege.  Comfortising == Chipping.  You're basically altering holds through means other than the natural wear-and-tear of Mother Nature or years of climbing traffic.
If it's too sharp for you

column2: the new Chief ranger
column3: Sue
column4: is on the verge of laying down the law on bouldering at Tram. It seems that irresponsible boulderers are creating problems
column5: not only with impact
column6: but with climber-ranger relations as well as being a nuisance to other forest users.

column1: The park service is in the process of writing policy that could result in severe restrictions on bouldering.
I urge everyone to come to the clean up
column2: not only to show support and to show that there are boulderers that care
column3: but also to voice your opinion before this new policy takes effect.

column1: 6448;"883";"1";"1929";"0";"76.95.23.162";"1282719223";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: Tram Clean Up day 2";"These cleanup days are great!  Since I started going to tram I have seen climber impact on the mountain.  Go to any climbing area and you will see used tape
column2: spilled chalk
column3: smashed plants and braided trails.  It may be true that the non-climbers there have a greater impact on the park (possibly because there are significantly more of them) but you will typically find that they don't tend to wander far off trail or far from the station.  We as climbers tend to visit more remote areas and wander off trail whenever we go.  I can't tell you how many different "braids" of trail I have seen when there is already an obvious trail heading out to certain areas.

column1: It will of course be easier for rangers to target boulderers because we are an actual group that can be targeted
column2: unlike tourists.  Tourists come maybe twice in a year (or in a lifetime) so having a chat with them is pretty pointless.
egos and attitudes the rangers are there to protect the park.  It is their job and we must understand that.  In my opinion
column3: it is our responsibility to work with the rangers to ensure the park stays clean with as little an impact as possible.  It isn't OUR mountain
column4: its natures and we need to respect that (this is the reason the entire park system was set up).  I have a feeling a lot of the "problem" boulderers are tram virgins or go very rarely (which would definitely explain the trail braiding).  Maybe posting a sign specifically for boulderers in the station or at the permit location that lists some climbing etiquette rules may make the rangers feel a little better about us.  Remember
column5: you catch more bees with honey than a big ole pile of stinkin' shit; which
column6: make sure you bury atleast 6 inches down .";"f71629bf9fba88ea1c24f74a783631f3";"0";;"1bu91ufi";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

column1: 6449;"883";"1";"3";"0";"67.49.249.115";"1282754856";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: Tram Clean Up day 2";"Many of the bouldering-related problems at Tram are the same problems that have plagued the area for the last five years or so: braided trails
column2: cigarette butts
column3: tape wads
column4: fruit rinds
column5: abuse of chalk
column6: loud music and yelling.

column1: New problems include: much larger posse's bringing many more pads
column2: an increase of chalk use and tick marks
column3: louder groups with less of a concern for the wilderness (probably due to a change in the demograph of boulderers).

column1: There are also several disturbing and totally unacceptable new trends that I have not seen before this year: one is the building of platforms on sloping landings
column2: and the other is debris stripping an entire area beneath a boulder problem (I'm talking every twig and pebble
column3: leaving a barren patch of dirt).

column1: The main difference now at Tram
column2: is that we have a new Park Service staff
column3: seeing the problems with fresh eyes and having the will to make change. Whether we like it or not
column4: this change is inevitable.

column1: Even if we win this round and things stay the same
column2: current bouldering habits are leading us down a road that will ultimately end in severe restrictions
column3: not only at Tram
column4: but across the entire country. The bouldering community need to open its eyes and change its ways ...quickly! Make no mistake
column5: wilderness authorities and the National Park Service is amassing data
column6: they have been for years now. Cold
column7: hard and indesputable data that will be used to create a policy that preserves the wilderness and curbs bouldering impact. If any of you think we can preserve our freedoms with nothing more than witty comments and uncompromising attitudes
column8: then you are sadly mistaken.";"4af51c46cbbc3d0bffc6784b20fb1f56";"0";;"6h2mbqy2";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

CA";"Hi everyone
column3: my name is Robbie Ogle.  Some friends and myself have started a little climbing group in Hemet
column4: CA
column5: spending most of our time in James Simpson Park and a couple of trips to JTree.  Jack Mcbroom has showed us the ropes up there and now I would like to step up and digitize the information we have logged from Simpson Park; and this site seems like the perfect place to start!

column1: So I just wanted to stop by
column2: say hi
column3: and let you know that a community of climbers are growing in Hemet.  We are calling ourselves "Team Limestoned"  and you can catch us a group on Facebook
column4: we have some videos on YouTube
column5: and a website should be coming soon!  Hit us up if you are ever in the area
column6: we enjoy the company and learning from others!

column1: Contact Robbie Ogle at teamlimestoned@gmail.com

column2: we have only been climbing for a month

The thing about climbing on sandstone after rains is that you may not think you're damaging the rock
column2: especially on large hold problems
column3: but it applies stress to the structure of the rock and can cause it to be much more brittle
column4: drastically decreasing the lifespan of a hold.

column2: Planet of the Apes Wall in Malibu tends to stay dryer and dry out faster than other areas in the park.

column1: Horse Flats is made of Granite so should be A-Ok
column2: it takes about an hour from LA and you my have to walk a mile in if the gates closed though- I don't think it has too much if any snow this year.

column1: There are also a few destination south/east of LA that are granite and not so affected by rain/snow
column2: Joshua Tree and Steele Valley come to mind immediately";"adca3d11c76dfbb62c356bc1b14dbd57";"0";;"1l0ux3o7";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

column1: 6578;"917";"1";"16";"0";"166.241.184.224";"1299189643";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: Steele valley is sick! How does Wasabi finish?";"After the opening moves
column2: there are a few longish moves to crisp crimps running pretty much vertically up and left from the start. The problem traverses left at the top.

column1: You can also bump up the difficulty (much harder) by starting further right and traversing into the problem.  To my knowledge
column2: this has not been climbed yet.

column1: There's also a short problem to the right of Wasabi that I was trying
column2: but wasn't able to control the hold after the big move.  This line pretty much revolves around a big move to the obvious large edge
column3: before topping out up and right on the lower summit.  It's a shorter line
column4: but equally good.

column2: and let us know if you end up adding anything good out there...

column1: 6638;"949";"1";"3";"0";"98.155.103.196";"1302707822";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Jacinto (Tram Bouldering) land managment meeting";"Stand up for your rights!
Thanks to Tom Donnely for posting this on Mountain Project:

column2: but access isn't exactly easy and some of the boulders are seriously overgrown.

column1: It's far easier if you have a car. Park near the top of Bienvenida Ave. in Pacific Palisades and walk in via the Leacock Trail to the Bienvenida Trail to the Temescal Ridge Trail
column2: turning left each time you can.

column1: If you don't have a car
column2: take the bus to the Temescal Canyon stop and walk in via the Temescal Ridge Trail. The first way is about 1.2 miles with a fair amount of uphill. The second is about 2.5 miles with a good deal more uphill.

column1: The most obvious boulder is right on the trail. there are a few good problems on the back side in the V0 - V2 range
column2: including a fun little problem with sweet mono (not sure of name or grade - feels V2ish). There is potential for harder stuff
column3: but the landings are not great.

column1: The other boulders are in the scrub downhill from the trail. Again
column2: there is enough to keep somebody busy for a while
column3: but the uphill hike to access the boulders and the thick brush are obstacles. The bouldering is all on relatively solid sandstone. Don't bother after rain as the rock gets very saturated and weak and you'll end up breaking holds.";"40f7c768bee8ad589df5de421def38e4";"0";;"37m6s8ev";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

column1: 6677;"986";"1";"2033";"0";"76.249.191.42";"1303759705";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Joshua Tree Clean Up Event-- THIS SATURDAY!";"Thresh Hold has put together a great volunteer event with Joshua Tree National Park and you are invited! On April 30th Meet at Intersection Rock at 10am. Bernadette
column2: the climbing ranger
column3: will get us started on our projects. Possible projects include chalk clean-ups
column4: social trail restoration
column5: or watering the new plants at Echo Cove or along Geo Tour Road. Each participant will receive one raffle ticket in the morning. Bring your cup because Bernadette also brews up some good coffee. Plan for about 4 hours of volunteering.

column1: After lunch lets enjoy climbing together in the park.
Everyone is welcome to attend the event! In order for us to plan the best use of volunteers time please sign up for the event at Thresh Hold
column2: or call to register.  951-742-8479

column1: Our friends at WeClimb has generously donated a WeClimb Tee Shirt to the first 20 people that register for the event. Don't wait get your friends and sign up today.
From Riverside head EAST CA-60 E/Moreno Valley Fwy.
Take the exit on the left onto I-10 E.
Take the I-10 to exit 117 to merge onto CA-62 E/Twenty Nine Palms Hwy toward 29 Palms/Yucca Valley
Turn right at Park Blvd (west enterance of JTNP) and continue straight on the road until you see Intersection Rock on your left
(google says that it is 13.9 miles from  Rt 62 to Intersection rock and there are signs for Intersection Rock.)";"4b694604821f2858b5fff48c37ba437e";"0";;"24e3kcwg";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"
6629;"944";"6";"16";"0";"68.4.52.239";"1301704008";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: Grade Comparisons";"Not sure if it converts between route and boulder ratings
column2: but here's a recently released app:
on Saturday 4/2 I lost my down jacket in the Ice Cave in the Sads.  It is a blue Mountain Hardwear Sub-Zero down jacket that was in a black stuff sack.

column1: I asked around and found out a guy that had been climbing in the Ice Cave earlier that day had picked it up
column2: asked around about it
column3: thought it might belong to someone from his group and took it to find out.  He was a strong V11
column4: V12 climber.  He was down there to try Beefy Gecko.  I came down to try Wheel of Beef
column5: he suggested I try The Aquarium.  One guy in his crew tried The Aquatic Hitchhiker
column6: it looked cool
column7: so I tried it
column8: and he ended up on it too.  He looked to be of Mexican or South American decent.  He had very dark brown skin
column9: medium-long bushy brown hair
column10: fairly ripped but not bulky body
column11: and was wearing lime green shorts.  I overheard him saying he had been staying at The Trees motel for a week but had checked out that Saturday morning.  It was also suggested to me that he was from the Bay Area.

column1: I posted Lost posters at Wilson's and Black Sheep.
If you know anyone who matches this description or you are the guy who found my jacket
column2: please respond to this forum post or call/text me at (805) 551-4565.";"99888be35296292b23aac8e923b38edb";"0";;"ycginbix";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

column1: 6625;"944";"6";"16";"0";"68.4.52.239";"1301545623";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Re: Grade Comparisons";"You'll probably never get a solid consensus on grade comparisons - that's kind of the reason for the two grading systems in the first place.
A lot of loose comparisons can be made
column2: but things are so subjective when you're looking at the difficulty of single moves and short sequences (such as found on boulder problems and for which the V-scale exists) when compared to the longer strings of moves and sequences that make up route climbing (and the YDS system).  In fact your "15c doesn't exist
column3: so V16 can't equal it" doesn't really hold true in that someone could argue that the individual difficult moves found on a V16 could in fact result in a 15c route if that sequence was interspersed with moderately easier climbing in a route context.

column2: V0 traditionally meant 5.10+ or 5.10d.  Over the years
column3: some ratings comparisons have morphed into (I feel) easier scale comparisons
column4: but if you want to go with how the system was originally designed - that should be your starting point.

column1: I also feel that a lot of gym grades have become soft when compared to the traditional sense of the V-scale.  Because of this pattern in gyms
column2: I feel you'll start (and probably already have) seeing things get a little softer on the bottom end of the V-scale outside as more gym climbers boulder outdoors.  There are some who will (and have already) argue(d) that this is happening on the upper end of the scale too.  I can't really comment on that though.
my opinion is only one of many you'll probably receive
column3: and to some extent I'm just playing devil's advocate here...";"e8a11e3f4b6edcbb04d293a095dc6ad9";"0";;"3tswgwpi";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

column3: the comparison isn't born from actual experience or some tangible state
column4: simply because the latter doesn't exist or hasn't been established

6616;"943";"1";"718";"0";"98.164.221.198";"1301119513";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Tram Bouldering Ethics and Concerns";"As we come closer and closer to this years Tram season
column2: I thought it best to review what we learned from last years Tram Cleanup
column3: where our community participated and welcomed an open forum with the Trams current head ranger (Sue?).  Luckily
column4: she herself has a climbing background and understood our viewpoints on the whole situation! Im sure I speak for all of us when I say we appreciated her open-mindedness and understanding in what we had to say
column5: just as much as she appreciated our efforts and enthusiasm during the cleanup!

column1: Now lets re-review Ranger Sues major concerns
column2: all of which we will proactively address this coming season.  As a funny and ironic side note
column3: all these concerns are already listed in rTms Tram Bouldering guide
column4: pg 6-7. And to think we had the information all along and most likely just overlooked it!

column1: [list:bkyqaxlk][b:bkyqaxlk]1.  Pack out all trash and garbage.[/b:bkyqaxlk]  Cant tell you guys/gals how many cigarette butts
column2: used tape wads
column3: bottle caps
column4: water bottles
column5: used toilet paper strips
column6: wrappers
column7: etc. etc. I was able to find last summer.  URG!  Please remember to pack out ALL of it.

column1: [b:bkyqaxlk]2.  Have no more than 15 people in your group and hike apart from other groups.[/b:bkyqaxlk]  Last year saw some major traffic and with it
column2: unmarked trails saw some extra traffic
column3: popular areas saw a bit more trash
column4: a bit more chalk
column5: and it definitely got a little loud!  Following along with James Marchs suggestions
column6: maybe we can try to keep the groups smaller this year
column7: keep the big pads at home and only use the midsized ones
column8: maybe even do a solo trip now and again?  Ill leave that up to you guys to figure out yourselves but lets try to keep it in mind.

column1: [b:bkyqaxlk]3.  Erect no structures made from rocks
column2: branches or other natural materials.  This includes small rock cairns.[/b:bkyqaxlk]  Last year the Titanic Boulder (Year of the Cockroach & Love of Basic Cable) had a rather huge platform built underneath it.  Ill have to give props to the two guys who built it as it must have taken them at least half the day
column3: and it definitely mitigated the risk level of the fall zone.  However this was a big NO-NO and had to get torn down.  Sorry guys
column4: State Park rules...

column1: [b:bkyqaxlk]4.  No smoking.[/b:bkyqaxlk]  You know how many cigarette butts I cleaned up at the Dance Floor last summer alone? One too many!!!  State Park rules guysno smoking on the mountain.  If you gotta smoke
column2: please get your fix at the parking lot before you head up.

column1: [b:bkyqaxlk]5. No person shall appear nude.[/b:bkyqaxlk] .........

column2: molest
column3: disturb or burn any plant materials (alive or dead).[/b:bkyqaxlk]  I hope this season we do our best to stay on the main trails.  Though the majority of the climbing areas have well established trails
column4: we are still observing several braids through some of the high traffic areas.  Lets remember to move from area to area in a single-file line
column5: following established trails only
column6: allowing some of those unnecessary braids an entire summer season to revegetate.

column2: as rTm mentioned in a previous forum topic
column3: other concerns were abuse of chalk
column4: loud music and yelling.

column1: [list:bkyqaxlk][b:bkyqaxlk]Abuse of Chalk - [/b:bkyqaxlk]The chalk is simply part of climbing
column2: plain and simple.  We can however do our best to brush off as much excessive chalk as possible.  Additionally
column3: if we utilize tic marks
column4: we must always remember to brush them off after were done.  Easy enough yea?  And if you spill your bag/bucket
column5: please remember to recoup as much of it as possible and bury the rest.

column1: [b:bkyqaxlk]Loud Music - [/b:bkyqaxlk]Ive frequented the Tram solo many a time
column2: not seeing a single soul from the moment I left the Ranger Station until the time I got back.  The silence is indescribably peaceful
column3: with only the slightest breeze serving as the single intruder to my solitude. To hear thumping-a$$ hip-hop beats or Cannibal Corpse blaring in the distance can be rather annoying.  If you need music to motivate you
column4: please keep the volume low enough for yourself and/or your group.  Better yet
column5: consider busting out your iPod! On solo trips I always bust out the Shuffle vs. the portable speakers when I need that dose of Motorhead to get the send!

column1: [b:bkyqaxlk]Yelling - [/b:bkyqaxlk]Being psyched about that project you just sent is something all of us can get behind. However I witnessed some seriously excessive cussing and yelling last season (I wont say who or what LA-based gym theyre coming from ). Theres no need to run off and around the place like a little girl screaming obscenities if/when you fall off your problem. So please refrain from the YEEEAAHHHH F**K YEAHH!!!!!! when sending or running around screaming F****K!!! if you fall.
Rtm reviews these and other points in the Tram guide as well

column2: [b:bkyqaxlk]ALL areas throughout the Willow Creek Trail are still off limits to any climbing[/b:bkyqaxlk].  This includes the (roughly) 2-mile radius of wilderness area before the lake bed/drop off point on the trail.  This also includes the Frog Pond. The fine last we checked was [b:bkyqaxlk]$1000[/b:bkyqaxlk]
column3: probably a lot more now thanks to state budget cuts and fiscal reform.  I dont know many climbers who can afford that kind of fine and no send is worth ponying up a grand. So lets stay away from that area for the foreseeable future. Ill make it a point though to discuss this with Ranger Sue next time Im up there to see if we have any new updates on the areas status.

column2: hope your climbing season is still going strong!  Just remember in a couple of months Tram should be thawed out and well be on for another fun summer season!  Lets keep things clean and enjoyable for everyone!

column1: Just an update...So far the rangers are pleased with most of the cooperation they are getting this summer season. Very cool stuff and I'm glad to hear we're keeping things going in the right direction.

column2: it is equally important to maintain a good relationship with not just the park rangers
column3: but also the staff who run the PS Aerial Tramway.  I ran into some issues with the parking lot coordinator this weekend and was somewhat displeased when I asked if there were parking spots available in the upper two lots and he refused to answer my question!  Feeling a bit annoyed about this experience
column4: I went to complain to his supervisor
column5: and this is what I was told:

column1: 1.  Though there may be available spots in the mid to later afternoon in the upper two parking lots
column2: they have to maintain flow of traffic such that it is efficient for both the trolley that takes people up to/down from the station as well as for those visitors leaving in their cars.  This is why they continue to direct traffic into the lower lots despite being mid to late afternoon.

column1: 2. We can ask (NICELY!!!!) to check for higher parking spots.  They may let us do this because we're climbing and they already know we're going to be here pretty late.  However if they say NO
column2: then we need to leave it at that and take the trolley from the lower spots.

column1: 3. Some ass-clown climber almost ran over one of the parking attendants after they didn't let him pass.  The climber's response apparently was something like "I'm parking up there no matter what!".  How'd they know he was a climber? ... The guy said he was climbing today and wanted to park up higher.  This was
column2: beyond a doubt
column3: a stupid thing to do.  We originally didn't have problems with the staff at the stations and now some one-off doosher is causing one.

column1: The supervisor was cool but was disappointed with one or two folks that just don't get it.  Hopefully we won't hear of anything similar for the rest of the season but understand this; it won't matter what the rangers say or do if the staff at the Tram station don't let us up there to begin with.  These guys (especially Doug!) have been WAY cool to us thus far.  There is simply no need to cause problems with these folks.

column2: if you've heard of the incident described above and know who it is
column3: please let myself or rTm know.  This boy needs some talkin' to...";"8cbf239ce014b33703a973ba41a24188";"0";;"1631z16h";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

column1: I'm working on a short bouldering film for steele valley currently and am looking for people interested in doing interviews or climbing in it. This was originally going to be a film consisting of just my friends and I
column2: but since we're limited to the v5/6 grade it would be nice to be able to showcase the harder climbs steele has to offer. As a filmmaker I'm interested in getting steele valley more exposure as currently I feel it's a hidden gem.

column1: The film will most likely be within the 15 minute range and showcase a number of the classics along with interviews talking about the area. It would be great to get as many people on board as possible. The film won't be a big budget production and it will just be released on the internet
column2: but hopefully it will inspire others curious about the area to come check it out. I shot one video last summer on lip tricks traverse
column3: but would like to do a much more comprehensive film.

column1: Here's the links to some of my other work.
If anyone would be willing to meet up one day this summer that would help a ton as it's not often I see people there by random chance.
Feel free to contact me at joeramosmail@yahoo.com";"1918f39b32d8e78f281f0234f91410fc";"0";;"1xwpinl4";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

column1: 1. They are now having climbers fill out individual passes in an effort to survey the areas in which we frequent.  So EVERYONE in your group has to fill one out.  I didn't ask but I assume they are collecting data to study impact
column2: to monitor  the areas for any abuse or violations
column3: and to figure out how to improve access.  Hopefully this will lead to something like what we currently have in the Buttermilks (established trails and markers for re-vegetation efforts)

column1: 2. No music PERIOD.  We're now restricted to iPods and other personal music gadgets.
3. Willow Creek is STILL closed to climbing.
4. Expect to get a small brochure on bouldering/climbing ethics this season.  Read up
column2: take note and do not doubt for a second...they are passing this out to us for a reason.
we are the ones making the most use of the wilderness area.  With that
column3: it is our responsibility to keep it clean and maintain it!!!  So please remember to follow all rules and regulations.

column2: we'll post it for sure~!  Til then
column3: have a safe and fun summer climbing season!";"e42dd347e13ab78ba6af973f696b8b55";"0";;"1kp5der7";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

7339;"1523";"9";"718";"0";"98.173.13.146";"1329240642";"1";"0";"1";"1";"1";"1";;"Rename/Re-purpose the site to SoCal and Bishop only";"What do you guys think....I'd like for us to re-purpose the website to encompass SoCal and Bishop/Yosemite only i.e. let's get rid of Squamish and the rest of NorCal.  We're not a significant source of information about those areas anyway
column2: mainly because I don't think many of us frequent those places on a regular basis. From what I can tell people who contribute to this site are primarily SoCal climbers who tend to frequent Bishop (I would even question Yosemite).  This way we provide visitors with highly concentrated data for areas well known to us vs potentially inaccurate data on places we tend not to frequent. I know this may be an old topic but it's worth revisiting
column3: given sites like mountainproject
column4: rockclimbing and 8a.nu have a plethora of information that gets posted by people who aren't even local or frequent visitors to SoCal. Any thoughts?";"3932dd7a48e1e245c8df13844a2f94cb";"0";;"38b6cyhs";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"

column2: Abalone cove in Palos Verdes. In crystal cove your only decent option is the jumping rock about a mile south of corona
column3: it is not Malta but there are some fun things to mess around on and for the adventurer the arch would be epic. Don't get your hopes up
column4: it is just a fun and beautiful place to be. Best to visit at high tide so you can jump off the arch! and check out the tunnel that goes from the center of the north face into the archway
column5: and be sure to get your timing right unless you want barnacle road rash.

column1: As far as Abalone cove goes
column2: don't go there expecting to climb. There are two lines that would need an adventuring/reckless ground up cleaning which would lead to a 20-30 foot jump into a doable(high tide) but precarious channel. Like the jumping rock I find this place awesome for hanging out and exploring. Bring snorkeling gear and food and do not go on weekends. Hike south through a huge tunnel or around the point to find an awesome black sand beach which leads to a nude beach which leads to another cool set of cliffs and reefs.";"03b2e4e2d46a6d4a0669c7d3b9cac198";"0";;"2rl7vi5y";"1";"0";;"0";"0";"0"
